Towards (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_ε )-Approximate Flow Sparsifiers

Alexandr Andoni
Microsoft Research Email: andoni@microsoft.com    Anupam Gupta
CMU and MSR Work supported in part by NSF awards CCF-0964474 and CCF-1016799, US-Israel BSF grant #2010426, and by a grant from the CMU-Microsoft Center for Computational Thinking. Email: anupamg@cs.cmu.edu    Robert Krauthgamer
Weizmann Institute Work supported in part by the Israel Science Foundation grant #897/13, the US-Israel BSF grant #2010418, and by the Citi Foundation. Email: robert.krauthgamer@weizmann.ac.il
Abstract

A useful approach to “compress” a large network G𝐺Gitalic_G is to represent it with a flow-sparsifier, i.e., a small network H𝐻Hitalic_H that supports the same flows as G𝐺Gitalic_G, up to a factor q≥1𝑞1q\geq 1italic_q ≥ 1 called the quality of sparsifier. Specifically, we assume the network G𝐺Gitalic_G contains a set of k𝑘kitalic_k terminals T𝑇Titalic_T, shared with the network H𝐻Hitalic_H, i.e., T⊆V⁢(G)∩V⁢(H)𝑇𝑉𝐺𝑉𝐻T\subseteq V(G)\cap V(H)italic_T ⊆ italic_V ( italic_G ) ∩ italic_V ( italic_H ), and we want H𝐻Hitalic_H to preserve all multicommodity flows that can be routed between the terminals T𝑇Titalic_T. The challenge is to construct H𝐻Hitalic_H that is small.

These questions have received a lot of attention in recent years, leading to some known tradeoffs between the sparsifier’s quality q𝑞qitalic_q and its size |V⁢(H)|𝑉𝐻|V(H)|| italic_V ( italic_H ) |. Nevertheless, it remains an outstanding question whether every G𝐺Gitalic_G admits a flow-sparsifier H𝐻Hitalic_H with quality q=1+ε𝑞1𝜀q=1+\varepsilonitalic_q = 1 + italic_ε, or even q=O⁢(1)𝑞𝑂1q=O(1)italic_q = italic_O ( 1 ), and size |V⁢(H)|≤f⁢(k,ε)𝑉𝐻𝑓𝑘𝜀|V(H)|\leq f(k,\varepsilon)| italic_V ( italic_H ) | ≤ italic_f ( italic_k , italic_ε ) (in particular, independent of |V⁢(G)|𝑉𝐺|V(G)|| italic_V ( italic_G ) | and the edge capacities).

Making a first step in this direction, we present new constructions for several scenarios:

  • •

    Our main result is that for quasi-bipartite networks G𝐺Gitalic_G, one can construct a (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_ε )-flow-sparsifier of size poly⁡(k/ε)poly𝑘𝜀\operatorname{poly}(k/\varepsilon)roman_poly ( italic_k / italic_ε ). In contrast, exact (q=1𝑞1q=1italic_q = 1) sparsifiers for this family of networks are known to require size 2Ω⁢(k)superscript2Ω𝑘2^{\Omega(k)}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Ω ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  • •

    For networks G𝐺Gitalic_G of bounded treewidth w𝑤witalic_w, we construct a flow-sparsifier with quality q=O⁢(log⁡w/log⁡log⁡w)𝑞𝑂𝑤𝑤q=O(\log w/\log\log w)italic_q = italic_O ( roman_log italic_w / roman_log roman_log italic_w ) and size O⁢(w⋅poly⁡(k))𝑂⋅𝑤poly𝑘O(w\cdot\operatorname{poly}(k))italic_O ( italic_w ⋅ roman_poly ( italic_k ) ).

  • •

    For general networks G𝐺Gitalic_G, we construct a sketch s⁢k⁢(G)𝑠𝑘𝐺sk(G)italic_s italic_k ( italic_G ), that stores all the feasible multicommodity flows up to factor q=1+ε𝑞1𝜀q=1+\varepsilonitalic_q = 1 + italic_ε, and its size (storage requirement) is f⁢(k,ε)𝑓𝑘𝜀f(k,\varepsilon)italic_f ( italic_k , italic_ε ).

1 Introduction

A powerful tool to deal with big graphs is to “compress” them by reducing their size — not only does it reduce their storage requirement, but often it also reveals opportunities for more efficient graph algorithms. Notable examples in this context include the cut and spectral sparsifiers of [BK96, ST04], which have had a huge impact on graph algorithmics. These sparsifiers reduce the number of edges of the graph, while preserving prominent features such as cut values and Laplacian spectrum, up to approximation factor 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε. This immediately improves the runtime of graph algorithms that depend on the number of edges, at the expense of (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_ε )-approximate solutions. Such sparsifiers reduce only the number of edges, but it is natural to wonder whether more is to be gained by reducing the number of nodes as well. This vision — of “node sparsification” — already appears, say, in [FM95].

One promising notion of node sparsification is that of flow or cut sparsifiers, introduced in [HKNR98, Moi09, LM10], where we have a network (a term we use to denote edge-capacitated graphs) G𝐺Gitalic_G, and the goal is to construct a smaller network H𝐻Hitalic_H that supports the same flows as G𝐺Gitalic_G, up to a factor q≥1𝑞1q\geq 1italic_q ≥ 1 called the quality of sparsifier H𝐻Hitalic_H. Specifically, we assume the network G𝐺Gitalic_G contains a set T𝑇Titalic_T of k𝑘kitalic_k terminals shared with the network H𝐻Hitalic_H, i.e., T⊆V⁢(G)∩V⁢(H)𝑇𝑉𝐺𝑉𝐻T\subseteq V(G)\cap V(H)italic_T ⊆ italic_V ( italic_G ) ∩ italic_V ( italic_H ), and we want H𝐻Hitalic_H to preserve all multicommodity flows that can be routed between the terminals T𝑇Titalic_T. (A formal definition is given in Section 2.) A somewhat simpler variant is a cut sparsifier, which preserves the single-commodity flow from every set S⊂T𝑆𝑇S\subset Titalic_S ⊂ italic_T to its complement T∖S𝑇𝑆T\setminus Sitalic_T ∖ italic_S, i.e., a minimum-cut in G𝐺Gitalic_G of the terminals bipartition T=S∪(T∖S)𝑇𝑆𝑇𝑆T=S\cup(T\setminus S)italic_T = italic_S ∪ ( italic_T ∖ italic_S ). Throughout, we consider undirected networks (although some of the results apply also for directed networks), and unless we say explicitly otherwise, flow and cut sparsifiers refer to their node versions, i.e., networks on few nodes that support (almost) the same flow.

The main question is: what tradeoff can one achieve between the quality of a sparsifier and its size? This question has received a lot of attention in recent years. In particular, if the sparsifier is only supported on T𝑇Titalic_T (achieves minimal size), one can guarantee quality q≤O⁢(log⁡klog⁡log⁡k)𝑞𝑂𝑘𝑘q\leq O\big{(}\frac{\log k}{\log\log k}\big{)}italic_q ≤ italic_O ( divide start_ARG roman_log italic_k end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_k end_ARG ) [Moi09, LM10, CLLM10, EGK+{}^{+}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT + end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT10, MM10]. On the other hand, with this minimal size, the (worst-case) quality must be q≥Ω~⁢(log⁡k)𝑞~Ω𝑘q\geq\tilde{\Omega}(\sqrt{\log k})italic_q ≥ over~ start_ARG roman_Ω end_ARG ( square-root start_ARG roman_log italic_k end_ARG ) [LM10, CLLM10, MM10], and thus a significantly better quality cannot be achieved without increasing the size of the sparsifier. The only other result for flow sparsifiers, due to [Chu12], achieves a constant quality sparsifiers whose size depends on the capacities in the original graph. (Her results give flow sparsifiers of size CO⁢(log⁡log⁡C)superscript𝐶𝑂𝐶C^{O(\log\log C)}italic_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( roman_log roman_log italic_C ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; here C𝐶Citalic_C is the total capacity of edges incident to terminals and hence may be Ω⁢(n⁢k)Ω𝑛𝑘\Omega(nk)roman_Ω ( italic_n italic_k ) even for unit-capacity graphs.) For the simpler notion of cut sparsifiers, there are known constructions at the other end of the tradeoff. Specifically, one can achieve exact (quality q=1𝑞1q=1italic_q = 1) cut sparsifier of size 22ksuperscript2superscript2𝑘2^{2^{k}}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [HKNR98, KRTV12], however, the size must still be at least 2Ω⁢(k)superscript2Ω𝑘2^{\Omega(k)}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Ω ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [KRTV12, KR13] (for both cut and flow sparsifiers).

Taking cue from edge-sparsification results, and the above lower bounds, it is natural to focus on small sparsifiers that achieve quality 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε, for small ε≥0𝜀0\varepsilon\geq 0italic_ε ≥ 0. Note that for flow sparsifiers, we do not know of any bound on the size of the sparsifier that would depend only on k𝑘kitalic_k (and 1/ε1𝜀1/\varepsilon1 / italic_ε), but not on n𝑛nitalic_n or edge capacities. In fact, we do not even know whether it is possible to represent the sparsifier information theoretically (i.e., by a small-size sketch), let alone by a graph.

1.1 Results

Making a first step towards constructing high-quality sparsifiers of small size, we present constructions for several scenarios:

  • •

    Our main result is for quasi-bipartite graphs, i.e., graphs where the non-terminals form an independent set (see [RV99]), and we construct for such networks a (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_ε )-flow-sparsifier of size poly⁡(k/ε)poly𝑘𝜀\operatorname{poly}(k/\varepsilon)roman_poly ( italic_k / italic_ε ). In contrast, exact (q=1𝑞1q=1italic_q = 1) sparsifiers for this family of networks are known to require size 2Ω⁢(k)superscript2Ω𝑘2^{\Omega(k)}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Ω ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT [KRTV12, KR13]. (See Theorem 6.2.)

  • •

    For general networks G𝐺Gitalic_G, we construct a sketch s⁢k⁢(G)𝑠𝑘𝐺sk(G)italic_s italic_k ( italic_G ), that stores all the feasible multicommodity flows up to factor q=1+ε𝑞1𝜀q=1+\varepsilonitalic_q = 1 + italic_ε, and has size (storage requirement) of f⁢(k,ε)𝑓𝑘𝜀f(k,\varepsilon)italic_f ( italic_k , italic_ε ) words. This implies an affirmative answer to the above information-theoretic question on existence of flow sparsifiers, and raises the hope for a (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_ε )-flow-sparsifier of size f⁢(k,ε)𝑓𝑘𝜀f(k,\varepsilon)italic_f ( italic_k , italic_ε ). (See Theorem 3.2.)

  • •

    For networks G𝐺Gitalic_G of bounded treewidth w𝑤witalic_w, we construct a flow-sparsifier with quality q=O⁢(log⁡wlog⁡log⁡w)𝑞𝑂𝑤𝑤q=O(\frac{\log w}{\log\log w})italic_q = italic_O ( divide start_ARG roman_log italic_w end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_w end_ARG ) and size O⁢(w⋅poly⁡(k))𝑂⋅𝑤poly𝑘O(w\cdot\operatorname{poly}(k))italic_O ( italic_w ⋅ roman_poly ( italic_k ) ). (See Theorem 7.7.)

  • •

    Series-parallel networks admit an exact (quality 1111) flow sparsifier with O⁢(k)𝑂𝑘O(k)italic_O ( italic_k ) vertices. (See Theorem 7.5.)

1.2 Techniques

Perhaps our most important contribution is the introduction of the three techniques listed below, and indeed, one can view our results from the prism of these three rather different approaches. In particular, applying these three techniques to quasi-bipartite graphs yields (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_ε )-quality sparsifiers whose sizes are (respectively) doubly-exponential, exponential, and polynomial in k/ε𝑘𝜀k/\varepsilonitalic_k / italic_ε.

  1. 1.

    Clumping: We first “discretize” the set of (almost) all possible multi-commodity demands into a finite set, whose size depends only on k/ε𝑘𝜀k/\varepsilonitalic_k / italic_ε, and then partition the graph vertices into a small number of “clusters”, so that clumping each cluster into a single vertex still preserves one (and eventually all) of the discretized demands. The idea of clumping vertices was used in the past to obtain exact (quality 1111) cut sparsifiers [HKNR98]. Flow-sparsifiers require, in effect, to preserve all metrics between the terminals rather than merely all inter-terminal cut metrics, and requires new ideas.

  2. 2.

    Splicing/Composition: Our Splicing Lemma shows that it is enough for the sparsifier to maintain flows routed using paths that do not contain internally any terminals. Our Composition Lemma shows that for a network obtained by gluing two networks along some subset of their terminals, gluing the respective sparsifiers (in the same manner) gives us a sparsifier for the glued network. These lemmas enable us to do “surgery” on networks, to decompose and recompose them, so that we find good sparsifiers on smaller networks and then combine them together without loss of quality.

  3. 3.

    Sampling: This technique samples parts of the graph, while preserving the flows approximately. The main difficulty is to determine correct sampling probabilities (and correlations). This is the technical heart of the paper, and we outline its main ideas in Section 1.3.

We hope they will inspire ulterior constructions of high-quality flow sparsifiers for general graphs. The clumping techniques give information-theoretic bounds on flow-sparsification, and the splicing/composition approach proves useful for sparsification of bounded treewidth and series-parallel graphs (beyond what can be derived using their flow/cut gaps from known cut sparsifiers).

1.3 Outline of Our Sampling Approach

A classic approach to obtain an edge-sparsifier [Kar94, BK96, SS11] is to sample the edges of the graph and rescale appropriately. Here, we outline instead how to sample the vertices of the graph to obtain a small flow-sparsifier. We outline our main idea on quasi-bipartite graphs (where the non-terminals form an independent set), considering for simplicity the (simpler) question of cut sparsifiers, where we want to construct a smaller graph G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that preserves the minimum cut between every bipartition of terminals T=S∪(T∖S)𝑇𝑆𝑇𝑆T=S\cup(T\setminus S)italic_T = italic_S ∪ ( italic_T ∖ italic_S ). The main idea is to sample a small number of non-terminals v𝑣vitalic_v, keeping only their incident edges, and rescaling the corresponding capacities. For a fixed bipartition T=S∪S¯𝑇𝑆¯𝑆T=S\cup\bar{S}italic_T = italic_S ∪ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG, we can write the value of the min-cut as

αS,S¯=∑v∉Tmin⁡{∑s∈Scs⁢v,∑t∈S¯cv⁢t}.subscript𝛼𝑆¯𝑆subscript𝑣𝑇subscript𝑠𝑆subscript𝑐𝑠𝑣subscript𝑡¯𝑆subscript𝑐𝑣𝑡\alpha_{S,\bar{S}}=\sum_{v\notin T}\min\Big{\{}\sum_{s\in S}c_{sv},\sum_{t\in\bar{S}}c_{vt}\Big{\}}.italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S , over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∉ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min { ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } . (1.1)

(Here cx⁢ysubscript𝑐𝑥𝑦c_{xy}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the capacity of the edge x⁢y𝑥𝑦xyitalic_x italic_y.) Suppose we assign each non-terminal v𝑣vitalic_v with some sampling probability pvsubscript𝑝𝑣p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then sample the non-terminals using these probabilities, letting Ivsubscript𝐼𝑣I_{v}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be an indicator variable for whether v𝑣vitalic_v was sampled. Then, for sampled v𝑣vitalic_v’s we re-normalize the capacities on incident edges by 1/pv1subscript𝑝𝑣1/p_{v}1 / italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., the new capacities are cv,t′=cv,t/pvsubscriptsuperscript𝑐′𝑣𝑡subscript𝑐𝑣𝑡subscript𝑝𝑣c^{\prime}_{v,t}=c_{v,t}/p_{v}italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all t∈T𝑡𝑇t\in Titalic_t ∈ italic_T (non-sampled v𝑣vitalic_v’s are dropped). The new value of the min-cut in the sparsifier G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is

αS,S¯′=∑v∉TIv/pv⋅min⁡{∑s∈Scs⁢v,∑t∈S¯cv⁢t}.subscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑆¯𝑆subscript𝑣𝑇⋅subscript𝐼𝑣subscript𝑝𝑣subscript𝑠𝑆subscript𝑐𝑠𝑣subscript𝑡¯𝑆subscript𝑐𝑣𝑡\alpha^{\prime}_{S,\bar{S}}=\sum_{v\notin T}I_{v}/p_{v}\cdot\min\Big{\{}\sum_{s\in S}c_{sv},\sum_{t\in\bar{S}}c_{vt}\Big{\}}.italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S , over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∉ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ roman_min { ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } . (1.2)

This classical estimator is unbiased, and hence each min-cut αS,S¯subscript𝛼𝑆¯𝑆\alpha_{S,\bar{S}}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S , over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is preserved in expectation.

The main challenge now is to prove that the above random sum concentrates around its expectation for “small” values of pvsubscript𝑝𝑣p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For example, consider setting all pvsubscript𝑝𝑣p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT equal, say to poly⁡(k)/|V|poly𝑘𝑉\operatorname{poly}(k)/|V|roman_poly ( italic_k ) / | italic_V |. Even if all cs,v∈{0,1}subscript𝑐𝑠𝑣01c_{s,v}\in\{0,1\}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ { 0 , 1 } (i.e., all edges in E𝐸Eitalic_E have unit capacity), due to the min operation, it is possible that only very few terms in the summation in Eqn. (1.1) have nonzero contribution to αS,S¯subscript𝛼𝑆¯𝑆\alpha_{S,\bar{S}}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S , over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and are extremely unlikely to be sampled.

Our general approach is to employ importance sampling, where each pvsubscript𝑝𝑣p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is related to v𝑣vitalic_v’s contribution to the sum, namely min⁡{∑s∈Scs⁢v,∑t∈S¯cv⁢t}subscript𝑠𝑆subscript𝑐𝑠𝑣subscript𝑡¯𝑆subscript𝑐𝑣𝑡\min\left\{\sum_{s\in S}c_{sv},\sum_{t\in\bar{S}}c_{vt}\right\}roman_min { ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. Applying this directly is hard — since that minimum depends on the bipartition S∪S¯𝑆¯𝑆S\cup\bar{S}italic_S ∪ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG, whereas pvsubscript𝑝𝑣p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot. Instead, we exploit the fact that for any bipartition, we can estimate

αS,S¯′≥maxs∈S,t∈S¯⁢∑vIv/pv⋅min⁡{cs⁢v,cv⁢t}≥1k2⁢αS,S¯′,subscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑆¯𝑆subscriptformulae-sequence𝑠𝑆𝑡¯𝑆subscript𝑣⋅subscript𝐼𝑣subscript𝑝𝑣subscript𝑐𝑠𝑣subscript𝑐𝑣𝑡1superscript𝑘2subscriptsuperscript𝛼′𝑆¯𝑆\alpha^{\prime}_{S,\bar{S}}\geq\max_{s\in S,t\in\bar{S}}\ \sum_{v}I_{v}/p_{v}\cdot\min\{c_{sv},c_{vt}\}\geq\tfrac{1}{k^{2}}\alpha^{\prime}_{S,\bar{S}},italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S , over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ italic_S , italic_t ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ roman_min { italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } ≥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S , over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (1.3)

and hence arguing about the sum in Eqn. (1.3) should be enough for bounding the variance. Following this reasoning through, it turns out that a good choice is

pv=M⋅maxs≠t⁡min⁡{cs⁢v,cv⁢t}∑v′min⁡{cs⁢v′,cv′⁢t},subscript𝑝𝑣⋅𝑀subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝑐𝑠𝑣subscript𝑐𝑣𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑣′subscript𝑐𝑠superscript𝑣′subscript𝑐superscript𝑣′𝑡p_{v}=M\cdot\max_{s\neq t}\frac{\min\{c_{sv},c_{vt}\}}{\sum_{v^{\prime}}\min\{c_{sv^{\prime}},c_{v^{\prime}t}\}},italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_M ⋅ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ≠ italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG roman_min { italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min { italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_ARG , (1.4)

where M=poly⁡(k/ε)𝑀poly𝑘𝜀M=\operatorname{poly}(k/\varepsilon)italic_M = roman_poly ( italic_k / italic_ε ) is an over-sampling factor. The underlying intuition of Eqn. (1.4) is that, replacing the max with a “correct” choice of s∈S,t∈S¯formulae-sequence𝑠𝑆𝑡¯𝑆s\in S,t\in\bar{S}italic_s ∈ italic_S , italic_t ∈ over¯ start_ARG italic_S end_ARG, the denominator is just the entire potential contribution to the sum in Eqn. (1.3), and hence these pvsubscript𝑝𝑣p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT values can be used as importance sampling probabilities for the sum in Eqn. (1.2). Moreover, we prove that this setting of pvsubscript𝑝𝑣p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT allows for a high-probability concentration bound in the sum from Eqn. (1.2), and thus sampling poly⁡(k/ε)poly𝑘𝜀\operatorname{poly}(k/\varepsilon)roman_poly ( italic_k / italic_ε ) vertices suffices for the purpose of taking a union bound over all 2ksuperscript2𝑘2^{k}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bipartitions.

So far we have described the approach for obtaining cut sparsifiers, but in fact we prove that the exact same approach works for obtaining flow sparsifiers as well. There are more issues that we need to take care in this generalized setting. First, we need to bound the “effective” number of demand vectors. Second, the flow does not have a simple closed-form formula like (1.1), so upper and lower bounds need to be proved by analyzing separately (the concentration of) the optimal value of the flow LP and of its dual.

2 Preliminaries

A k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal network is an edge-capacitated graph G=(V,E,c)𝐺𝑉𝐸𝑐G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) with a subset T⊆V𝑇𝑉T\subseteq Vitalic_T ⊆ italic_V of k𝑘kitalic_k terminals. We will be interested only in terminal flows, i.e., flows that start and end only at the terminal vertices of G𝐺Gitalic_G. Define 𝒟⁢(G)𝒟𝐺{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ), the demand polytope of G𝐺Gitalic_G as the set of all demand vectors 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d that are supported only on terminal-pairs, and admit a feasible multicommodity-flow in G𝐺Gitalic_G, formally,

𝒟⁢(G):={𝐝∈ℝ+(T2):demand 𝐝 can be routed in G},assign𝒟𝐺conditional-set𝐝superscriptsubscriptℝbinomial𝑇2demand 𝐝 can be routed in G\displaystyle{\mathcal{D}}(G):=\{\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}:\ \text{demand $\mathbf{d}$ can be routed in $G$}\},caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) := { bold_d ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : demand bold_d can be routed in italic_G } , (2.5)

where we denote ℝ+:={x∈R:x≥0}assignsubscriptℝconditional-set𝑥𝑅𝑥0{\mathbb{R}}_{+}:=\{x\in R:x\geq 0\}blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := { italic_x ∈ italic_R : italic_x ≥ 0 } and (T2):={S⊆T:|S|=2}assignbinomial𝑇2conditional-set𝑆𝑇𝑆2\tbinom{T}{2}:=\{S\subseteq T:\ \lvert S\rvert=2\}( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) := { italic_S ⊆ italic_T : | italic_S | = 2 }. Throughout, we assume G𝐺Gitalic_G is connected.

Lemma 2.1.

𝒟⁢(G)𝒟𝐺{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) is a polytope, and is down-monotone.

Proof.

Let 𝒫i⁢jsubscript𝒫𝑖𝑗\mathcal{P}_{ij}caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the set of paths between terminals i𝑖iitalic_i and j𝑗jitalic_j. Consider the extended demand polytope 𝒟e⁢x⁢t⁢(G)subscript𝒟𝑒𝑥𝑡𝐺{\mathcal{D}}_{ext}(G)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_x italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) with variables di⁢jsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑗d_{ij}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all {i,j}∈(T2)𝑖𝑗binomial𝑇2\{i,j\}\in\binom{T}{2}{ italic_i , italic_j } ∈ ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ), and fPsubscript𝑓𝑃f_{P}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for each P∈∪i,j𝒫i⁢j𝑃subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝒫𝑖𝑗P\in\cup_{i,j}\mathcal{P}_{ij}italic_P ∈ ∪ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

∑P∈𝒫i⁢jfPsubscript𝑃subscript𝒫𝑖𝑗subscript𝑓𝑃\displaystyle\textstyle\sum_{P\in\mathcal{P}_{ij}}f_{P}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =di⁢jabsentsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑗\displaystyle=d_{ij}= italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
∑i,j∑P∈𝒫i⁢j:e∈PfPsubscript𝑖𝑗subscript:𝑃subscript𝒫𝑖𝑗𝑒𝑃subscript𝑓𝑃\displaystyle\textstyle\sum_{i,j}\sum_{P\in\mathcal{P}_{ij}:e\in P}f_{P}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P ∈ caligraphic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_e ∈ italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ceabsentsubscript𝑐𝑒\displaystyle\leq c_{e}≤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
fP,di⁢jsubscript𝑓𝑃subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗\displaystyle f_{P},d_{ij}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥0.absent0\displaystyle\geq 0.≥ 0 .

This polytope captures all the feasible terminal flows, and hence all the routable demands between the terminals of G𝐺Gitalic_G. The projection of this polytope 𝒟e⁢x⁢t⁢(G)subscript𝒟𝑒𝑥𝑡𝐺{\mathcal{D}}_{ext}(G)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_x italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) onto the variables d𝑑ditalic_d is exactly 𝒟⁢(G)𝒟𝐺{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ); hence the latter is also a polytope.111As a aside, we can write 𝒟e⁢x⁢t⁢(G)subscript𝒟𝑒𝑥𝑡𝐺{\mathcal{D}}_{ext}(G)caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e italic_x italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_G ) more compactly using edge-flow variables fi⁢j⁢(e)superscript𝑓𝑖𝑗𝑒f^{ij}(e)italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_e ) instead of path variables fPsubscript𝑓𝑃f_{P}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_P end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; we omit such standard optimizations here. Finally, the down-monotonicity of the polytope follows from the downward-feasibility of flows, in turn due to the lack of lower-bounds on the flows on edges. ∎

Dual linear program for concurrent flow.

For a demand vector 𝐝∈ℝ+(T2)∖{0}𝐝superscriptsubscriptℝbinomial𝑇20\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}\setminus\{0\}bold_d ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ { 0 }, we denote the concurrent flow problem (inverse of the congestion) by

λG⁢(𝐝):=sup{λ≥0:λ⁢𝐝∈𝒟⁢(G)}.assignsubscript𝜆𝐺𝐝supremumconditional-set𝜆0𝜆𝐝𝒟𝐺\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d}):=\sup\{\lambda\geq 0:\ \lambda\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G)\}.italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) := roman_sup { italic_λ ≥ 0 : italic_λ bold_d ∈ caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) } .

This is well-defined because 0→∈𝒟⁢(G)→0𝒟𝐺\vec{0}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G)over→ start_ARG 0 end_ARG ∈ caligraphic_D ( italic_G ). The following well-known lemma writes λG⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) by applying linear programming (LP) duality to multicommodity flow, see e.g. [LR99, Shm97, Moi09].

Lemma 2.2.

λG⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) can be computed via the linear program (LP1) which has “edge-length” variables ℓesubscriptnormal-ℓ𝑒\ell_{e}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for edges e∈E𝑒𝐸e\in Eitalic_e ∈ italic_E and “distance” variable δu⁢v=δv⁢usubscript𝛿𝑢𝑣subscript𝛿𝑣𝑢\delta_{uv}=\delta_{vu}italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for terminal pairs {s,t}∈(T2)𝑠𝑡binomial𝑇2\{s,t\}\in\binom{T}{2}{ italic_s , italic_t } ∈ ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ).

Flow-sparsifier definition.

A network G′=(V′,E′,c′)superscript𝐺′superscript𝑉′superscript𝐸′superscript𝑐′G^{\prime}=(V^{\prime},E^{\prime},c^{\prime})italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with T⊆V′𝑇superscript𝑉′T\subseteq V^{\prime}italic_T ⊆ italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is called a flow sparsifier of G𝐺Gitalic_G with quality q≥1𝑞1q\geq 1italic_q ≥ 1 if

∀d∈ℝ+(T2),λG⁢(𝐝)≤λG′⁢(𝐝)≤q⋅λG⁢(𝐝).formulae-sequencefor-all𝑑superscriptsubscriptℝbinomial𝑇2subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝subscript𝜆superscript𝐺′𝐝⋅𝑞subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\forall d\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}},\qquad\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\leq\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})\leq q\cdot\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d}).∀ italic_d ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≤ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≤ italic_q ⋅ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) .

This condition is equivalent to writing 𝒟⁢(G)⊆𝒟⁢(G′)⊆q⋅𝒟⁢(G)𝒟𝐺𝒟superscript𝐺′⋅𝑞𝒟𝐺{\mathcal{D}}(G)\subseteq{\mathcal{D}}(G^{\prime})\subseteq q\cdot{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) ⊆ caligraphic_D ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ⊆ italic_q ⋅ caligraphic_D ( italic_G ).

3 A Data Structure for Multicommodity Flows

We present a data structure that “maintains” 𝒟⁢(G)𝒟𝐺{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) within approximation factor 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε. More precisely, we preprocess the terminal network G𝐺Gitalic_G into a data structure whose storage requirement depends only on k𝑘kitalic_k and ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε (but not on n=|V⁢(G)|𝑛𝑉𝐺n=|V(G)|italic_n = | italic_V ( italic_G ) |). Given a query 𝐝∈ℝ+(T2)𝐝superscriptsubscriptℝbinomial𝑇2\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}bold_d ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, this data structure returns an approximation to λG⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) within factor 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε (without further access to G𝐺Gitalic_G). The formal statement appears in Theorem 3.2. We assume henceforth that 0<ε<180𝜀180<\varepsilon<{\tfrac{1}{8}}0 < italic_ε < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG.

An approximate polytope.

Let G=(V,E,c)𝐺𝑉𝐸𝑐G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) be a terminal network with k terminals T⊂V𝑇𝑉T\subset Vitalic_T ⊂ italic_V. For each commodity {i,j}∈(T2)𝑖𝑗binomial𝑇2\{i,j\}\in\binom{T}{2}{ italic_i , italic_j } ∈ ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ), let Li⁢jsubscript𝐿𝑖𝑗L_{ij}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the maximum flow of commodity i⁢j𝑖𝑗ijitalic_i italic_j alone (i.e., as a single-commodity flow) in G𝐺Gitalic_G. Discretize the set 𝒟⁢(G)𝒟𝐺{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) defined in (2.5) by defining the subset

𝒟εdiscrete:={𝐝∈𝒟⁢(G):every nonzero di⁢j is a power of 1+ε in the range [ε/k2⋅Li⁢j,Li⁢j] }.assignsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discreteconditional-set𝐝𝒟𝐺every nonzero di⁢j is a power of 1+ε in the range [ε/k2⋅Li⁢j,Li⁢j] {\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}:=\{\,\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G):\ \text{every nonzero $d_{ij}$ is a power of $1+\varepsilon$ in the range $[\varepsilon/k^{2}\cdot L_{ij},L_{ij}]$\, }\}.caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := { bold_d ∈ caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) : every nonzero italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a power of 1 + italic_ε in the range [ italic_ε / italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] } .

The range upper bound Li⁢jsubscript𝐿𝑖𝑗L_{ij}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (which is not really necessary, as it follows from 𝐝∈𝒟⁢(G)𝐝𝒟𝐺\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G)bold_d ∈ caligraphic_D ( italic_G )), immediately implies that

|𝒟εdiscrete|≤(1+1ε⁢log1+ε⁡k)(k2)≤(O⁢(1)ε⁢log⁡k)k2.superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discretesuperscript11𝜀subscript1𝜀𝑘binomial𝑘2superscript𝑂1𝜀𝑘superscript𝑘2\lvert{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}\rvert\leq\Big{(}1+\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\log_{1+\varepsilon}k\Big{)}^{\binom{k}{2}}\leq\Big{(}\tfrac{O(1)}{\varepsilon}\log k\Big{)}^{k^{2}}.| caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ≤ ( 1 + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 + italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ ( divide start_ARG italic_O ( 1 ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG roman_log italic_k ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (3.6)
Lemma 3.1.

The convex hull conv⁡(𝒟ε𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑐𝑟𝑒𝑡𝑒)normal-convsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑐𝑟𝑒𝑡𝑒\operatorname{conv}({\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}})roman_conv ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is down-monotone, namely, if 𝐝∈conv⁡(𝒟ε𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑐𝑟𝑒𝑡𝑒)𝐝normal-convsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑐𝑟𝑒𝑡𝑒\mathbf{d}\in\operatorname{conv}({\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}})bold_d ∈ roman_conv ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and 0≤𝐝^≤𝐝0normal-^𝐝𝐝0\leq\widehat{\mathbf{d}}\leq\mathbf{d}0 ≤ over^ start_ARG bold_d end_ARG ≤ bold_d, then also 𝐝^∈conv⁡(𝒟ε𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑐𝑟𝑒𝑡𝑒)normal-^𝐝normal-convsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑐𝑟𝑒𝑡𝑒\widehat{\mathbf{d}}\in\operatorname{conv}({\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}})over^ start_ARG bold_d end_ARG ∈ roman_conv ( caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

Proof.

Consider first the special case where 𝐝^^𝐝\widehat{\mathbf{d}}over^ start_ARG bold_d end_ARG is obtained from 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d by scaling the coordinates in some subset S⊆(T2)𝑆binomial𝑇2S\subseteq\binom{T}{2}italic_S ⊆ ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) by a scalar 0≤β<10𝛽10\leq\beta<10 ≤ italic_β < 1. Write 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d as a convex combination of some vectors 𝐝j∈𝒟εdiscretesubscript𝐝𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discrete\mathbf{d}_{j}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, say ∑jαj⁢𝐝jsubscript𝑗subscript𝛼𝑗subscript𝐝𝑗\sum_{j}\alpha_{j}\mathbf{d}_{j}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where αj>0subscript𝛼𝑗0\alpha_{j}>0italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 and ∑jαj=1subscript𝑗subscript𝛼𝑗1\sum_{j}\alpha_{j}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. Let 𝐝^jsubscript^𝐝𝑗\widehat{\mathbf{d}}_{j}over^ start_ARG bold_d end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the vector obtained from 𝐝jsubscript𝐝𝑗\mathbf{d}_{j}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by zeroing all the coordinates in S𝑆Sitalic_S, and observe it is also in 𝒟εdiscretesuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discrete{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Now write

𝐝^=∑jαj⁢[β⁢𝐝j+(1−β)⁢𝐝^j]=∑jαj⁢β⁢𝐝j+∑jαj⁢(1−β)⁢𝐝^j,^𝐝subscript𝑗subscript𝛼𝑗delimited-[]𝛽subscript𝐝𝑗1𝛽subscript^𝐝𝑗subscript𝑗subscript𝛼𝑗𝛽subscript𝐝𝑗subscript𝑗subscript𝛼𝑗1𝛽subscript^𝐝𝑗\widehat{\mathbf{d}}=\sum_{j}\alpha_{j}[\beta\mathbf{d}_{j}+(1-\beta)\widehat{\mathbf{d}}_{j}]=\sum_{j}\alpha_{j}\beta\mathbf{d}_{j}+\sum_{j}\alpha_{j}(1-\beta)\widehat{\mathbf{d}}_{j},over^ start_ARG bold_d end_ARG = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_β bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( 1 - italic_β ) over^ start_ARG bold_d end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_β ) over^ start_ARG bold_d end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

and observe the right-hand side is a convex combination of vectors in 𝒟εdiscretesuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discrete{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which proves the aforementioned special case. The general case follows by iterating this special-case argument several times. ∎

The data structure.

The next theorem expresses the space requirement of an algorithm in machine words, assuming every machine word can store log⁡k𝑘\log kroman_log italic_k bits and any single value Li⁢jsubscript𝐿𝑖𝑗L_{ij}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (either exactly or within accuracy factor 1+ε/21𝜀21+\varepsilon/21 + italic_ε / 2). This holds, in particular, when edge capacities in the graph G𝐺Gitalic_G are integers bounded by n=|V⁢(G)|𝑛𝑉𝐺n=\lvert V(G)\rvertitalic_n = | italic_V ( italic_G ) |, and a word has 2⁢log⁡n2𝑛2\log n2 roman_log italic_n bits.

Theorem 3.2.

For every 0<ε<180𝜀180<\varepsilon<{\tfrac{1}{8}}0 < italic_ε < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG there is a data structure that provides a (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_ε )-approximation for multicommodity flows in a k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal network, using space (O⁢(1)ε⁢log⁡k)k2superscript𝑂1𝜀𝑘superscript𝑘2\Big{(}\tfrac{O(1)}{\varepsilon}\log k\Big{)}^{k^{2}}( divide start_ARG italic_O ( 1 ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG roman_log italic_k ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and query time O⁢(1ε⁢k2⁢log⁡k)𝑂1𝜀superscript𝑘2𝑘O(\frac{1}{\varepsilon}k^{2}\log k)italic_O ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_k ).

Proof.

We present a data structure achieving approximation 1+O⁢(ε)1𝑂𝜀1+O(\varepsilon)1 + italic_O ( italic_ε ); the theorem would then follow by scaling ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0italic_ε > 0 appropriately. The data structure stores the set 𝒟εdiscretesuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discrete{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, using a dictionary (such as a hash table) to answer membership queries in time O⁢(k2)𝑂superscript𝑘2O(k^{2})italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), the time required to read a single vector. It additionally stores all the values Li⁢jsubscript𝐿𝑖𝑗L_{ij}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. (We assume these values can be stored exactly; the case of 1+ε/21𝜀21+\varepsilon/21 + italic_ε / 2 approximation follows by straightforward modifications.)

Given a query 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d, the algorithm first computes β=mini,j∈T⁡{Li⁢j/di⁢j}𝛽subscript𝑖𝑗𝑇subscript𝐿𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗\beta=\min_{i,j\in T}\{L_{ij}/d_{ij}\}italic_β = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j ∈ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. We thus have that β⁢k−2≤λG⁢(𝐝)≤β𝛽superscript𝑘2subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝𝛽\beta k^{-2}\leq\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\leq\betaitalic_β italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≤ italic_β, because the commodity i,j∈T𝑖𝑗𝑇i,j\in Titalic_i , italic_j ∈ italic_T attaining β⁢di⁢j=Li⁢j𝛽subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗subscript𝐿𝑖𝑗\beta d_{ij}=L_{ij}italic_β italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT limits λG⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) to not exceed β𝛽\betaitalic_β, and because we can ship β⁢di⁢j≤Li⁢j𝛽subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗subscript𝐿𝑖𝑗\beta d_{ij}\leq L_{ij}italic_β italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT units separately for every commodity i,j∈T𝑖𝑗𝑇i,j\in Titalic_i , italic_j ∈ italic_T, hence also their convex combination (k2)−1⁢β⁢𝐝superscriptbinomial𝑘21𝛽𝐝\binom{k}{2}^{-1}\beta\mathbf{d}( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_β bold_d.

The query algorithm then computes an estimate for λG⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) by performing a binary search over all powers of (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_ε ) in the range [β⁢k−2,β]𝛽superscript𝑘2𝛽[\beta k^{-2},\beta][ italic_β italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_β ], where each iteration decides, up to 1+2⁢ε12𝜀1+2\varepsilon1 + 2 italic_ε multiplicative approximation, whether a given λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ in that range is at most λG⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). The number of iterations is clearly O⁢(log1+ε⁡k2)≤O⁢(1ε⁢log⁡k)𝑂subscript1𝜀superscript𝑘2𝑂1𝜀𝑘O(\log_{1+\varepsilon}k^{2})\leq O(\frac{1}{\varepsilon}\log k)italic_O ( roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 + italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≤ italic_O ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG roman_log italic_k ).

The approximate decision procedure is performed in two steps. In the first step, we let 𝐝−superscript𝐝\mathbf{d}^{-}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the vector obtained from λ⁢𝐝𝜆𝐝\lambda\mathbf{d}italic_λ bold_d by zeroing all coordinates that are at most 2⁢ε/k2⋅Li⁢j⋅2𝜀superscript𝑘2subscript𝐿𝑖𝑗2\varepsilon/k^{2}\cdot L_{ij}2 italic_ε / italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This vector can be written as

𝐝−=λ⁢𝐝−∑i,j∈Tαi⁢j⁢Li⁢j⁢𝐞i⁢j,superscript𝐝𝜆𝐝subscript𝑖𝑗𝑇subscript𝛼𝑖𝑗subscript𝐿𝑖𝑗subscript𝐞𝑖𝑗\mathbf{d}^{-}=\lambda\mathbf{d}-\sum_{i,j\in T}\alpha_{ij}L_{ij}\mathbf{e}_{ij},bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_λ bold_d - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j ∈ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

where 𝐞i⁢j∈ℝ+(T2)subscript𝐞𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptℝbinomial𝑇2\mathbf{e}_{ij}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the standard basis vector corresponding to {i,j}𝑖𝑗\{i,j\}{ italic_i , italic_j }, and for every i,j∈T𝑖𝑗𝑇i,j\in Titalic_i , italic_j ∈ italic_T we define αi⁢j:=di⁢j/Li⁢jassignsubscript𝛼𝑖𝑗subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗subscript𝐿𝑖𝑗\alpha_{ij}:=d_{ij}/L_{ij}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if di⁢j≤2⁢ε/k2⋅Li⁢jsubscript𝑑𝑖𝑗⋅2𝜀superscript𝑘2subscript𝐿𝑖𝑗d_{ij}\leq 2\varepsilon/k^{2}\cdot L_{ij}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 2 italic_ε / italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and αi⁢j:=0assignsubscript𝛼𝑖𝑗0\alpha_{ij}:=0italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := 0 otherwise. By definition, ∑i,jαi,j≤εsubscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝛼𝑖𝑗𝜀\sum_{i,j}\alpha_{i,j}\leq\varepsilon∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_ε. The second step lets 𝐝′superscript𝐝′\mathbf{d}^{\prime}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the vector obtained from 𝐝−superscript𝐝\mathbf{d}^{-}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by rounding down each coordinate to the nearest power of 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε. Finally, decide whether λ≤λG⁢(𝐝)𝜆subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda\leq\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ ≤ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) by checking whether 𝐝′∈𝒟εdiscretesuperscript𝐝′superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discrete\mathbf{d}^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which is implemented using the dictionary in O⁢(k2)𝑂superscript𝑘2O(k^{2})italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) time.

It remains to prove the correctness of the approximate decision procedure. For one direction, assume that λ≤λG⁢(𝐝)𝜆subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda\leq\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ ≤ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). It follows that the demands λ⁢𝐝≥𝐝−≥𝐝′𝜆𝐝superscript𝐝superscript𝐝′\lambda\mathbf{d}\geq\mathbf{d}^{-}\geq\mathbf{d}^{\prime}italic_λ bold_d ≥ bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can all be routed in G𝐺Gitalic_G, and furthermore 𝐝′∈𝒟εdiscretesuperscript𝐝′superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discrete\mathbf{d}^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, implying that our procedure reports a correct decision. For the other direction, suppose our procedure reports that λ≤λG⁢(𝐝)𝜆subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda\leq\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ ≤ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ), which means that its corresponding 𝐝′∈𝒟εdiscrete⊂𝒟⁢(G)superscript𝐝′superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discrete𝒟𝐺\mathbf{d}^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}\subset{\mathcal{D}}(G)bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊂ caligraphic_D ( italic_G ). We can thus write

λ⁢𝐝=𝐝−+∑i⁢jαi⁢j⁢Li⁢j⁢𝐞i⁢j≤(1+ε)⁢𝐝′+∑i⁢jαi⁢j⁢Li⁢j⁢𝐞i⁢j.𝜆𝐝superscript𝐝subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝛼𝑖𝑗subscript𝐿𝑖𝑗subscript𝐞𝑖𝑗1𝜀superscript𝐝′subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝛼𝑖𝑗subscript𝐿𝑖𝑗subscript𝐞𝑖𝑗\lambda\mathbf{d}=\mathbf{d}^{-}+\sum_{ij}\alpha_{ij}L_{ij}\mathbf{e}_{ij}\leq(1+\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}^{\prime}+\sum_{ij}\alpha_{ij}L_{ij}\mathbf{e}_{ij}.italic_λ bold_d = bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ ( 1 + italic_ε ) bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

The right-hand side can be described as a positive combination of vectors in 𝒟⁢(G)𝒟𝐺{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ), whose sum of coefficients is (1+ε)+∑i⁢jαi⁢j≤1+2⁢ε1𝜀subscript𝑖𝑗subscript𝛼𝑖𝑗12𝜀(1+\varepsilon)+\sum_{ij}\alpha_{ij}\leq 1+2\varepsilon( 1 + italic_ε ) + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 1 + 2 italic_ε. Since 𝒟⁢(G)𝒟𝐺{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) is convex and contains 0¯¯0\underline{0}under¯ start_ARG 0 end_ARG, we have that also (1+2⁢ε)−1⁢λ⁢𝐝∈𝒟⁢(G)superscript12𝜀1𝜆𝐝𝒟𝐺(1+2\varepsilon)^{-1}\lambda\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G)( 1 + 2 italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ bold_d ∈ caligraphic_D ( italic_G ), i.e., that (1+2⁢ε)−1⁢λ≤λG⁢(𝐝)superscript12𝜀1𝜆subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝(1+2\varepsilon)^{-1}\lambda\leq\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})( 1 + 2 italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ ≤ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ), which proves the correctness of the decision procedure up to 1+2⁢ε12𝜀1+2\varepsilon1 + 2 italic_ε multiplicative approximation. Overall, we have indeed shown that the binary search algorithm approximates λG⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) within factor (1+ε)⁢(1+2⁢ε)≤1+O⁢(ε)1𝜀12𝜀1𝑂𝜀(1+\varepsilon)(1+2\varepsilon)\leq 1+O(\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_ε ) ( 1 + 2 italic_ε ) ≤ 1 + italic_O ( italic_ε ). ∎

4 The Clumping Method for Flow Sparsifiers

In this section we develop a method based on clumping (merging) vertices, and exemplify its use on quasi-bipartite graphs. Let G=(V,E,c)𝐺𝑉𝐸𝑐G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) be a terminal network with terminal set T𝑇Titalic_T. For a subset S⊆V𝑆𝑉S\subseteq Vitalic_S ⊆ italic_V, denote the edges in the induced subgraph G⁢[S]𝐺delimited-[]𝑆G[S]italic_G [ italic_S ] by E⁢[S]:={(u,v)∈E:u,v∈S}assign𝐸delimited-[]𝑆conditional-set𝑢𝑣𝐸𝑢𝑣𝑆E[S]:=\{(u,v)\in E:\ u,v\in S\}italic_E [ italic_S ] := { ( italic_u , italic_v ) ∈ italic_E : italic_u , italic_v ∈ italic_S }. Given a partition Π={S1,S2,…,Sm}Πsubscript𝑆1subscript𝑆2…subscript𝑆𝑚\Pi=\{S_{1},S_{2},\ldots,S_{m}\}roman_Π = { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } of the vertex set (i.e., ∪i=1mSi=Vsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑆𝑖𝑉\cup_{i=1}^{m}S_{i}=V∪ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V), say a distance function δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ on the vertex set V𝑉Vitalic_V is Πnormal-Π\Piroman_Π-respecting if for all l∈[m]𝑙delimited-[]𝑚l\in[m]italic_l ∈ [ italic_m ] and {i,j}∈Sl𝑖𝑗subscript𝑆𝑙\{i,j\}\in S_{l}{ italic_i , italic_j } ∈ italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT it holds that δi⁢j=0subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗0\delta_{ij}=0italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.

Proposition 4.1.

Let G=(V,E,c)𝐺𝑉𝐸𝑐G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) be a k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal network, and fix 0<ε<1/30𝜀130<\varepsilon<1/30 < italic_ε < 1 / 3 and b≥1𝑏1b\geq 1italic_b ≥ 1. Suppose there is an m𝑚mitalic_m-way partition Π={S1,…,Sm}normal-Πsubscript𝑆1normal-…subscript𝑆𝑚\Pi=\{S_{1},\ldots,S_{m}\}roman_Π = { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } such that for every 𝐝′∈𝒟ε𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑐𝑟𝑒𝑡𝑒superscript𝐝normal-′superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑐𝑟𝑒𝑡𝑒\mathbf{d}^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, there exists a Πnormal-Π\Piroman_Π-respecting distance function δ𝛿\deltaitalic_δ that is a feasible solution to (LP1) with objective value at most b⋅λG⁢(𝐝′)normal-⋅𝑏subscript𝜆𝐺superscript𝐝normal-′b\cdot\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d}^{\prime})italic_b ⋅ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Then the graph G′superscript𝐺normal-′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT obtained from G𝐺Gitalic_G by merging each Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into a single vertex (keeping parallel edges222From our perspective of flows, parallel edges can also be merged into one edge with the same total capacity. ) is a flow-sparsifier of G𝐺Gitalic_G with quality (1+3⁢ε)⁢b13𝜀𝑏(1+3\varepsilon)b( 1 + 3 italic_ε ) italic_b.

Proof.

The graph G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can equivalently be defined as taking G𝐺Gitalic_G and adding the edges E0:=∪i=1m(Si2)assignsubscript𝐸0superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚binomialsubscript𝑆𝑖2E_{0}:=\cup_{i=1}^{m}\binom{S_{i}}{2}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := ∪ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ), each with infinite capacity—merging all vertices in each Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the same as adding these infinite capacity edges. Formally, let G′=(V,E∪E0,c′)superscript𝐺′𝑉𝐸subscript𝐸0superscript𝑐′G^{\prime}=(V,E\cup E_{0},c^{\prime})italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_V , italic_E ∪ italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) where c′⁢(e)=c⁢(e)superscript𝑐′𝑒𝑐𝑒c^{\prime}(e)=c(e)italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_e ) = italic_c ( italic_e ) if e∈E𝑒𝐸e\in Eitalic_e ∈ italic_E and c′⁢(e)=∞superscript𝑐′𝑒c^{\prime}(e)=\inftyitalic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_e ) = ∞ if e∈E0𝑒subscript𝐸0e\in E_{0}italic_e ∈ italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then for any 𝐝∈ℝ+(T2)𝐝superscriptsubscriptℝbinomial𝑇2\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}bold_d ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, it is immediate that λG′⁢(𝐝)≥λG⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆superscript𝐺′𝐝subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})\geq\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≥ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d )—every flow that is feasible in G𝐺Gitalic_G is also feasible in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, even without shipping any flow on E0subscript𝐸0E_{0}italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

For the opposite direction, without loss of generality we may assume (by scaling) that λG⁢(𝐝)=1subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝1\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})=1italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) = 1. Let 𝐝′∈𝒟εdiscretesuperscript𝐝′superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discrete\mathbf{d}^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the demand vector obtained from 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d in the construction of 𝒟εdiscretesuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discrete{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (by zeroing small coordinates and rounding downwards to the nearest power of (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_ε )). Clearly, 𝐝′≤𝐝superscript𝐝′𝐝\mathbf{d}^{\prime}\leq\mathbf{d}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ bold_d.

First, we claim that λG⁢(𝐝′)<1+3⁢εsubscript𝜆𝐺superscript𝐝′13𝜀\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d}^{\prime})<1+3\varepsilonitalic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < 1 + 3 italic_ε. Indeed, assume to the contrary that (1+3⁢ε)⁢𝐝′13𝜀superscript𝐝′(1+3\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}^{\prime}( 1 + 3 italic_ε ) bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is feasible in G𝐺Gitalic_G, i.e., (1+3⁢ε)⁢𝐝′∈𝒟⁢(G)13𝜀superscript𝐝′𝒟𝐺(1+3\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G)( 1 + 3 italic_ε ) bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D ( italic_G ). Then the demand

𝐝′′:=(1−ε)⁢(1+3⁢ε)⁢𝐝′+∑i∈(T2)ε/(k2)⋅Li⁢𝐞i,assignsuperscript𝐝′′1𝜀13𝜀superscript𝐝′subscript𝑖binomial𝑇2⋅𝜀binomial𝑘2subscript𝐿𝑖subscript𝐞𝑖\mathbf{d}^{\prime\prime}:=(1-\varepsilon)(1+3\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}^{\prime}+\sum_{i\in\binom{T}{2}}\varepsilon/\tbinom{k}{2}\cdot L_{i}\mathbf{e}_{i},bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := ( 1 - italic_ε ) ( 1 + 3 italic_ε ) bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε / ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) ⋅ italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

is a convex combination of demands in 𝒟⁢(G)𝒟𝐺{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ), and thus also 𝐝′′∈𝒟⁢(G)superscript𝐝′′𝒟𝐺\mathbf{d}^{\prime\prime}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G)bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D ( italic_G ). Observe that 𝐝′′>𝐝superscript𝐝′′𝐝\mathbf{d}^{\prime\prime}>\mathbf{d}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > bold_d (coordinate-wise), because each coordinate of 𝐝′superscript𝐝′\mathbf{d}^{\prime}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT was obtained from 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d by rounding down and possible zeroing (if it is smaller than some threshold), but we more than compensate for this when 𝐝′′superscript𝐝′′\mathbf{d}^{\prime\prime}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is created by multiplying 𝐝′superscript𝐝′\mathbf{d}^{\prime}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by (1−ε)⁢(1+3⁢ε)≥1+ε1𝜀13𝜀1𝜀(1-\varepsilon)(1+3\varepsilon)\geq 1+\varepsilon( 1 - italic_ε ) ( 1 + 3 italic_ε ) ≥ 1 + italic_ε and adding more than the threshold. By down-monotonicity of 𝒟⁢(G)𝒟𝐺{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) we obtain that λG⁢(𝐝)>1subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝1\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})>1italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) > 1 in contradiction to our assumption, and the claim that λG⁢(𝐝′)<1+3⁢εsubscript𝜆𝐺superscript𝐝′13𝜀\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d}^{\prime})<1+3\varepsilonitalic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < 1 + 3 italic_ε follows.

To get a handle on the value λG′⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆superscript𝐺′𝐝\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ), we rewrite (LP1) for G′=G+E0superscript𝐺′𝐺subscript𝐸0G^{\prime}=G+E_{0}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_G + italic_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to obtain LP (LP2).

end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY (LP2)

By our premise, the demand 𝐝′∈𝒟εdiscretesuperscript𝐝′superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discrete\mathbf{d}^{\prime}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has a ΠΠ\Piroman_Π-respecting feasible solution {δs⁢t,ℓe}subscript𝛿𝑠𝑡subscriptℓ𝑒\{\delta_{st},\ell_{e}\}{ italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } with value at most b⋅λG⁢(𝐝′)⋅𝑏subscript𝜆𝐺superscript𝐝′b\cdot\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d}^{\prime})italic_b ⋅ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ); note that such a ΠΠ\Piroman_Π-respecting distance function is also a solution to (LP2). Hence λG′⁢(𝐝′)≤b⋅λG⁢(𝐝′)subscript𝜆superscript𝐺′superscript𝐝′⋅𝑏subscript𝜆𝐺superscript𝐝′\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d}^{\prime})\leq b\cdot\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d}^{\prime})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≤ italic_b ⋅ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). Plugging in λG⁢(𝐝′)≤(1+3⁢ε)subscript𝜆𝐺superscript𝐝′13𝜀\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d}^{\prime})\leq(1+3\varepsilon)italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≤ ( 1 + 3 italic_ε ) and the normalization λG⁢(𝐝)=1subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝1\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})=1italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) = 1, we conclude that λG′⁢(𝐝)≤(1+3⁢ε)⁢b⁢λG⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆superscript𝐺′𝐝13𝜀𝑏subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})\leq(1+3\varepsilon)b\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≤ ( 1 + 3 italic_ε ) italic_b italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ), which completes the proof of Proposition 4.1. ∎

The next proposition is similar in spirit to the previous one, but with the crucial difference that it allows (or assumes) a different partition of V𝑉Vitalic_V for every demand 𝐝∈𝒟εdiscrete𝐝superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discrete\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Its proof is a simple application of the Proposition 4.1.

Proposition 4.2.

Let G=(V,E,c)𝐺𝑉𝐸𝑐G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) be a k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal network, and fix 0<ε<1/30𝜀130<\varepsilon<1/30 < italic_ε < 1 / 3, b≥1𝑏1b\geq 1italic_b ≥ 1, and m≥1𝑚1m\geq 1italic_m ≥ 1. Suppose that for every 𝐝∈𝒟ε𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑐𝑟𝑒𝑡𝑒𝐝superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑐𝑟𝑒𝑡𝑒\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, there is an m𝑚mitalic_m-way partition Π𝐝={S1,…,Sm}subscriptnormal-Π𝐝subscript𝑆1normal-…subscript𝑆𝑚\Pi_{\mathbf{d}}=\{S_{1},\ldots,S_{m}\}roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } (with some sets Sjsubscript𝑆𝑗S_{j}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT potentially empty) and a Π𝐝subscriptnormal-Π𝐝\Pi_{\mathbf{d}}roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-respecting distance function that is a feasible solution to (LP1) with objective value at most b⋅λG⁢(𝐝)normal-⋅𝑏subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝b\cdot\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_b ⋅ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). Then G𝐺Gitalic_G has a flow-sparsifier G′superscript𝐺normal-′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with quality (1+3⁢ε)⁢b13𝜀𝑏(1+3\varepsilon)b( 1 + 3 italic_ε ) italic_b, which has

|V⁢(G′)|≤m|𝒟ε𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑐𝑟𝑒𝑡𝑒|≤m(ε−1⁢log⁡k)k2𝑉superscript𝐺′superscript𝑚superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀𝑑𝑖𝑠𝑐𝑟𝑒𝑡𝑒superscript𝑚superscriptsuperscript𝜀1𝑘superscript𝑘2\lvert V(G^{\prime})\rvert\leq m^{\lvert{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}\rvert}\leq m^{(\varepsilon^{-1}\log k)^{k^{2}}}| italic_V ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) | ≤ italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_k ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

vertices. Moreover, this graph G′superscript𝐺normal-′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is obtained by merging vertices in G𝐺Gitalic_G.

Proof.

For every demand 𝐝∈𝒟εdiscrete𝐝superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discrete\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}bold_d ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we know there is an appropriate m𝑚mitalic_m-way partition Π𝐝subscriptΠ𝐝\Pi_{\mathbf{d}}roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of V𝑉Vitalic_V. Imposing all these partitions simultaneously yields a “refined” partition Π={S1′,…,Sm′′}Πsubscriptsuperscript𝑆′1…subscriptsuperscript𝑆′superscript𝑚′\Pi=\{S^{\prime}_{1},\ldots,S^{\prime}_{m^{\prime}}\}roman_Π = { italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } in which the number of parts is m′≤m|𝒟εdiscrete|superscript𝑚′superscript𝑚superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discretem^{\prime}\leq m^{\lvert{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}\rvert}italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and two vertices in the same part Sj′subscriptsuperscript𝑆′𝑗S^{\prime}_{j}italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of this refined partition if and only if they are in the same part of every initial partition. Now apply Proposition 4.1 using this m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime}italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-way partition (using that any Π𝐝subscriptΠ𝐝\Pi_{\mathbf{d}}roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-respecting distance function is also a ΠΠ\Piroman_Π-respecting one), we obtain graph G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that is a flow-sparsifier of G𝐺Gitalic_G and has at most m′superscript𝑚′m^{\prime}italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT vertices. Finally, we bound |𝒟εdiscrete|superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discrete\lvert{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}\rvert| caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | using (3.6). ∎

4.1 Quasi-Bipartite Graphs via Clumping

As a warm-up, we use Proposition 4.2 to construct a graph sparsifier for quasi-bipartite graphs with quality (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_ε ), where the size of the sparsifier is only a function of k𝑘kitalic_k and ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε. Recall that a graph G𝐺Gitalic_G with terminals T𝑇Titalic_T is quasi-bipartite if the non-terminals form an independent set [RV99]. For this discussion, we assume that the terminals form an independent set as well, by subdividing every terminal-terminal edge—hence the graph is just bipartite.

Theorem 4.3.

Let G=(V,E,c)𝐺𝑉𝐸𝑐G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) be a quasi-bipartite k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal network, and let ε∈(0,18)𝜀018\varepsilon\in(0,{\tfrac{1}{8}})italic_ε ∈ ( 0 , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ). Then G𝐺Gitalic_G admits a quality 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε flow-sparsifier G^normal-^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG of size exp⁡{O⁢(k⁢log⁡kε⁢(1ε⁢log⁡k)k2)}𝑂𝑘𝑘𝜀superscript1𝜀𝑘superscript𝑘2\exp\{O(k\log\tfrac{k}{\varepsilon}(\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\log k)^{k^{2}})\}roman_exp { italic_O ( italic_k roman_log divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG roman_log italic_k ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) }.

Proof.

To apply Proposition 4.2, the main challenge is to bound m𝑚mitalic_m, the number of parts in the partition. To this end, fix a demand 𝐝∈𝒟εdiscrete⊆𝒟⁢(G)𝐝superscriptsubscript𝒟𝜀discrete𝒟𝐺\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}_{\varepsilon}^{\text{discrete}}\subseteq{\mathcal{D}}(G)bold_d ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT discrete end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊆ caligraphic_D ( italic_G ), and let {ℓe,δi⁢j}subscriptℓ𝑒subscript𝛿𝑖𝑗\{\ell_{e},\delta_{ij}\}{ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } be an optimal solution for the linear program (LP1), hence its value is ∑e∈Ece⁢ℓe=λG⁢(𝐝)subscript𝑒𝐸subscript𝑐𝑒subscriptℓ𝑒subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\sum_{e\in E}c_{e}\ell_{e}=\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e ∈ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). We will modify this solution into another one, {ℓe′,δi⁢j′}subscriptsuperscriptℓ′𝑒subscriptsuperscript𝛿′𝑖𝑗\{\ell^{\prime}_{e},\delta^{\prime}_{ij}\}{ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, that satisfies the desired conditions. This modification will be carried out in a couple steps, where we initially work only with lengths ℓu⁢vsubscriptℓ𝑢𝑣\ell_{uv}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of edges (u,v)∈E𝑢𝑣𝐸(u,v)\in E( italic_u , italic_v ) ∈ italic_E, and eventually let δ′superscript𝛿′\delta^{\prime}italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the metric induced by shortest-path distances.

For every s,t∈T𝑠𝑡𝑇s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T define the interval Γs⁢t:=[ε⁢ds⁢t,ds⁢t]assignsubscriptΓ𝑠𝑡𝜀subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡\Gamma_{st}:=[\varepsilon d_{st},d_{st}]roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := [ italic_ε italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ], and let Γ={0}∪(∪s,t∈TΓs⁢t)Γ0subscript𝑠𝑡𝑇subscriptΓ𝑠𝑡\Gamma=\{0\}\cup\Big{(}\cup_{s,t\in T}\Gamma_{st}\Big{)}roman_Γ = { 0 } ∪ ( ∪ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and let ΓεsuperscriptΓ𝜀\Gamma^{\varepsilon}roman_Γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT contain 00 and all powers of (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_ε ) that lie in ΓΓ\Gammaroman_Γ. The following claim provides structural information about a “nice” near-optimal solution.

Claim 4.4.

Fix a non-terminal v∈V∖T𝑣𝑉𝑇v\in V\setminus Titalic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T, Then the edges between v𝑣vitalic_v and its neighbors set N⁢(v)⊂T𝑁𝑣𝑇N(v)\subset Titalic_N ( italic_v ) ⊂ italic_T (in G𝐺Gitalic_G) admit edge lengths {ℓ^v⁢t:t∈N⁢(v)}conditional-setsubscriptnormal-^normal-ℓ𝑣𝑡𝑡𝑁𝑣\{\widehat{\ell}_{vt}:t\in N(v)\}{ over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_t ∈ italic_N ( italic_v ) } that

  • •

    are dominated by l𝑙litalic_l (namely, ∀t∈N⁢(v),ℓ^v⁢t≤ℓv⁢tformulae-sequencefor-all𝑡𝑁𝑣subscript^ℓ𝑣𝑡subscriptℓ𝑣𝑡\forall t\in N(v),\ \widehat{\ell}_{vt}\leq\ell_{vt}∀ italic_t ∈ italic_N ( italic_v ) , over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT);

    use values only from ΓεsuperscriptΓ𝜀\Gamma^{\varepsilon}roman_Γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (namely, ∀t∈N⁢(v),ℓ^v⁢t∈Γεformulae-sequencefor-all𝑡𝑁𝑣subscript^ℓ𝑣𝑡superscriptΓ𝜀\forall t\in N(v),\ \widehat{\ell}_{vt}\in\Gamma^{\varepsilon}∀ italic_t ∈ italic_N ( italic_v ) , over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ roman_Γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT); and
