    satisfy 1+ε(1−ε)21𝜀superscript1𝜀2\frac{1+\varepsilon}{(1-\varepsilon)^{2}}divide start_ARG 1 + italic_ε end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG-relaxed shortest distance constraints (namely, ∀s,t∈T,ℓ^s⁢v+ℓ^v⁢t≥(1−ε)21+ε⁢δs⁢tformulae-sequencefor-all𝑠𝑡𝑇subscript^ℓ𝑠𝑣subscript^ℓ𝑣𝑡superscript1𝜀21𝜀subscript𝛿𝑠𝑡\forall s,t\in T,\ \widehat{\ell}_{sv}+\widehat{\ell}_{vt}\geq\frac{(1-\varepsilon)^{2}}{1+\varepsilon}\delta_{st}∀ italic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T , over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ divide start_ARG ( 1 - italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_ε end_ARG italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT).

Proof.

Let every edge length ℓ^v⁢tsubscript^ℓ𝑣𝑡\widehat{\ell}_{vt}over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be defined as ℓv⁢tsubscriptℓ𝑣𝑡\ell_{vt}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT rounded down to its nearest value from ΓεsuperscriptΓ𝜀\Gamma^{\varepsilon}roman_Γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The first two claimed properties then hold by construction. For the third property, recall that l𝑙litalic_l is a feasible LP solution, thus ℓs⁢v+ℓv⁢t≥ds⁢tsubscriptℓ𝑠𝑣subscriptℓ𝑣𝑡subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡\ell_{sv}+\ell_{vt}\geq d_{st}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Assume without loss of generality that ℓs⁢v≤ℓv⁢tsubscriptℓ𝑠𝑣subscriptℓ𝑣𝑡\ell_{sv}\leq\ell_{vt}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. If the large one ℓv⁢t≥(1−ε)2⁢ds⁢tsubscriptℓ𝑣𝑡superscript1𝜀2subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡\ell_{vt}\geq(1-\varepsilon)^{2}d_{st}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ ( 1 - italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the claim follows because also ℓ^v⁢t≥(1−ε)21+ε⁢ds⁢tsubscript^ℓ𝑣𝑡superscript1𝜀21𝜀subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡\widehat{\ell}_{vt}\geq\frac{(1-\varepsilon)^{2}}{1+\varepsilon}d_{st}over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ divide start_ARG ( 1 - italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_ε end_ARG italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, regardless of whether ℓv⁢tsubscriptℓ𝑣𝑡\ell_{vt}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is smaller or bigger than ds⁢tsubscript𝑑𝑠𝑡d_{st}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where the extra term of (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_ε ) comes from rounding down to the nearest power of (1+ε)1𝜀(1+\varepsilon)( 1 + italic_ε ). Otherwise, ℓv⁢t<(1−ε)2⁢ds⁢tsubscriptℓ𝑣𝑡superscript1𝜀2subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡\ell_{vt}<(1-\varepsilon)^{2}d_{st}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ( 1 - italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT hence the smaller one ℓs⁢v≥ε⁢(2−ε)⁢ds⁢tsubscriptℓ𝑠𝑣𝜀2𝜀subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡\ell_{sv}\geq\varepsilon(2-\varepsilon)d_{st}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_ε ( 2 - italic_ε ) italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and rounding down ensures ℓ^s⁢v≥ε⁢(2−ε)1+ε⁢ds⁢tsubscript^ℓ𝑠𝑣𝜀2𝜀1𝜀subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡\widehat{\ell}_{sv}\geq\frac{\varepsilon(2-\varepsilon)}{1+\varepsilon}d_{st}over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ divide start_ARG italic_ε ( 2 - italic_ε ) end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_ε end_ARG italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The fact that ε<18𝜀18\varepsilon<{\tfrac{1}{8}}italic_ε < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG means ε⁢(2−ε)⁢1+ε≥1𝜀2𝜀1𝜀1{\varepsilon(2-\varepsilon)}{1+\varepsilon}\geq 1italic_ε ( 2 - italic_ε ) 1 + italic_ε ≥ 1, so rounding down does not zero out ℓ^s⁢vsubscript^ℓ𝑠𝑣\widehat{\ell}_{sv}over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We conclude that the new lengths are at least 11+ε11𝜀\frac{1}{1+\varepsilon}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_ε end_ARG times the old ones, namely ℓ^s⁢v≥ℓs⁢v1+εsubscript^ℓ𝑠𝑣subscriptℓ𝑠𝑣1𝜀\widehat{\ell}_{sv}\geq\frac{\ell_{sv}}{1+\varepsilon}over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ divide start_ARG roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_ε end_ARG and ℓ^v⁢t≥ℓv⁢t1+εsubscript^ℓ𝑣𝑡subscriptℓ𝑣𝑡1𝜀\widehat{\ell}_{vt}\geq\frac{\ell_{vt}}{1+\varepsilon}over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ divide start_ARG roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_ε end_ARG. The claim follows. ∎

We proceed with the proof of Theorem 4.3. Define new edge lengths {ℓe′:e∈E}conditional-setsubscriptsuperscriptℓ′𝑒𝑒𝐸\{\ell^{\prime}_{e}:e\in E\}{ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_e ∈ italic_E } by applying the claim and scaling edge lengths by 1+ε(1−ε)21𝜀superscript1𝜀2\frac{1+\varepsilon}{(1-\varepsilon)^{2}}divide start_ARG 1 + italic_ε end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG, namely for every v∈V∖T𝑣𝑉𝑇v\in V\setminus Titalic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T, and an adjacent t∈T𝑡𝑇t\in Titalic_t ∈ italic_T, set ℓv⁢t′:=1+ε(1−ε)2⁢ℓ^v⁢tassignsubscriptsuperscriptℓ′𝑣𝑡1𝜀superscript1𝜀2subscript^ℓ𝑣𝑡\ell^{\prime}_{vt}:=\frac{1+\varepsilon}{(1-\varepsilon)^{2}}\,\widehat{\ell}_{vt}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG 1 + italic_ε end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This scaling and the third property of Claim 4.4 ensures that the shortest-path distances (using edge lengths ℓe′subscriptsuperscriptℓ′𝑒\ell^{\prime}_{e}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) between each pair of vertices i,j𝑖𝑗i,jitalic_i , italic_j is at least δi⁢jsubscript𝛿𝑖𝑗\delta_{ij}italic_δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Now partition the non-terminals into buckets, where two non-terminals u,v∈V∖T𝑢𝑣𝑉𝑇u,v\in V\setminus Titalic_u , italic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T are in the same bucket if they “agree” about each of their neighbors t∈T𝑡𝑇t\in Titalic_t ∈ italic_T: either (i) they are both non-adjacent to t𝑡titalic_t, or (ii) they are both adjacent to t𝑡titalic_t and ℓu⁢t′=ℓv⁢t′subscriptsuperscriptℓ′𝑢𝑡subscriptsuperscriptℓ′𝑣𝑡\ell^{\prime}_{ut}=\ell^{\prime}_{vt}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Observe that this bucketing is indeed a well-defined equivalence relation. Now for every u,v∈V∖T𝑢𝑣𝑉𝑇u,v\in V\setminus Titalic_u , italic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T that are the same bucket, add an edge of length ℓu⁢v′=0subscriptsuperscriptℓ′𝑢𝑣0\ell^{\prime}_{uv}=0roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, and let E′superscript𝐸′E^{\prime}italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote this set of new edges. Let δ′superscript𝛿′\delta^{\prime}italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the shortest-path distances according to these new edge-lengths. Observe that the shortest-path distances between the terminals are unchanged by the addition of these new zero-length edges, even though the distances between some non-terminals have obviously changed. Hence (ℓe′,δi⁢j′)subscriptsuperscriptℓ′𝑒subscriptsuperscript𝛿′𝑖𝑗(\ell^{\prime}_{e},\delta^{\prime}_{ij})( roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_δ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a feasible solution to (LP1), with objective function value at most 1+ε(1−ε)2⁢λG⁢(𝐝)≤(1+5⁢ε)⁢λG⁢(𝐝)1𝜀superscript1𝜀2subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝15𝜀subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\frac{1+\varepsilon}{(1-\varepsilon)^{2}}\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\leq(1+5\varepsilon)\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})divide start_ARG 1 + italic_ε end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≤ ( 1 + 5 italic_ε ) italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ).

We define the equivalence classes of the bucketing above as the sets Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Proposition 4.2. Each bucket corresponds to a “profile” vector with k𝑘kitalic_k coordinates that represent the lengths of k𝑘kitalic_k edges going to the k𝑘kitalic_k terminals, if at all there is an edge to the terminals. Each coordinate of this profile vector is an element of ΓεsuperscriptΓ𝜀\Gamma^{\varepsilon}roman_Γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ε end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or it represents the corresponding edge does not exist. It follows that the number of buckets (or profile vectors) is m≤((k2)⁢(log1+ε⁡1ε+3))k≤(O⁢(k2ε⁢log⁡1ε))k≤(O⁢(kε))2⁢k≤exp⁡{O⁢(k⁢log⁡(k/ε))}𝑚superscriptbinomial𝑘2subscript1𝜀1𝜀3𝑘superscript𝑂superscript𝑘2𝜀1𝜀𝑘superscript𝑂𝑘𝜀2𝑘𝑂𝑘𝑘𝜀m\leq\Big{(}\binom{k}{2}(\log_{1+\varepsilon}\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}+3)\Big{)}^{k}\leq(O(\tfrac{k^{2}}{\varepsilon}\log\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}))^{k}\leq(O(\tfrac{k}{\varepsilon}))^{2k}\leq\exp\{{O(k\log(k/\varepsilon))}\}italic_m ≤ ( ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) ( roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 + italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG + 3 ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ ( italic_O ( divide start_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ ( italic_O ( divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ roman_exp { italic_O ( italic_k roman_log ( italic_k / italic_ε ) ) }. The theorem follows by applying Proposition 4.2, which asserts the existence of a flow-sparsifier with m(ε−1⁢log⁡k)k2≤exp⁡{O⁢(k⁢log⁡kε⁢(1ε⁢log⁡k)k2)}superscript𝑚superscriptsuperscript𝜀1𝑘superscript𝑘2𝑂𝑘𝑘𝜀superscript1𝜀𝑘superscript𝑘2m^{(\varepsilon^{-1}\log k)^{k^{2}}}\leq\exp\{O(k\log\tfrac{k}{\varepsilon}(\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\log k)^{k^{2}})\}italic_m start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log italic_k ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ roman_exp { italic_O ( italic_k roman_log divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG roman_log italic_k ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) } vertices. ∎

5 The Splicing and Composition Techniques

We say that a path is terminal-free if all its internal vertices are non-terminals. This terminology shall be used mostly for flow paths, in which the paths’ endpoints are certainly terminals. The lemma below refers to two different methods of routing a demand 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d in a network G𝐺Gitalic_G. The first method is the usual (and default) meaning, where the demand is routed along arbitrary flow paths. The second method is to route the demand along terminal-free flow paths, and we will say this explicitly whenever we refer to this method. We use a parameter ρ≥1𝜌1\rho\geq 1italic_ρ ≥ 1 to achieve greater generality, although the case ρ=1𝜌1\rho=1italic_ρ = 1 conveys the main idea.

Lemma 5.1 (Splicing Lemma).

Let Gasubscript𝐺𝑎G_{a}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Gbsubscript𝐺𝑏G_{b}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be two networks having the same set of terminals T𝑇Titalic_T, and fix ρ≥1𝜌1\rho\geq 1italic_ρ ≥ 1. Suppose that whenever a demand 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d between terminals in T𝑇Titalic_T can be routed in Gasubscript𝐺𝑎G_{a}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using terminal-free flow paths, demand 𝐝/ρ𝐝𝜌\mathbf{d}/\rhobold_d / italic_ρ can be routed in Gbsubscript𝐺𝑏G_{b}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (by arbitrary flow paths). Then for every demand 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d between terminals in T𝑇Titalic_T that can be routed in Gasubscript𝐺𝑎G_{a}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, demand 𝐝/ρ𝐝𝜌\mathbf{d}/\rhobold_d / italic_ρ can be routed in Gbsubscript𝐺𝑏G_{b}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proof.

Consider a demand 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d that is routed in Gasubscript𝐺𝑎G_{a}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT using flow f*superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and let us show that it can be routed also in Gbsubscript𝐺𝑏G_{b}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Fix for f*superscript𝑓f^{*}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT a flow decomposition D={(P1,ϕ⁢(P1)),(P2,ϕ⁢(P2)),…}𝐷subscript𝑃1italic-ϕsubscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2italic-ϕsubscript𝑃2…D=\{(P_{1},\phi(P_{1})),(P_{2},\phi(P_{2})),\ldots\}italic_D = { ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϕ ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) , ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϕ ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) , … } for it, where each Plsubscript𝑃𝑙P_{l}italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a terminal-to-terminal path, and ϕ⁢(Pl)italic-ϕsubscript𝑃𝑙\phi(P_{l})italic_ϕ ( italic_P start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is the amount of flow sent on this path. A flow decomposition also specifies the demand vector since ds⁢t=∑s⁢t-paths P∈Dϕ⁢(P)subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡subscripts⁢t-paths P∈Ditalic-ϕ𝑃d_{st}=\sum_{\text{$st$-paths $P\in D$}}\phi(P)italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t -paths italic_P ∈ italic_D end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ ( italic_P ). If all the paths (P,ϕ)∈D𝑃italic-ϕ𝐷(P,\phi)\in D( italic_P , italic_ϕ ) ∈ italic_D are terminal-free, then we know by the assumption of the lemma that demand 𝐝/ρ𝐝𝜌\mathbf{d}/\rhobold_d / italic_ρ can be routed in Gbsubscript𝐺𝑏G_{b}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Else, take a path (P,ϕ)∈D𝑃italic-ϕ𝐷(P,\phi)\in D( italic_P , italic_ϕ ) ∈ italic_D that contains internally some terminal—say P𝑃Pitalic_P routes flow between terminals t′,t′′superscript𝑡′superscript𝑡′′t^{\prime},t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and uses another terminal s𝑠sitalic_s internally. We may assume without loss of generality that the flow paths are simple, so s∉{t′,t′′}𝑠superscript𝑡′superscript𝑡′′s\not\in\{t^{\prime},t^{\prime\prime}\}italic_s ∉ { italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }. We replace the flow (P,ϕ⁢(P))𝑃italic-ϕ𝑃(P,\phi(P))( italic_P , italic_ϕ ( italic_P ) ) in 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d by the two paths (P⁢[t′,s],ϕ)𝑃superscript𝑡′𝑠italic-ϕ(P[t^{\prime},s],\phi)( italic_P [ italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_s ] , italic_ϕ ) and (P⁢[s,t′′],ϕ)𝑃𝑠superscript𝑡′′italic-ϕ(P[s,t^{\prime\prime}],\phi)( italic_P [ italic_s , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] , italic_ϕ ) to get a new flow decomposition D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and denote the corresponding demand vector by 𝐝′superscript𝐝′\mathbf{d}^{\prime}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that dt′,t′′′=dt′,t′′−ϕsubscriptsuperscript𝑑′superscript𝑡′superscript𝑡′′subscript𝑑superscript𝑡′superscript𝑡′′italic-ϕd^{\prime}_{t^{\prime},t^{\prime\prime}}=d_{t^{\prime},t^{\prime\prime}}-\phiitalic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_ϕ, whereas dt′,s′=dt′,s+ϕsubscriptsuperscript𝑑′superscript𝑡′𝑠subscript𝑑superscript𝑡′𝑠italic-ϕd^{\prime}_{t^{\prime},s}=d_{t^{\prime},s}+\phiitalic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_ϕ and the same for ds,t′′′subscriptsuperscript𝑑′𝑠superscript𝑡′′d^{\prime}_{s,t^{\prime\prime}}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Moreover, if 𝐝′/ρsuperscript𝐝′𝜌\mathbf{d}^{\prime}/\rhobold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_ρ can be routed on some graph Gbsubscript𝐺𝑏G_{b}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with an arbitrary routing, we can connect together ϕ/ρitalic-ϕ𝜌\phi/\rhoitalic_ϕ / italic_ρ amount of the flow from t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to s𝑠sitalic_s with ϕ/ρitalic-ϕ𝜌\phi/\rhoitalic_ϕ / italic_ρ flow from s𝑠sitalic_s to t′′superscript𝑡′′t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to get a feasible routing for 𝐝/ρ𝐝𝜌\mathbf{d}/\rhobold_d / italic_ρ in Gbsubscript𝐺𝑏G_{b}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Moreover the total number of terminals occurring internally on paths in the flow decomposition D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime}italic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is less than that in 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d, so the proof follows by a simple induction. ∎

The next lemma addresses the case where our network can be described as the gluing of two networks G1subscript𝐺1G_{1}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and G2subscript𝐺2G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and we already have sparsifiers for G1subscript𝐺1G_{1}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and G2subscript𝐺2G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; in this case, we can simply glue together the two sparsifiers, provided that the vertices at the gluing locations are themselves terminals. Formally, let G1subscript𝐺1G_{1}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and G2subscript𝐺2G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be networks on disjoint sets of vertices, having terminal sets T1={s1,s2,…,sa}subscript𝑇1subscript𝑠1subscript𝑠2…subscript𝑠𝑎T_{1}=\{s_{1},s_{2},\ldots,s_{a}\}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and T2={t1,t2,…,tb}subscript𝑇2subscript𝑡1subscript𝑡2…subscript𝑡𝑏T_{2}=\{t_{1},t_{2},\ldots,t_{b}\}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } respectively. Given a bijection ϕ:={s1↔t1,…,sc↔tc}\phi:=\{s_{1}\leftrightarrow t_{1},\ldots,s_{c}\leftrightarrow t_{c}\}italic_ϕ := { italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ↔ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ↔ italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } between some subset of T1subscript𝑇1T_{1}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and T2subscript𝑇2T_{2}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the ϕitalic-ϕ\phiitalic_ϕ-merge of G1subscript𝐺1G_{1}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and G2subscript𝐺2G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (denoted G1⊕ϕG2subscriptdirect-sumitalic-ϕsubscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2G_{1}\oplus_{\phi}G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) is the graph formed by identifying the vertices sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and tisubscript𝑡𝑖t_{i}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all i∈[c]𝑖delimited-[]𝑐i\in[c]italic_i ∈ [ italic_c ]. Note that the set of terminals in G𝐺Gitalic_G is T:=T1∪{tc+1,…,tb}assign𝑇subscript𝑇1subscript𝑡𝑐1…subscript𝑡𝑏T:=T_{1}\cup\{t_{c+1},\ldots,t_{b}\}italic_T := italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ { italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_b end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }.

Lemma 5.2 (Composition Lemma).

Suppose G=G1⊕ϕG2𝐺subscriptdirect-sumitalic-ϕsubscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2G=G_{1}\oplus_{\phi}G_{2}italic_G = italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⊕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For j∈{1,2}𝑗12j\in\{1,2\}italic_j ∈ { 1 , 2 }, let Gj′subscriptsuperscript𝐺normal-′𝑗G^{\prime}_{j}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be a flow-sparsifier for Gjsubscript𝐺𝑗G_{j}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with quality ρjsubscript𝜌𝑗\rho_{j}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then the graph G′=G1′⊕ϕG2′superscript𝐺normal-′subscriptdirect-sumitalic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝐺1normal-′superscriptsubscript𝐺2normal-′G^{\prime}=G_{1}^{\prime}\oplus_{\phi}G_{2}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊕ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϕ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a quality max⁡{ρ1,ρ2}subscript𝜌1subscript𝜌2\max\{{\rho_{1},\rho_{2}}\}roman_max { italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } flow sparsifier for G𝐺Gitalic_G.

Proof.

Consider a demand 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d that is routable in G𝐺Gitalic_G using flow paths that do not have internal terminals. Since G𝐺Gitalic_G is formed by gluing G1subscript𝐺1G_{1}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and G2subscript𝐺2G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at terminals, this means each of the flow paths lies entirely within G1subscript𝐺1G_{1}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or G2subscript𝐺2G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We can write 𝐝=𝐝1+𝐝2𝐝subscript𝐝1subscript𝐝2\mathbf{d}=\mathbf{d}_{1}+\mathbf{d}_{2}bold_d = bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where each 𝐝jsubscript𝐝𝑗\mathbf{d}_{j}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the demand being routed on the flow paths among these that lie within Gjsubscript𝐺𝑗G_{j}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By the definition of flow-sparsifiers, these demands are also routable in G1′,G2′superscriptsubscript𝐺1′superscriptsubscript𝐺2′G_{1}^{\prime},G_{2}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT respectively, and hence demand 𝐝1+𝐝2=𝐝subscript𝐝1subscript𝐝2𝐝\mathbf{d}_{1}+\mathbf{d}_{2}=\mathbf{d}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_d is routable in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (in fact by paths that lie entirely within G1subscript𝐺1G_{1}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT or G2subscript𝐺2G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). Applying the Splicing Lemma (with ρ=1𝜌1\rho=1italic_ρ = 1), we get that every demand 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d routable in G𝐺Gitalic_G is routable also in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

The argument in the other direction is similar. Assume 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d is routable in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT using terminal-free flow paths; then we get two demands 𝐝1,𝐝2subscript𝐝1subscript𝐝2\mathbf{d}_{1},\mathbf{d}_{2}bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT routable entirely in G1′,G2′superscriptsubscript𝐺1′superscriptsubscript𝐺2′G_{1}^{\prime},G_{2}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT respectively. Scaling these demands down by max⁡{ρ1,ρ2}subscript𝜌1subscript𝜌2\max\{{\rho_{1},\rho_{2}}\}roman_max { italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, they can be routed in G1,G2subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2G_{1},G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT respectively, and hence we can route their sum (𝐝1+𝐝2)/max⁡{ρ1,ρ2}subscript𝐝1subscript𝐝2subscript𝜌1subscript𝜌2(\mathbf{d}_{1}+\mathbf{d}_{2})/\max\{{\rho_{1},\rho_{2}}\}( bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / roman_max { italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } in G𝐺Gitalic_G. Applying the Splicing Lemma with ρ=max⁡{ρ1,ρ2}𝜌subscript𝜌1subscript𝜌2\rho=\max\{{\rho_{1},\rho_{2}}\}italic_ρ = roman_max { italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, we get a similar conclusion for all demands routable in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (on arbitrary flow paths), and this completes the proof. ∎

Applications of Splicing/Composition.

The Splicing and Composition Lemmas will be useful in many of our arguments: we use them to show a singly-exponential bound for quasi-bipartite graphs in Section 5.1 below, in the sampling approach for quasi-bipartite graphs in Section 6, and also in constructing flow-sparsifiers for series parallel and bounded treewidth graphs in Section 7.

5.1 Quasi-Bipartite Graphs via Splicing

We show how to use Splicing Lemma 5.1 to construct a flow sparsifier for the quasi-bipartite graph of size (1/ε)O~⁢(k)superscript1𝜀~𝑂𝑘(1/\varepsilon)^{\tilde{O}(k)}( 1 / italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Theorem 5.3.

Let G=(V,E,c)𝐺𝑉𝐸𝑐G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) be a quasi-bipartite k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal network, and let ε∈(0,18)𝜀018\varepsilon\in(0,{\tfrac{1}{8}})italic_ε ∈ ( 0 , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ). Then G𝐺Gitalic_G admits a quality 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε flow-sparsifier G^normal-^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG of size (1/ε)O~⁢(k)superscript1𝜀normal-~𝑂𝑘(1/\varepsilon)^{\tilde{O}(k)}( 1 / italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof.

The construction goes through several stages. First, we construct G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by rounding down the capacity to an integer power of 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε. The main idea is to define “types” for non-terminals v𝑣vitalic_v and then merge all vertices of the same type (i.e., the new edge capacity is the sum of the respective edge capacities incident to the merged vertices). The main difficulty is in defining the types.

To define the type, first of all partition all non-terminals v𝑣vitalic_v into “super-types”, according to the set S𝑆Sitalic_S of terminals that are connected to v𝑣vitalic_v by edges with non-zero capacity. Now fix one such super-type S𝑆Sitalic_S, i.e., all vertices v𝑣vitalic_v such that {t∈T:cv⁢t≠0}=Sconditional-set𝑡𝑇subscript𝑐𝑣𝑡0𝑆\{t\in T:c_{vt}\neq 0\}=S{ italic_t ∈ italic_T : italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ 0 } = italic_S. Without loss of generality, suppose S={t1,…⁢th+1}𝑆subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡ℎ1S=\{t_{1},\ldots t_{h+1}\}italic_S = { italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and cv⁢ti≥cv⁢ti+1subscript𝑐𝑣subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑐𝑣subscript𝑡𝑖1c_{vt_{i}}\geq c_{vt_{i+1}}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for i∈[h]𝑖delimited-[]ℎi\in[h]italic_i ∈ [ italic_h ]. For a vertex v𝑣vitalic_v, consider the vector of ratios rv*={cv⁢t1/cv⁢t2,cv⁢t2/cv⁢t3,…⁢cv⁢th/cv⁢th+1)subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑣subscript𝑐𝑣subscript𝑡1subscript𝑐𝑣subscript𝑡2subscript𝑐𝑣subscript𝑡2subscript𝑐𝑣subscript𝑡3…subscript𝑐𝑣subscript𝑡ℎsubscript𝑐𝑣subscript𝑡ℎ1r^{*}_{v}=\{c_{vt_{1}}/c_{vt_{2}},c_{vt_{2}}/c_{vt_{3}},\ldots c_{vt_{h}}/c_{vt_{h+1}})italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Note that rv*subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑣r^{*}_{v}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT’s entries are all power of 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε. Now let M=k2/ε+1𝑀superscript𝑘2𝜀1M=k^{2}/\varepsilon+1italic_M = italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_ε + 1, and define rvsubscript𝑟𝑣r_{v}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by thresholding all entries of rt*subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑡r^{*}_{t}italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT * end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT exceeding M𝑀Mitalic_M by M𝑀Mitalic_M. The rvsubscript𝑟𝑣r_{v}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT defines the type of the vertex v𝑣vitalic_v. Now we merge all vertices v𝑣vitalic_v with the same super-type S𝑆Sitalic_S and type rtsubscript𝑟𝑡r_{t}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Denote the new capacities c^t,usubscript^𝑐𝑡𝑢\hat{c}_{t,u}over^ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t , italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for a terminal t𝑡titalic_t and a non-terminal node u𝑢uitalic_u in G^^𝐺\hat{G}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG.

Now we proceed to the analysis. First of all, notice that G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a quality 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε flow sparsifier, so we will care to preserve its flows only. Furthermore, since the main operation is merging of the nodes, we can only increase the set of feasible demands in G^^𝐺\hat{G}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG. The main challenge is to prove that if we can route a demand vector 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we can route a demand (1−O⁢(ε))⁢𝐝1𝑂𝜀𝐝(1-O(\varepsilon))\mathbf{d}( 1 - italic_O ( italic_ε ) ) bold_d in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Using the Splicing Lemma 5.1, it is enough to consider only demands 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d that are feasible using 2-hop paths.

Fix some demand vector 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d that is feasible in G^^𝐺\hat{G}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG using 2-hop paths only. Fix a non-terminal node u∈G^𝑢^𝐺u\in\hat{G}italic_u ∈ over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG, and let fs,tsubscript𝑓𝑠𝑡f_{s,t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the flow (of the solution) between s,t∈T𝑠𝑡𝑇s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T via u𝑢uitalic_u. Suppose u𝑢uitalic_u has super-type S𝑆Sitalic_S and type r=(r1,…⁢rh)𝑟subscript𝑟1…subscript𝑟ℎr=(r_{1},\ldots r_{h})italic_r = ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). We will show that we can route (1−O⁢(ε))⁢fs,t1𝑂𝜀subscript𝑓𝑠𝑡(1-O(\varepsilon))f_{s,t}( 1 - italic_O ( italic_ε ) ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in G𝐺Gitalic_G for all s𝑠sitalic_s to t𝑡titalic_t via the nodes v∈G′𝑣superscript𝐺′v\in G^{\prime}italic_v ∈ italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that have super-type S𝑆Sitalic_S and type r𝑟ritalic_r. This would clearly be sufficient to conclude that (1−O⁢(ε))⁢𝐝1𝑂𝜀𝐝(1-O(\varepsilon))\mathbf{d}( 1 - italic_O ( italic_ε ) ) bold_d is feasible in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Let v1,…⁢vmsubscript𝑣1…subscript𝑣𝑚v_{1},\ldots v_{m}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the nodes with super-type S𝑆Sitalic_S and type r𝑟ritalic_r.

We proceed in stages, routing iteratively from the “small flows” to the “large flows” via u𝑢uitalic_u. Consider a suffix of r𝑟ritalic_r, denoted ri,…⁢rhsubscript𝑟𝑖…subscript𝑟ℎr_{i},\ldots r_{h}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where ri=Msubscript𝑟𝑖𝑀r_{i}=Mitalic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_M and ri′<Msubscript𝑟superscript𝑖′𝑀r_{i^{\prime}}<Mitalic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_M for all i′>isuperscript𝑖′𝑖i^{\prime}>iitalic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT > italic_i. For j∈[m]𝑗delimited-[]𝑚j\in[m]italic_j ∈ [ italic_m ], let αvj=cti,vj/c^ti,usubscript𝛼subscript𝑣𝑗subscript𝑐subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑣𝑗subscript^𝑐subscript𝑡𝑖𝑢\alpha_{v_{j}}=c_{t_{i},v_{j}}/\hat{c}_{t_{i},u}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over^ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Now for all flows fs⁢tsubscript𝑓𝑠𝑡f_{st}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where s∈{ti+1,…⁢th+1}𝑠subscript𝑡𝑖1…subscript𝑡ℎ1s\in\{t_{i+1},\ldots t_{h+1}\}italic_s ∈ { italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } and t∈{t1,…⁢th}𝑡subscript𝑡1…subscript𝑡ℎt\in\{t_{1},\ldots t_{h}\}italic_t ∈ { italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, we route (1−ε)⁢αvj⁢fs⁢t1𝜀subscript𝛼subscript𝑣𝑗subscript𝑓𝑠𝑡(1-\varepsilon)\alpha_{v_{j}}f_{st}( 1 - italic_ε ) italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT flow from s𝑠sitalic_s to t𝑡titalic_t via vjsubscript𝑣𝑗v_{j}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We argue this is possible (even when doing this for all s,t𝑠𝑡s,titalic_s , italic_t). Namely, consider any edge e=(ti′,vj)𝑒subscript𝑡superscript𝑖′subscript𝑣𝑗e=(t_{i^{\prime}},v_{j})italic_e = ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) for ti′∈{ti+1,…⁢th+1}subscript𝑡superscript𝑖′subscript𝑡𝑖1…subscript𝑡ℎ1t_{i^{\prime}}\in\{t_{i+1},\ldots t_{h+1}\}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ { italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. The flow accumulated on this edge is:

∑t(1−ε)⁢αvj⁢fti′,tsubscript𝑡1𝜀subscript𝛼subscript𝑣𝑗subscript𝑓subscript𝑡superscript𝑖′𝑡\displaystyle\sum_{t}(1-\varepsilon)\alpha_{v_{j}}f_{t_{i^{\prime}},t}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_ε ) italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =(1−ε)⁢cti,vj/c^ti,u⋅∑tfti′,tabsent⋅1𝜀subscript𝑐subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑣𝑗subscript^𝑐subscript𝑡𝑖𝑢subscript𝑡subscript𝑓subscript𝑡superscript𝑖′𝑡\displaystyle=(1-\varepsilon)c_{t_{i},v_{j}}/\hat{c}_{t_{i},u}\cdot\sum_{t}f_{t_{i^{\prime}},t}= ( 1 - italic_ε ) italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over^ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
≤(1−ε)⁢cti,vj/c^ti,u⋅c^ti′,u.absent⋅1𝜀subscript𝑐subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑣𝑗subscript^𝑐subscript𝑡𝑖𝑢subscript^𝑐subscript𝑡superscript𝑖′𝑢\displaystyle\leq(1-\varepsilon)c_{t_{i},v_{j}}/\hat{c}_{t_{i},u}\cdot\hat{c}_{t_{i^{\prime}},u}.≤ ( 1 - italic_ε ) italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over^ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ over^ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

Note that cti⁢vj/cti′,vj=ri⋅ri+1⁢⋯⁢ri′−1subscript𝑐subscript𝑡𝑖subscript𝑣𝑗subscript𝑐subscript𝑡superscript𝑖′subscript𝑣𝑗⋅subscript𝑟𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖1⋯subscript𝑟superscript𝑖′1c_{t_{i}v_{j}}/c_{t_{i^{\prime}},v_{j}}=r_{i}\cdot r_{i+1}\cdots r_{i^{\prime}-1}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋯ italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and similarly c^ti,u/c^ti′,u=ri⋅ri+1⁢⋯⁢ri′−1subscript^𝑐subscript𝑡𝑖𝑢subscript^𝑐subscript𝑡superscript𝑖′𝑢⋅subscript𝑟𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖1⋯subscript𝑟superscript𝑖′1\hat{c}_{t_{i},u}/\hat{c}_{t_{i^{\prime}},u}=r_{i}\cdot r_{i+1}\cdots r_{i^{\prime}-1}over^ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over^ start_ARG italic_c end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋯ italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Hence the above formula is bounded by (1−ε)⁢cti′,vj1𝜀subscript𝑐subscript𝑡superscript𝑖′subscript𝑣𝑗(1-\varepsilon)c_{t_{i^{\prime}},v_{j}}( 1 - italic_ε ) italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i.e., we satisfy the edge capacity (with a 1−ε1𝜀1-\varepsilon1 - italic_ε slack, which will help later). Furthermore, we have routed ∑j(1−ε)⁢αvj⁢fs⁢t=(1−ε)⁢fs⁢tsubscript𝑗1𝜀subscript𝛼subscript𝑣𝑗subscript𝑓𝑠𝑡1𝜀subscript𝑓𝑠𝑡\sum_{j}(1-\varepsilon)\alpha_{v_{j}}f_{st}=(1-\varepsilon)f_{st}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 1 - italic_ε ) italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 - italic_ε ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT flow for each s,t𝑠𝑡s,titalic_s , italic_t.

We will repeat the above procedure for the next suffix of r𝑟ritalic_r until we are done routing flow G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note that we have at most k𝑘kitalic_k such stages.

We need to mention one more aspect in the above argument — what happens to the flow that is contributed to edges (ti′,vj)subscript𝑡superscript𝑖′subscript𝑣𝑗(t_{i^{\prime}},v_{j})( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where i′≤isuperscript𝑖′𝑖i^{\prime}\leq iitalic_i start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_i? The total contribution is at most k/M≤ε/k𝑘𝑀𝜀𝑘k/M\leq\varepsilon/kitalic_k / italic_M ≤ italic_ε / italic_k fraction of the capacity (since ri=Msubscript𝑟𝑖𝑀r_{i}=Mitalic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_M), which, over all (at most) k𝑘kitalic_k stages is still at most ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε fraction of the edge capacity. Since we left a slack of ε𝜀\varepsilonitalic_ε in the capacity for each edge in the above argument, we still satisfy the capacity constraint overall for each edge.

Finally, to argue about the size of G^^𝐺\hat{G}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG, note that there are only 2ksuperscript2𝑘2^{k}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT super-types, and there are at most O⁢(k2/ε)k𝑂superscriptsuperscript𝑘2𝜀𝑘O(k^{2}/\varepsilon)^{k}italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT possible vectors r𝑟ritalic_r, and hence G^^𝐺\hat{G}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG has size at most O⁢(2k⋅O⁢(k2/ε)k)=(1/ε)O~⁢(k)𝑂⋅superscript2𝑘𝑂superscriptsuperscript𝑘2𝜀𝑘superscript1𝜀~𝑂𝑘O(2^{k}\cdot O(k^{2}/\varepsilon)^{k})=(1/\varepsilon)^{\tilde{O}(k)}italic_O ( 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ( 1 / italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_k ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. ∎

6 A Sampling Approach for Flow Sparsifiers

In this section we develop our sampling approach to construct flow sparsifiers. In particular, for quasi-bipartite graphs we construct in this method flow sparsifiers of size bounded by a polynomial in k/ε𝑘𝜀k/\varepsilonitalic_k / italic_ε. This family includes the graphs for which a lower bound (for exact cut/flow sparsification) was proved in [KR13], and we further discuss how our construction extends to include also the graphs for which a lower bound was proved in [KRTV12].

6.1 Preliminaries

We say that a random variable is deterministic if it has variance 00 (i.e., it attains one specific value with probability 1111).

Theorem 6.1 (A Chernoff Variant).

Let X1,…,Xm≥0subscript𝑋1normal-…subscript𝑋𝑚0X_{1},\ldots,X_{m}\geq 0italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 be independent random variables, such that each Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is either deterministic or Xi∈[0,b]subscript𝑋𝑖0𝑏X_{i}\in[0,b]italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ 0 , italic_b ], and let X=∑i=1mXi𝑋superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑚subscript𝑋𝑖X=\sum_{i=1}^{m}X_{i}italic_X = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then

Pr⁡[X≤(1−ε)⁢𝔼[X]]Pr𝑋1𝜀𝔼𝑋\displaystyle\Pr\Big{[}X\leq(1-\varepsilon)\operatorname*{{\mathbb{E}}}[X]\Big{]}roman_Pr [ italic_X ≤ ( 1 - italic_ε ) blackboard_E [ italic_X ] ] ≤e−ε2⁢𝔼[X]/(2⁢b),absentsuperscript𝑒superscript𝜀2𝔼𝑋2𝑏\displaystyle\leq e^{-\varepsilon^{2}\operatorname*{{\mathbb{E}}}[X]/(2b)},≤ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ italic_X ] / ( 2 italic_b ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ∀ε∈(0,1),for-all𝜀01\displaystyle\forall\varepsilon\in(0,1),∀ italic_ε ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) ,
Pr⁡[X≥(1+ε)⁢𝔼[X]]Pr𝑋1𝜀𝔼𝑋\displaystyle\Pr\Big{[}X\geq(1+\varepsilon)\operatorname*{{\mathbb{E}}}[X]\Big{]}roman_Pr [ italic_X ≥ ( 1 + italic_ε ) blackboard_E [ italic_X ] ] ≤e−ε2⁢𝔼[X]/(3⁢b),absentsuperscript𝑒superscript𝜀2𝔼𝑋3𝑏\displaystyle\leq e^{-\varepsilon^{2}\operatorname*{{\mathbb{E}}}[X]/(3b)},≤ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ italic_X ] / ( 3 italic_b ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ∀ε∈(0,1).for-all𝜀01\displaystyle\forall\varepsilon\in(0,1).∀ italic_ε ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) .
Proof.

First, replace every deterministic Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i}italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with multiple random variables that are still deterministic but are all in the range [0,b]0𝑏[0,b][ 0 , italic_b ]. It suffices to prove the deviation bounds for the new summation, because the new variables trivially maintain the independence condition, and the deviation bound does not depend on the number m𝑚mitalic_m of random variables.

Assuming now that every random variable is in the range [0,b]0𝑏[0,b][ 0 , italic_b ], the deviation bounds follow from standard Chernoff bounds [MR95, DP09] by scaling all the random variables by factor 1/b1𝑏1/b1 / italic_b. ∎

6.2 Quasi-Bipartite Graphs

Recall that a quasi-bipartite graph is one where the non-terminals form an independent set; i.e., there are no edges between non-terminals.

Theorem 6.2.

Let G=(V,E,c)𝐺𝑉𝐸𝑐G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) be a quasi-bipartite k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal network, and let 0<ε<180𝜀180<\varepsilon<{\tfrac{1}{8}}0 < italic_ε < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG. Then G𝐺Gitalic_G admits a quality 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε flow-sparsifier G^normal-^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG that has at most O~⁢(k7/ε3)normal-~𝑂superscript𝑘7superscript𝜀3\tilde{O}(k^{7}/\varepsilon^{3})over~ start_ARG italic_O end_ARG ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 7 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) vertices.

Our algorithm is randomized, and is based on importance sampling, as follows. Throughout, let T⊂V𝑇𝑉T\subset Vitalic_T ⊂ italic_V be the set of k𝑘kitalic_k terminals, and assume the graph is connected. We may assume without loss of generality that T𝑇Titalic_T also forms an independent set, by subdividing every edge that connects two terminals (i.e., replacing it with a length 2222 path whose edges have the same capacities as the edge being replaced). We use a parameter M:=C⁢ε−3⁢k5⁢log⁡(1ε⁢log⁡k)assign𝑀𝐶superscript𝜀3superscript𝑘51𝜀𝑘M:=C\varepsilon^{-3}k^{5}\log(\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\log k)italic_M := italic_C italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG roman_log italic_k ), where C>0𝐶0C>0italic_C > 0 is a sufficiently large constant.

  1. 1.

    For every s,t∈T𝑠𝑡𝑇s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T, compute a maximum s⁢t𝑠𝑡stitalic_s italic_t-flow in G𝐺Gitalic_G along 2-hops paths. These path are edge-disjoint and each is identified by its middle vertex, this flow is given by

    Fs⁢t:=∑v∈V∖TFs⁢t,v, where Fs⁢t,v:=min⁡{cs⁢v,cv⁢t}.formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝐹𝑠𝑡subscript𝑣𝑉𝑇subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑣 where assignsubscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑣subscript𝑐𝑠𝑣subscript𝑐𝑣𝑡F_{st}:=\sum_{v\in V\setminus T}F_{st,v},\quad\text{ where }\quad F_{st,v}:=\min\{{c_{sv},c_{vt}}\}.italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , where italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_min { italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } . (6.7)
  2. 2.

    For every non-terminal v∈V∖T𝑣𝑉𝑇v\in V\setminus Titalic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T, define a sampling probability

    p~v:=min⁡{1,pv}, where pv:=M⋅max⁡{Fs⁢t,vFs⁢t:s,t∈T⁢ and ⁢Fs⁢t,v>0}.formulae-sequenceassignsubscript~𝑝𝑣1subscript𝑝𝑣 where assignsubscript𝑝𝑣⋅𝑀:subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑣subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑠𝑡𝑇 and subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑣0\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}:=\min\{{1,p_{v}}\},\quad\text{ where }\quad p_{v}:=M\cdot\max\Big{\{}\frac{F_{st,v}}{F_{st}}:\ s,t\in T\text{ and }F_{st,v}>0\Big{\}}.over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_min { 1 , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } , where italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_M ⋅ roman_max { divide start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG : italic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T and italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 } . (6.8)
  3. 3.

    Sample each non-terminal with probability p~vsubscript~𝑝𝑣\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; more precisely, for each v∈V∖T𝑣𝑉𝑇v\in V\setminus Titalic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T independently at random, with probability p~vsubscript~𝑝𝑣\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT scale the capacity of every edge incident to v𝑣vitalic_v by a factor of 1/p~v1subscript~𝑝𝑣1/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}1 / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and with the remaining probability remove v𝑣vitalic_v from the graph.

  4. 4.

    Report the resulting graph G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG.

For the sake of analysis, it will be convenient to replace step 3 with the following step, which is obviously equivalent in terms of flow.

  1. 3’.

    For each v∈V∖T𝑣𝑉𝑇v\in V\setminus Titalic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T, set independently at random Iv=1subscript𝐼𝑣1I_{v}=1italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 with probability p~vsubscript~𝑝𝑣\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Iv=0subscript𝐼𝑣0I_{v}=0italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 otherwise (with probability 1−p~v1subscript~𝑝𝑣1-\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}1 - over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), and scale the capacities of every edge incident to v𝑣vitalic_v by a factor of Iv/p~vsubscript𝐼𝑣subscript~𝑝𝑣I_{v}/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

We first bound the size of G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG, and then show that with high probability G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG is a flow-sparsifier with quality 1+O⁢(ε)1𝑂𝜀1+O(\varepsilon)1 + italic_O ( italic_ε ).

Lemma 6.3.

With probability at least 0.90.90.90.9, the number of vertices in G^normal-^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG is at most O⁢(k2⁢M)𝑂superscript𝑘2𝑀O(k^{2}M)italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M ).

Proof.

The number of vertices in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG is exactly ∑v∈V∖TIvsubscript𝑣𝑉𝑇subscript𝐼𝑣\sum_{v\in V\setminus T}I_{v}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, hence its expectation is

𝔼[∑v∈V∖TIv]≤∑v∈V∖Tpv≤M⁢∑v∈V∖T∑s,t∈T:Fs⁢t,v>0Fs⁢t,vFs⁢t=M⁢∑s,t∈T:Fs⁢t>0∑v∈V∖TFs⁢t,vFs⁢t≤O⁢(k2⁢M),𝔼subscript𝑣𝑉𝑇subscript𝐼𝑣subscript𝑣𝑉𝑇subscript𝑝𝑣𝑀subscript𝑣𝑉𝑇subscript:𝑠𝑡𝑇subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑣0subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑣subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑀subscript:𝑠𝑡𝑇subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡0subscript𝑣𝑉𝑇subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑣subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑂superscript𝑘2𝑀\operatorname*{{\mathbb{E}}}\Big{[}\sum_{v\in V\setminus T}I_{v}\Big{]}\leq\sum_{v\in V\setminus T}p_{v}\leq M\sum_{v\in V\setminus T}\ \sum_{s,t\in T:\ F_{st,v}>0}\tfrac{F_{st,v}}{F_{st}}=M\sum_{s,t\in T:\ F_{st}>0}\ \sum_{v\in V\setminus T}\tfrac{F_{st,v}}{F_{st}}\leq O(k^{2}M),blackboard_E [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ≤ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_M ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T : italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = italic_M ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T : italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ≤ italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M ) ,

where the second inequality simply bounds the maximum in (6.8) with a summation, and the last inequality follows from (6.7). The lemma then follows by applying Markov’s inequality. ∎

Lemma 6.4.

Let d𝑑ditalic_d range over all nonzero demand vectors in ℝ+(T2)superscriptsubscriptℝbinomial𝑇2{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then

Pr⁡[∀d≠0,λG^⁢(d)≥(1−3⁢ε)⁢λG⁢(d)]≥0.9,Prfor-all𝑑0subscript𝜆^𝐺𝑑13𝜀subscript𝜆𝐺𝑑0.9\displaystyle\Pr\Big{[}\forall d\neq 0,\ \lambda_{\smash{\widehat{G}}}(d)\geq(1-3\varepsilon)\lambda_{G}(d)\Big{]}\geq 0.9,roman_Pr [ ∀ italic_d ≠ 0 , italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_d ) ≥ ( 1 - 3 italic_ε ) italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_d ) ] ≥ 0.9 , (6.9)
Pr⁡[∀d≠0,λG^⁢(d)≤(1+4⁢ε)⁢λG⁢(d)]≥0.9.Prfor-all𝑑0subscript𝜆^𝐺𝑑14𝜀subscript𝜆𝐺𝑑0.9\displaystyle\Pr\Big{[}\forall d\neq 0,\ \lambda_{\smash{\widehat{G}}}(d)\leq(1+4\varepsilon)\lambda_{G}(d)\Big{]}\geq 0.9.roman_Pr [ ∀ italic_d ≠ 0 , italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_d ) ≤ ( 1 + 4 italic_ε ) italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_d ) ] ≥ 0.9 . (6.10)

Observe that Theorem 6.2 follows immediately from Lemmas 6.3 and 6.4. It remains to prove the latter lemma, and we do this next. We remark that the 0.90.90.90.9 probabilities above are arbitrary, and can be easily improved to be 1−o⁢(1)1𝑜11-o(1)1 - italic_o ( 1 ).

6.2.1 Proving the Lower Bound (6.9)

The plan for proving (6.9) is to discretize the set of all demand vectors, show a deviation bound for each of these demands (separately), and then apply a union bound. We will thus need the next lemma, which shows that for every fixed demand vector 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d that (satisfies some technical conditions and) is feasible in G𝐺Gitalic_G, with high probability a slightly scaled demand (1−ε)⁢𝐝1𝜀𝐝(1-\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}( 1 - italic_ε ) bold_d is feasible in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG.

Given a demand vector 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d, the problem of concurrent flow along 2-hop paths can be written as linear program (LP3). It has variables fvs⁢tsubscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑠𝑡𝑣f^{st}_{v}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT representing flow along a path s−v−t𝑠𝑣𝑡s-v-titalic_s - italic_v - italic_t, for the commodity s,t∈T𝑠𝑡𝑇s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T and intermediate non-terminal v∈V∖T𝑣𝑉𝑇v\in V\setminus Titalic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T. Let NG⁢(w)subscript𝑁𝐺𝑤N_{G}(w)italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_w ) denote the set of neighbors of vertex w𝑤witalic_w in the graph G𝐺Gitalic_G.

maxλs.t.∑v∈NG⁢(s)∩NG⁢(t)fvs⁢t≥ds⁢t⁢λ∀{s,t}∈(T2)∑s∈NG⁢(v)∖{t}fvs⁢t≤cv⁢t∀(v,t)∈Efvs⁢t≥0∀{s,t}∈(T2),∀v∈NG⁢(s)∩NG⁢(t).\begin{array}[]{llll}\max&\lambda\\ \operatorname{s.t.}&\sum_{v\in N_{G}(s)\cap end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL roman_s . roman_t . end_CELL start_CELL ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) ∩ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ Lemma 6.5.

Fix η>0𝜂0\eta>0italic_η > 0 and 𝐝∈ℝ+(T2)∖{0}𝐝superscriptsubscriptℝbinomial𝑇20\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}\setminus\{0\}bold_d ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ { 0 } such that (i) demand 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d can be satisfied in G𝐺Gitalic_G by flow along 2222-hop paths, and (ii) every nonzero coordinate ds⁢tsubscript𝑑𝑠𝑡d_{st}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d is a power of 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε in the range [η⁢Fs⁢t,Fs⁢t]𝜂subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡[\eta F_{st},F_{st}][ italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ].333The range upper bound Fs⁢tsubscript𝐹𝑠𝑡F_{st}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT follows anyway from requirement (i). We also remark that the requirement about power of 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε is not necessary for the lemma’s proof, but for later use, it is convenient to include it here. Then

Pr⁡[demand (1−ε)⁢𝐝 admits a flow in G^ along 2-hop paths]≥1−(k2)⁢e−ε2⁢η⁢M/2.Prdemand (1−ε)⁢𝐝 admits a flow in G^ along 2-hop paths1binomial𝑘2superscript𝑒superscript𝜀2𝜂𝑀2\Pr[\text{demand $(1-\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}$ admits a flow in ${\smash{\widehat{G}}}$ along $2$-hop paths}]\geq 1-\textstyle\binom{k}{2}\,e^{-\varepsilon^{2}\eta M/2}.roman_Pr [ demand ( 1 - italic_ε ) bold_d admits a flow in over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG along 2 -hop paths ] ≥ 1 - ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η italic_M / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .
Proof.

Given demand vector 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d, fix a flow f𝑓fitalic_f that satisfies it in G𝐺Gitalic_G along 2222-hop paths. Thus, fs⁢t=ds⁢t≥η⁢Fs⁢tsubscript𝑓𝑠𝑡subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡𝜂subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡f_{st}=d_{st}\geq\eta F_{st}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG be the graph constructed using the above randomized procedure, and recall that random variable Ivsubscript𝐼𝑣I_{v}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is an indicator for the event that non-terminal v𝑣vitalic_v is sampled in step 3’, which happens independently with probability p~vsubscript~𝑝𝑣\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Define a flow f^^𝑓{\smash{\widehat{f}}}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG in the natural way: scale every flow-path in f𝑓fitalic_f whose intermediate vertex is v∈V∖T𝑣𝑉𝑇v\in V\setminus Titalic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T by the corresponding Iv/p~vsubscript𝐼𝑣subscript~𝑝𝑣I_{v}/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The resulting flow f^^𝑓{\smash{\widehat{f}}}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG is indeed feasible in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG along 2222-hop paths. It remains to prove that with high probability this flow f^^𝑓{\smash{\widehat{f}}}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG routes at least (i.e., a demand that dominates) (1−ε)⁢𝐝1𝜀𝐝(1-\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}( 1 - italic_ε ) bold_d.

Fix a demand pair (commodity) s,t∈T𝑠𝑡𝑇s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T. The amount of flow shipped by f^^𝑓{\smash{\widehat{f}}}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG along the path s−v−t𝑠𝑣𝑡s-v-titalic_s - italic_v - italic_t is f^vs⁢t:=fvs⁢t⁢Iv/p~vassignsubscriptsuperscript^𝑓𝑠𝑡𝑣subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑠𝑡𝑣subscript𝐼𝑣subscript~𝑝𝑣{\smash{\widehat{f}}}^{st}_{v}:=f^{st}_{v}I_{v}/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and the total amount shipped by f^^𝑓{\smash{\widehat{f}}}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG between s𝑠sitalic_s and t𝑡titalic_t is

f^s⁢t:=∑v∈NG⁢(s)∩NG⁢(t)f^vs⁢t=∑v∈NG⁢(s)∩NG⁢(t)fvs⁢t⋅Iv/p~v.assignsuperscript^𝑓𝑠𝑡subscript𝑣subscript𝑁𝐺𝑠subscript𝑁𝐺𝑡subscriptsuperscript^𝑓𝑠𝑡𝑣subscript𝑣subscript𝑁𝐺𝑠subscript𝑁𝐺𝑡⋅subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑠𝑡𝑣subscript𝐼𝑣subscript~𝑝𝑣{\smash{\widehat{f}}}^{st}:=\sum_{v\in N_{G}(s)\cap N_{G}(t)}{\smash{\widehat{f}}}^{st}_{v}=\sum_{v\in N_{G}(s)\cap N_{G}(t)}f^{st}_{v}\cdot I_{v}/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}.over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) ∩ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) ∩ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (6.11)

By linearity of expectation, 𝔼[f^s⁢t]=∑vfvs⁢t⋅𝔼[Iv]/p~v=∑vfvs⁢t=fs⁢t𝔼superscript^𝑓𝑠𝑡subscript𝑣⋅subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑠𝑡𝑣𝔼subscript𝐼𝑣subscript~𝑝𝑣subscript𝑣subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑠𝑡𝑣superscript𝑓𝑠𝑡\operatorname*{{\mathbb{E}}}[{\smash{\widehat{f}}}^{st}]=\sum_{v}f^{st}_{v}\cdot\operatorname*{{\mathbb{E}}}[I_{v}]/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}=\sum_{v}f^{st}_{v}=f^{st}blackboard_E [ over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ blackboard_E [ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Furthermore, we wrote f^s⁢tsuperscript^𝑓𝑠𝑡{\smash{\widehat{f}}}^{st}over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in (6.11) as the sum of independent non-negative random variables, where each of summand is either deterministic (when p~v=1subscript~𝑝𝑣1\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}=1over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1), or (when p~v=pv<1subscript~𝑝𝑣subscript𝑝𝑣1\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}=p_{v}<1over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1) can be bounded using (6.8) by

fvs⁢t⋅Iv/p~v≤fvs⁢t/p~v≤Fs⁢t,v/pv≤Fs⁢t/M.⋅subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑠𝑡𝑣subscript𝐼𝑣subscript~𝑝𝑣subscriptsuperscript𝑓𝑠𝑡𝑣subscript~𝑝𝑣subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑣subscript𝑝𝑣subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑀f^{st}_{v}\cdot I_{v}/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}\leq f^{st}_{v}/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}\leq F_{st,v}/p_{v}\leq F_{st}/M.italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_M .

Applying Theorem 6.1, we obtain, as required,

Pr⁡[f^s⁢t≤(1−ε)⁢fs⁢t]≤e−ε2⁢fs⁢t/(2⁢Fs⁢t/M)≤e−ε2⁢η⁢M/2.Prsuperscript^𝑓𝑠𝑡1𝜀superscript𝑓𝑠𝑡superscript𝑒superscript𝜀2superscript𝑓𝑠𝑡2subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑀superscript𝑒superscript𝜀2𝜂𝑀2\Pr[{\smash{\widehat{f}}}^{st}\leq(1-\varepsilon)f^{st}]\leq e^{-\varepsilon^{2}f^{st}/(2F_{st}/M)}\leq e^{-\varepsilon^{2}\eta M/2}.roman_Pr [ over^ start_ARG italic_f end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ ( 1 - italic_ε ) italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( 2 italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_M ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η italic_M / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

A straightforward union bound over the (k2)binomial𝑘2\binom{k}{2}( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) choices of s,t𝑠𝑡s,titalic_s , italic_t completes the proof of Lemma 6.5. ∎

We proceed now to prove (6.9) using Lemma 6.5.

Proof of Eqn. (6.9).

Set η:=ε/k2assign𝜂𝜀superscript𝑘2\eta:=\varepsilon/k^{2}italic_η := italic_ε / italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and define
