Then clearly |𝒟L⁢B|≤(2+log1+ε⁡1η)(k2)≤(1ε⁢log⁡kε)k2≤(log⁡kε)O⁢(k2).superscript𝒟𝐿𝐵superscript2subscript1𝜀1𝜂binomial𝑘2superscript1𝜀𝑘𝜀superscript𝑘2superscript𝑘𝜀𝑂superscript𝑘2\lvert{\mathcal{D}}^{LB}\rvert\leq\Big{(}2+\log_{1+\varepsilon}\tfrac{1}{\eta}\Big{)}^{\binom{k}{2}}\leq\Big{(}\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\log\tfrac{k}{\varepsilon}\Big{)}^{k^{2}}\leq\Big{(}\tfrac{\log k}{\varepsilon}\Big{)}^{O(k^{2})}.| caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ≤ ( 2 + roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 + italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_η end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ ( divide start_ARG roman_log italic_k end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . Applying Lemma 6.5 to each d∈𝒟L⁢B𝑑superscript𝒟𝐿𝐵d\in{\mathcal{D}}^{LB}italic_d ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and using a union bound, we get that with probability at least 1−|𝒟L⁢B|⋅(k2)⁢e−ε2⁢η⁢M/2≥0.91⋅superscript𝒟𝐿𝐵binomial𝑘2superscript𝑒superscript𝜀2𝜂𝑀20.91-\lvert{\mathcal{D}}^{LB}\rvert\cdot\binom{k}{2}e^{-\varepsilon^{2}\eta M/2}\geq 0.91 - | caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ⋅ ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η italic_M / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ 0.9, for every d∈𝒟L⁢B𝑑superscript𝒟𝐿𝐵d\in{\mathcal{D}}^{LB}italic_d ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT we have that (1−ε)⁢d1𝜀𝑑(1-\varepsilon)d( 1 - italic_ε ) italic_d can be satisfied in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG by 2-hop flow paths. We assume henceforth this high-probability event indeed occurs, and show how this assumption implies the event described in (6.9).

To this end, fix a demand vector 𝐝∈ℝ+(T2)∖{0}𝐝superscriptsubscriptℝbinomial𝑇20\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}\setminus\{0\}bold_d ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ { 0 }, and let us prove that λG^⁢(𝐝)≥(1−3⁢ε)⁢λG⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆^𝐺𝐝13𝜀subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda_{\smash{\widehat{G}}}(\mathbf{d})\geq(1-3\varepsilon)\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≥ ( 1 - 3 italic_ε ) italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). We can make two simplifying assumptions about the demand vector 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d, both of which are without loss of generality. Firstly, we assume that λG⁢(𝐝)≥1subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝1\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\geq 1italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≥ 1, i.e., demand 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d can be satisfied in G𝐺Gitalic_G, because event in (6.9) is invariant under scaling of 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d. Secondly, we assume that 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d can be satisfied in G𝐺Gitalic_G by 2222-hop flow paths; if each such demand 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d can be satisfied in G^^𝐺\widehat{G}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG with congestion at most 1/(1−3⁢ε)113𝜀1/(1-3\varepsilon)1 / ( 1 - 3 italic_ε ), then Lemma 5.1 implies that every demand satisfiable in G𝐺Gitalic_G (without the restriction to 2222-hop paths) can be satisfied in G^^𝐺\widehat{G}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG with the same congestion.

So consider a demand 𝐝∈ℝ+(T2)∖{0}𝐝superscriptsubscriptℝbinomial𝑇20\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}\setminus\{0\}bold_d ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ { 0 }, such that λG⁢(𝐝)=1subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝1\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})=1italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) = 1 and 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d can be satisfied in G𝐺Gitalic_G by 2-hop flow paths. Let 𝐝−superscript𝐝\mathbf{d}^{-}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the vector obtained from 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d by zeroing every coordinate ds⁢tsubscript𝑑𝑠𝑡d_{st}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that is smaller than 2⁢η⁢Fs⁢t2𝜂subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡2\eta\,F_{st}2 italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This vector can be written as 𝐝−=𝐝−∑s⁢tαs⁢t⁢𝐞s⁢tsuperscript𝐝𝐝subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝛼𝑠𝑡subscript𝐞𝑠𝑡\mathbf{d}^{-}=\mathbf{d}-\sum_{st}\alpha_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_d - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where 𝐞s⁢t∈ℝ+(T2)subscript𝐞𝑠𝑡superscriptsubscriptℝbinomial𝑇2\mathbf{e}_{st}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the standard basis vector for pair (s,t)𝑠𝑡(s,t)( italic_s , italic_t ), and αs⁢t:=ds⁢tassignsubscript𝛼𝑠𝑡subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡\alpha_{st}:=d_{st}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if this value is smaller than 2⁢η⁢Fs⁢t2𝜂subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡2\eta F_{st}2 italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and zero otherwise. Rounding each nonzero coordinate of 𝐝−superscript𝐝\mathbf{d}^{-}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT down to the next power of 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε yields a demand vector 𝐝L⁢B∈𝒟L⁢Bsuperscript𝐝𝐿𝐵superscript𝒟𝐿𝐵\mathbf{d}^{LB}\in{\mathcal{D}}^{LB}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and thus by our earlier assumption, (1−ε)⁢𝐝L⁢B≥1−ε1+ε⁢𝐝−1𝜀superscript𝐝𝐿𝐵1𝜀1𝜀superscript𝐝(1-\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}^{LB}\geq\frac{1-\varepsilon}{1+\varepsilon}\mathbf{d}^{-}( 1 - italic_ε ) bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ divide start_ARG 1 - italic_ε end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_ε end_ARG bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be satisfied in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG by 2-hop flow paths. For each s,t∈T𝑠𝑡𝑇s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T, consider the demand vector Fs⁢t⁢𝐞s⁢tsubscript𝐹𝑠𝑡subscript𝐞𝑠𝑡F_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. By rounding its single nonzero coordinate down to the next power of 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε, we obtain a vector in 𝒟L⁢Bsuperscript𝒟𝐿𝐵{\mathcal{D}}^{LB}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Hence we conclude that 1−ε1+ε⁢Fs⁢t⁢𝐞s⁢t1𝜀1𝜀subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡subscript𝐞𝑠𝑡\frac{1-\varepsilon}{1+\varepsilon}F_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}divide start_ARG 1 - italic_ε end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_ε end_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be satisfied in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG by 2-hop flow paths. The set of demands satisfiable by 2-hop flow paths in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG is clearly convex, so taking a combination of such demand vectors with coefficients that add up to (1−ε)+∑s,t∈Tαs⁢tFs⁢t≤(1−ε)+k22⋅2⁢η=11𝜀subscript𝑠𝑡𝑇subscript𝛼𝑠𝑡subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡1𝜀⋅superscript𝑘222𝜂1(1-\varepsilon)+\sum_{s,t\in T}\frac{\alpha_{st}}{F_{st}}\leq(1-\varepsilon)+\tfrac{k^{2}}{2}\cdot 2\eta=1( 1 - italic_ε ) + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ≤ ( 1 - italic_ε ) + divide start_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ⋅ 2 italic_η = 1, we conclude that

(1−ε)⋅1−ε1+ε⁢𝐝−+∑s⁢tαs⁢tFs⁢t⋅1−ε1+ε⁢Fs⁢t⁢𝐞s⁢t≥(1−ε)21+ε⁢[𝐝−+∑s⁢tαs⁢t⁢𝐞s⁢t]≥(1−3⁢ε)⁢𝐝⋅1𝜀1𝜀1𝜀superscript𝐝subscript𝑠𝑡⋅subscript𝛼𝑠𝑡subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡1𝜀1𝜀subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡subscript𝐞𝑠𝑡superscript1𝜀21𝜀delimited-[]superscript𝐝subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝛼𝑠𝑡subscript𝐞𝑠𝑡13𝜀𝐝(1-\varepsilon)\cdot\tfrac{1-\varepsilon}{1+\varepsilon}\,\mathbf{d}^{-}+\sum_{st}\frac{\alpha_{st}}{F_{st}}\cdot\tfrac{1-\varepsilon}{1+\varepsilon}F_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}\geq\tfrac{(1-\varepsilon)^{2}}{1+\varepsilon}\Big{[}\mathbf{d}^{-}+\sum_{st}\alpha_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}\Big{]}\geq(1-3\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}( 1 - italic_ε ) ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 - italic_ε end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_ε end_ARG bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 - italic_ε end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_ε end_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ divide start_ARG ( 1 - italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_ε end_ARG [ bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ≥ ( 1 - 3 italic_ε ) bold_d

can be satisfied in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG. This implies that λG^⁢(𝐝)≥1−3⁢εsubscript𝜆^𝐺𝐝13𝜀\lambda_{\smash{\widehat{G}}}(\mathbf{d})\geq 1-3\varepsilonitalic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≥ 1 - 3 italic_ε, which completes the proof of (6.9). ∎

6.2.2 Proving the Upper Bound (6.10)

The plan for proving (6.10) is similar, i.e., to prove a deviation bound for every demand in a small discrete set and then apply a union bound. However, we need to bound the deviation in the opposite direction, and thus use the LP that is dual to flow (which can be viewed as “fractional cut”). We will need a statement of the following form: for every fixed demand vector 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d that (satisfies some technical conditions and) is not feasible in G𝐺Gitalic_G, with high probability the slightly further scaled-up demand (1+ε)⁢𝐝1𝜀𝐝(1+\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}( 1 + italic_ε ) bold_d is not feasible in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG. The next lemma proves such a statement, except that it considers only flow along 2222-hop paths, and that 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d is scaled by another 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε factor.

Lemma 6.6.

Fix η>0𝜂0\eta>0italic_η > 0 and let 𝐝∈ℝ+(T2)∖{0}𝐝superscriptsubscriptℝbinomial𝑇20\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}\setminus\{0\}bold_d ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ { 0 } be a demand vector such that (i) demand (1+ε)⁢𝐝1𝜀𝐝(1+\varepsilon)\mathbf{d}( 1 + italic_ε ) bold_d cannot be satisfied in G𝐺Gitalic_G by flow along 2-hop paths, and (ii) every nonzero coordinate ds⁢tsubscript𝑑𝑠𝑡d_{st}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a power of 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε in the range [η⁢Fs⁢t,Fs⁢t]𝜂subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡[\eta F_{st},F_{st}][ italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ].444Again, the power of 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε requirement is not really necessary to prove the lemma, and will be needed only later. But by introducing it right now, we avoid having two versions of condition (ii). Then

Pr⁡[demand (1+ε)2⁢𝐝 admits a flow in G^ along 2-hop flow paths]≤e−ε2⁢η⁢M/k2.Prdemand (1+ε)2⁢𝐝 admits a flow in G^ along 2-hop flow pathssuperscript𝑒superscript𝜀2𝜂𝑀superscript𝑘2\Pr[\text{demand $(1+\varepsilon)^{2}\mathbf{d}$ admits a flow in ${\smash{\widehat{G}}}$ along $2$-hop flow paths}]\leq e^{-\varepsilon^{2}\eta M/k^{2}}.roman_Pr [ demand ( 1 + italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_d admits a flow in over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG along 2 -hop flow paths ] ≤ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η italic_M / italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Our proof of Lemma 6.6 uses LP duality for flows along 2-hop paths, which we discuss first. Recall that for a given demand vector 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d, our linear program (LP3) describes the problem of maximizing concurrent flow along 2222-hop paths. Its dual LP, written below, has variables ℓesubscriptℓ𝑒\ell_{e}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT representing the lengths of edges e∈E𝑒𝐸e\in Eitalic_e ∈ italic_E, and variables ys⁢tsubscript𝑦𝑠𝑡y_{st}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT representing the distance (along the shortest 2-hop path) between s,t∈T𝑠𝑡𝑇s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T.

min∑v∈V∖T∑t∈NG⁢(v)cv⁢t⁢ℓv⁢ts.t.∑s,t∈(T2)ds⁢t⁢ys⁢t≥1ys⁢t≤ℓs⁢v+ℓv⁢t∀{s,t}∈(T2),∀v∈NG⁢(s)∩NG⁢(t)ℓe≥0∀e∈Eys⁢t≥0∀{s,t}∈(T2).\begin{array}[]{llll}\min&\sum_{v\in V\setminus T}\sum_{t\in N_{G}(v)}c_{vt}\ell_{vt}\\ \operatorname{s.t.}&\sum_{{s,t}\in\tbinom{T}{2}}d_{st}y_{st}\geq 1\\ &y_{st}\leq\ell_{sv}+\ell_{vt}&\forall\{s,t\}\in\tbinom{T}{2},\ \forall v\in N_{G}(s)\cap N_{G}(t)\\ &\ell_{e}\geq 0&\forall e\in E\\ &y_{st}\geq 0&\forall\{s,t\}\in\tbinom{T}{2}.\end{array}start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL roman_min end_CELL start_CELL ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL roman_s . roman_t . end_CELL start_CELL ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_t ∈ ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 1 end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL ∀ { italic_s , italic_t } ∈ ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) , ∀ italic_v ∈ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s ) ∩ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 end_CELL start_CELL ∀ italic_e ∈ italic_E end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 end_CELL start_CELL ∀ { italic_s , italic_t } ∈ ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) . end_CELL start_CELL end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY (LP4)

By strong LP duality, (LP4) has the same value as (LP3) (assuming the primal LP is feasible and bounded, which happens if, for every demand ds⁢t>0subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡0d_{st}>0italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0, there is a non-terminal v∈V∖T𝑣𝑉𝑇v\in V\setminus Titalic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T connected to both s𝑠sitalic_s and t𝑡titalic_t with edges of positive capacity).

We can use these two LPs to reinterpret our algorithm’s sampling probabilities, namely the values Fs⁢tsubscript𝐹𝑠𝑡F_{st}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and pvsubscript𝑝𝑣p_{v}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT computed in (6.7) and (6.8). (These will be needed in the proof of Lemma 6.6.) Consider a demand vector 𝐝=𝐞s′⁢t′𝐝subscript𝐞superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′\mathbf{d}=\mathbf{e}_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}bold_d = bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for some fixed s′,t′∈Tsuperscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′𝑇s^{\prime},t^{\prime}\in Titalic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_T, i.e., a unit demand for commodity {s′,t′}superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′\{s^{\prime},t^{\prime}\}{ italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } and zero otherwise. We shall assume there is v∈V∖T𝑣𝑉𝑇v\in V\setminus Titalic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T that is connected to both s′superscript𝑠′s^{\prime}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with edges of positive capacity. The next two lemmas analyze the optimal solutions to the two LPs above for this demand vector.

Lemma 6.7.

Fix a demand vector 𝐝=𝐞s′⁢t′𝐝subscript𝐞superscript𝑠normal-′superscript𝑡normal-′\mathbf{d}=\mathbf{e}_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}bold_d = bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then LP (LP3) has an optimal solution with fvs′⁢t′:=Fs′⁢t′,vassignsubscriptsuperscript𝑓superscript𝑠normal-′superscript𝑡normal-′𝑣subscript𝐹superscript𝑠normal-′superscript𝑡normal-′𝑣f^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}_{v}:=F_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime},v}italic_f start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, all other flows are 00, and λ:=Fs′⁢t′assign𝜆subscript𝐹superscript𝑠normal-′superscript𝑡normal-′\lambda:=F_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}italic_λ := italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proof.

Immediate from the fact that 2222-hop flow paths are edge-disjoint, as explained in (6.7). ∎

Lemma 6.8.

Fix a demand vector 𝐝=𝐞s′⁢t′𝐝subscript𝐞superscript𝑠normal-′superscript𝑡normal-′\mathbf{d}=\mathbf{e}_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}bold_d = bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then LP (LP4) has an optimal solution {ℓes′⁢t′}e∈E,{ys⁢ts′⁢t′}s,t∈Tsubscriptsubscriptsuperscriptnormal-ℓsuperscript𝑠normal-′superscript𝑡normal-′𝑒𝑒𝐸subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑦superscript𝑠normal-′superscript𝑡normal-′𝑠𝑡𝑠𝑡𝑇\{\ell^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}_{e}\}_{e\in E},\{y^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}_{st}\}_{s,t\in T}{ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e ∈ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where every non-terminal v∈V∖T𝑣𝑉𝑇v\in V\setminus Titalic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T contributes to the objective ∑t∈NG⁢(v)cv⁢t⁢ℓv⁢ts′⁢t′=Fs′⁢t′,vsubscript𝑡subscript𝑁𝐺𝑣subscript𝑐𝑣𝑡subscriptsuperscriptnormal-ℓsuperscript𝑠normal-′superscript𝑡normal-′𝑣𝑡subscript𝐹superscript𝑠normal-′superscript𝑡normal-′𝑣\sum_{t\in N_{G}(v)}c_{vt}\ell^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}_{vt}=F_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime},v}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Proof.

Let us construct a solution to LP (LP4), denoted {ℓe},{ys⁢t}subscriptℓ𝑒subscript𝑦𝑠𝑡\{\ell_{e}\},\{y_{st}\}{ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } , { italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } (we omit the superscript in this proof to simplify notation). Let all edges e𝑒eitalic_e not incident to either s′superscript𝑠′s^{\prime}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT or t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT have length ℓe=0subscriptℓ𝑒0\ell_{e}=0roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, and let ys⁢t=0subscript𝑦𝑠𝑡0y_{st}=0italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 for all {s,t}≠{s′,t′}𝑠𝑡superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′\{s,t\}\neq\{s^{\prime},t^{\prime}\}{ italic_s , italic_t } ≠ { italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }. Let ys′⁢t′=1subscript𝑦superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′1y_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}=1italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 and for every v∈NG⁢(s′)∩NG⁢(t′)𝑣subscript𝑁𝐺superscript𝑠′subscript𝑁𝐺superscript𝑡′v\in N_{G}(s^{\prime})\cap N_{G}(t^{\prime})italic_v ∈ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∩ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), let one of the two edges (s′,v)superscript𝑠′𝑣(s^{\prime},v)( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v ) and (v,t′)𝑣superscript𝑡′(v,t^{\prime})( italic_v , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), namely the one of cheaper cost have length 1111, and the other one have length 00 (breaking ties arbitrarily). It is easy to verify that this is a feasible solution, and every non-terminal v𝑣vitalic_v contributes to the objective ∑t∈NG⁢(v)cv⁢t⁢ℓv⁢t=∑t∈{s′,t′}cv⁢t⁢ℓv⁢t=min⁡{cs′⁢v,cv⁢t′}=Fs′⁢t′,vsubscript𝑡subscript𝑁𝐺𝑣subscript𝑐𝑣𝑡subscriptℓ𝑣𝑡subscript𝑡superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′subscript𝑐𝑣𝑡subscriptℓ𝑣𝑡subscript𝑐superscript𝑠′𝑣subscript𝑐𝑣superscript𝑡′subscript𝐹superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′𝑣\sum_{t\in N_{G}(v)}c_{vt}\ell_{vt}=\sum_{t\in\{s^{\prime},t^{\prime}\}}c_{vt}\ell_{vt}=\min\{{c_{s^{\prime}v},c_{vt^{\prime}}}\}=F_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime},v}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ { italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min { italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } = italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Furthermore, the value of this solution is ∑v∈V∖TFs′⁢t′,v=Fs′⁢t′subscript𝑣𝑉𝑇subscript𝐹superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′𝑣subscript𝐹superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′\sum_{v\in V\setminus T}F_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime},v}=F_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Observing that the optimal LP value must be at least Fs′⁢t′subscript𝐹superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′F_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT because of weak LP duality and Lemma 6.7, we conclude that the constructed solution is indeed an optimal one. ∎

Proof of Lemma 6.6.

Fix η>0𝜂0\eta>0italic_η > 0 and let 𝐝∈ℝ+(T2)∖{0}𝐝superscriptsubscriptℝbinomial𝑇20\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}\setminus\{0\}bold_d ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ { 0 } be a demand vector satisfying the two requirements. We may assume that

∀s,t∈T,if ds⁢t>0 then Fs⁢t>0,formulae-sequencefor-all𝑠𝑡𝑇if ds⁢t>0 then Fs⁢t>0\forall s,t\in T,\ \text{if $d_{st}>0$ then $F_{st}>0$},∀ italic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T , if italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 then italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 , (6.12)

as otherwise the demand cannot be satisfied and the lemma’s assertion holds trivially (the probability is 00). By requirement (i), the value of LP (LP3), and thus also of LP (LP4), is smaller than 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε. Fix an optimal solution {ℓ→,y→}→ℓ→𝑦\{\vec{\ell},\vec{y}\}{ over→ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG , over→ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG } for the latter LP; we can then write its value as

z:=∑e∈Ece⁢ℓe=∑v∈V∖T∑t∈NG⁢(v)cv⁢t⁢ℓv⁢t<1+ε.assign𝑧subscript𝑒𝐸subscript𝑐𝑒subscriptℓ𝑒subscript𝑣𝑉𝑇subscript𝑡subscript𝑁𝐺𝑣subscript𝑐𝑣𝑡subscriptℓ𝑣𝑡1𝜀z:=\sum_{e\in E}c_{e}\ell_{e}=\sum_{v\in V\setminus T}\sum_{t\in N_{G}(v)}c_{vt}\ell_{vt}<1+\varepsilon.italic_z := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e ∈ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1 + italic_ε .

In addition, the first constraint is tight, i.e., ∑s⁢tds⁢t⁢ys⁢t=1subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡subscript𝑦𝑠𝑡1\sum_{st}d_{st}y_{st}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, as otherwise we can scale the entire solution to obtain a strictly better one. (This holds for every optimal solution for every demand vector.) Now consider the same values {ℓe},{ys⁢t}subscriptℓ𝑒subscript𝑦𝑠𝑡\{\ell_{e}\},\{y_{st}\}{ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } , { italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } as the LP solution for the graph G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG and same demand 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d, where we use the viewpoint of step 3’ according to which G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG has the same edges as G𝐺Gitalic_G but the capacities of edges incident to every v∈V∖T𝑣𝑉𝑇v\in V\setminus Titalic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T are scaled by Iv/p~vsubscript𝐼𝑣subscript~𝑝𝑣I_{v}/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This LP solution is obviously feasible also for G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG, and what remains is to prove a deviation bound on its objective value

Z^:=∑v∈V∖T∑t∈NG⁢(v)(cv⁢t⁢Iv/p~v)⁢ℓv⁢t=∑v∈V∖T(Iv/p~v)⁢∑t∈NG⁢(v)cv⁢t⁢ℓv⁢t.assign^𝑍subscript𝑣𝑉𝑇subscript𝑡subscript𝑁𝐺𝑣subscript𝑐𝑣𝑡subscript𝐼𝑣subscript~𝑝𝑣subscriptℓ𝑣𝑡subscript𝑣𝑉𝑇subscript𝐼𝑣subscript~𝑝𝑣subscript𝑡subscript𝑁𝐺𝑣subscript𝑐𝑣𝑡subscriptℓ𝑣𝑡\widehat{Z}:=\sum_{v\in V\setminus T}\sum_{t\in N_{G}(v)}(c_{vt}I_{v}/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v})\ell_{vt}=\sum_{v\in V\setminus T}(I_{v}/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v})\sum_{t\in N_{G}(v)}c_{vt}\ell_{vt}.over^ start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (6.13)

By construction 𝔼[Iv/p~v]=1𝔼subscript𝐼𝑣subscript~𝑝𝑣1\operatorname*{{\mathbb{E}}}[I_{v}/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}]=1blackboard_E [ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = 1, hence 𝔼[Z^]=z<1+ε𝔼^𝑍𝑧1𝜀\operatorname*{{\mathbb{E}}}[\widehat{Z}]=z<1+\varepsilonblackboard_E [ over^ start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG ] = italic_z < 1 + italic_ε. To prove a deviation bound on Z^^𝑍\widehat{Z}over^ start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG using concentration from Theorem 6.1, we need an upper bound on each term of the summation over v𝑣vitalic_v’s. For this, we analyze how each sampling probabilities p~vsubscript~𝑝𝑣\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (which are set without “knowing” the demand vector 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d) relate to the potential contributions ∑t∈NG⁢(v)cv⁢t⁢ℓv⁢tsubscript𝑡subscript𝑁𝐺𝑣subscript𝑐𝑣𝑡subscriptℓ𝑣𝑡\sum_{t\in N_{G}(v)}c_{vt}\ell_{vt}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (which depend on 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d). The key insight is captured by the following claim.

Claim 6.9.

For every non-terminal v∈V∖T𝑣𝑉𝑇v\in V\setminus Titalic_v ∈ italic_V ∖ italic_T with p~v<1subscriptnormal-~𝑝𝑣1\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}<1over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1, its maximum contribution to z𝑧zitalic_z is ∑t∈NG⁢(v)cv⁢t⁢ℓv⁢t≤p~v⋅k2/(2⁢η⁢M)subscript𝑡subscript𝑁𝐺𝑣subscript𝑐𝑣𝑡subscriptnormal-ℓ𝑣𝑡normal-⋅subscriptnormal-~𝑝𝑣superscript𝑘22𝜂𝑀\sum_{t\in N_{G}(v)}c_{vt}\ell_{vt}\leq\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}\cdot k^{2}/(2\eta M)∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t ∈ italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_v ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⋅ italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( 2 italic_η italic_M ).

Proof of Claim 6.9.

Fix v𝑣vitalic_v with p~v<1subscript~𝑝𝑣1\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}<1over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1, which implies pv=p~v<1subscript𝑝𝑣subscript~𝑝𝑣1p_{v}=\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{v}<1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 1. The plan is to modify the optimal LP solution {ℓe},{ys⁢t}subscriptℓ𝑒subscript𝑦𝑠𝑡\{\ell_{e}\},\{y_{st}\}{ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } , { italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }, by assigning new lengths to just the edges incident to v𝑣vitalic_v, and keeping the old length assignments for the other edges. Once we verify that the modified solution is feasible, this modified solution will give us an upper bound on v𝑣vitalic_v’s contribution to the objective in the optimal LP solution.

We set the new edge lengths {ℓ~e}subscript~ℓ𝑒\{\widetilde{\ell}_{e}\}{ over~ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } as follows. Consider a demand {s′,t′}∈(T2)superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′binomial𝑇2\{s^{\prime},t^{\prime}\}\in\binom{T}{2}{ italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } ∈ ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) such that ds′⁢t′>0subscript𝑑superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′0d_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}>0italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0, which implies ds′⁢t′∈[η⁢Fs′⁢t′,Fs′⁢t′]subscript𝑑superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′𝜂subscript𝐹superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′subscript𝐹superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′d_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}\in[\eta F_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}},F_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}]italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]; moreover, Fs′⁢t′>0subscript𝐹superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′0F_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}>0italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0, by (6.12). Let {ℓes′⁢t′}e∈E,{ys⁢ts′⁢t′}s,t∈Tsubscriptsubscriptsuperscriptℓsuperscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′𝑒𝑒𝐸subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑦superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′𝑠𝑡𝑠𝑡𝑇\{\ell^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}_{e}\}_{e\in E},\{y^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}_{st}\}_{s,t\in T}{ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e ∈ italic_E end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , { italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be an optimal LP solution for the single-commodity demand 𝐞s′⁢t′subscript𝐞superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′\mathbf{e}_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, as computed in Lemma 6.8. Now scale the edge lengths in this solution by 1/(η⁢Fs′⁢t′)1𝜂subscript𝐹superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′1/(\eta F_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}})1 / ( italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and add up over all such {s′,t′}superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′\{s^{\prime},t^{\prime}\}{ italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }, to get the new length for edges incident to v𝑣vitalic_v. Formally, for every edge e𝑒eitalic_e, let

ℓ~e:={∑s′,t′:ds′⁢t′>0ℓes′⁢t′/(η⁢Fs′⁢t′)if e is incident to v (in G),ℓeotherwise.assignsubscript~ℓ𝑒casessubscript:superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′subscript𝑑superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′0subscriptsuperscriptℓsuperscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′𝑒𝜂subscript𝐹superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′if e is incident to v (in G),subscriptℓ𝑒otherwise.\widetilde{\ell}_{e}:=\begin{cases}\sum_{s^{\prime},t^{\prime}:\ d_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}>0}\ \ell^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}_{e}/(\eta F_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}})\quad&\text{if $e$ is incident to $v$ (in $G$),}\\ \ell_{e}&\text{otherwise.}\end{cases}over~ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := { start_ROW start_CELL ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL start_CELL if italic_e is incident to italic_v (in italic_G ), end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL otherwise. end_CELL end_ROW (6.14)

To verify this LP solution is feasible, we only need to check that ys⁢t≤ℓ~s⁢v+ℓ~v⁢tsubscript𝑦𝑠𝑡subscript~ℓ𝑠𝑣subscript~ℓ𝑣𝑡y_{st}\leq\widetilde{\ell}_{sv}+\widetilde{\ell}_{vt}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ over~ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all s,t∈N⁢(v)𝑠𝑡𝑁𝑣s,t\in N(v)italic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_N ( italic_v ). To this end, fix s,t∈N⁢(v)𝑠𝑡𝑁𝑣s,t\in N(v)italic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_N ( italic_v ). We may assume that ds⁢t>0subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡0d_{st}>0italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0, as otherwise ys⁢tsubscript𝑦𝑠𝑡y_{st}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be set to a large enough value without affecting the objective (strictly speaking, this modifies the LP also in some ys⁢tsubscript𝑦𝑠𝑡y_{st}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT variables). We now have

ℓ~s⁢v+ℓ~v⁢tsubscript~ℓ𝑠𝑣subscript~ℓ𝑣𝑡\displaystyle\widetilde{\ell}_{sv}+\widetilde{\ell}_{vt}over~ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT =∑s′,t′:ds′⁢t′>0(ℓs⁢vs′⁢t′+ℓv⁢ts′⁢t′)/(η⁢Fs′⁢t′)absentsubscript:superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′subscript𝑑superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′0subscriptsuperscriptℓsuperscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′𝑠𝑣subscriptsuperscriptℓsuperscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′𝑣𝑡𝜂subscript𝐹superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′\displaystyle=\sum_{s^{\prime},t^{\prime}:\ d_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}>0}(\ell^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}_{sv}+\ell^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}_{vt})/(\eta F_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}})= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / ( italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) by plugging (6.14)
≥∑s′,t′:ds′⁢t′>0ys⁢ts′⁢t′/(η⁢Fs′⁢t′)absentsubscript:superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′subscript𝑑superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′0subscriptsuperscript𝑦superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′𝑠𝑡𝜂subscript𝐹superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′\displaystyle\geq\sum_{s^{\prime},t^{\prime}:\ d_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}>0}y^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}_{st}/(\eta F_{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}})≥ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ℓ→s′⁢t′,y→s′⁢t′superscript→ℓsuperscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′superscript→𝑦superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′\vec{\ell}^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}},\vec{y}^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}over→ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , over→ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is feasible
≥ys⁢ts⁢t/(η⁢Fs⁢t)absentsubscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑠𝑡𝑠𝑡𝜂subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡\displaystyle\geq y^{st}_{st}/(\eta F_{st})≥ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) using s′=s,t′=t.using s′=s,t′=t\displaystyle\text{using $s^{\prime}=s,\ t^{\prime}=t$}.using italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_s , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_t .

Moreover, the LP solution ℓ→s⁢t,y→s⁢tsuperscript→ℓ𝑠𝑡superscript→𝑦𝑠𝑡\vec{\ell}^{st},\vec{y}^{st}over→ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , over→ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (for the single-commodity demand 𝐞s⁢tsubscript𝐞𝑠𝑡\mathbf{e}_{st}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), satisfies the first constraint of LP, which simplifies to ys⁢ts⁢t=1subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑠𝑡𝑠𝑡1y^{st}_{st}=1italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. Also the LP solution ℓ→,y→→ℓ→𝑦\vec{\ell},\vec{y}over→ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG , over→ start_ARG italic_y end_ARG (for demand 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d) satisfies the first constraint, and then using requirement (ii), we have 1≥ds⁢t⁢ys⁢t≥η⁢Fs⁢t⁢ys⁢t1subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡subscript𝑦𝑠𝑡𝜂subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡subscript𝑦𝑠𝑡1\geq d_{st}y_{st}\geq\eta F_{st}y_{st}1 ≥ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Combining our last three estimates, we obtain

ℓ~s⁢v+ℓ~v⁢t≥ys⁢ts⁢t/(η⁢Fs⁢t)=1/(η⁢Fs⁢t)≥ys⁢t,subscript~ℓ𝑠𝑣subscript~ℓ𝑣𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑠𝑡𝑠𝑡𝜂subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡1𝜂subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡subscript𝑦𝑠𝑡\widetilde{\ell}_{sv}+\widetilde{\ell}_{vt}\geq y^{st}_{st}/(\eta F_{st})=1/(\eta F_{st})\geq y_{st},over~ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + over~ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1 / ( italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≥ italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

which completes the verification that the modified LP solution is feasible.

The objective value ∑ece⁢ℓesubscript𝑒subscript𝑐𝑒subscriptℓ𝑒\sum_{e}c_{e}\ell_{e}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the optimal LP solution is clearly at most the objective value ∑ece⁢ℓ~esubscript𝑒subscript𝑐𝑒subscript~ℓ𝑒\sum_{e}c_{e}\widetilde{\ell}_{e}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over~ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT of the modified LP solution, but since we only modified the length of edges incident to v𝑣vitalic_v (in G𝐺Gitalic_G), we get

We can now continue with the proof of Lemma 6.6 and prove the desired deviation bound on Z^^𝑍\widehat{Z}over^ start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG. Proof of Eqn. (6.10).

The proof generally resembles that of (6.9), although several details are different and somewhat more complicated. Set η:=ε/k2assign𝜂𝜀superscript𝑘2\eta:=\varepsilon/k^{2}italic_η := italic_ε / italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and define

𝒟U⁢B:={𝐝∈ℝ+(T2)∖{0} that satisfy requirements (i) and (ii) in Lemma 6.6}.assignsubscript𝒟𝑈𝐵𝐝∈ℝ+(T2)∖{0} that satisfy requirements (i) and (ii) in Lemma 6.6{\mathcal{D}}_{UB}:=\Big{\{}\text{$\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}\setminus\{0\}$ that satisfy requirements (i) and (ii) in Lemma \ref{lem:samplingUBfixedDemand}}\Big{\}}.caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := { d∈R+(T2)∖{0} that satisfy requirements (i) and (ii) in Lemma } . (6.15)

Then clearly |𝒟U⁢B|≤(2+log1+ε⁡1η)(k2)≤(1ε⁢log⁡kε)k2≤(log⁡kε)O⁢(k2).superscript𝒟𝑈𝐵superscript2subscript1𝜀1𝜂binomial𝑘2superscript1𝜀𝑘𝜀superscript𝑘2superscript𝑘𝜀𝑂superscript𝑘2\lvert{\mathcal{D}}^{UB}\rvert\leq\Big{(}2+\log_{1+\varepsilon}\tfrac{1}{\eta}\Big{)}^{\binom{k}{2}}\leq\Big{(}\tfrac{1}{\varepsilon}\log\tfrac{k}{\varepsilon}\Big{)}^{k^{2}}\leq\Big{(}\tfrac{\log k}{\varepsilon}\Big{)}^{O(k^{2})}.| caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ≤ ( 2 + roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 + italic_ε end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_η end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG italic_k end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ ( divide start_ARG roman_log italic_k end_ARG start_ARG italic_ε end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . Applying Lemma 6.6 to each 𝐝∈𝒟U⁢B𝐝superscript𝒟𝑈𝐵\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}^{UB}bold_d ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and a straightforward union bound, we see that with probability at least 1−|𝒟U⁢B|⋅e−ε2⁢η⁢M/k2≥0.91⋅superscript𝒟𝑈𝐵superscript𝑒superscript𝜀2𝜂𝑀superscript𝑘20.91-\lvert{\mathcal{D}}^{UB}\rvert\cdot e^{-\varepsilon^{2}\eta M/k^{2}}\geq 0.91 - | caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ⋅ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ε start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η italic_M / italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ 0.9, for every 𝐝∈𝒟U⁢B𝐝superscript𝒟𝑈𝐵\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}^{UB}bold_d ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT we have that demand (1+ε)2⁢𝐝superscript1𝜀2𝐝(1+\varepsilon)^{2}\,\mathbf{d}( 1 + italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_d cannot be satisfied in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG by flow along 2222-hop paths. We assume henceforth that this high-probability event indeed occurs, and show how this assumption implies the event in (6.10).

We thus aim to show that for every 𝐝∈ℝ+(T2)∖{0}𝐝superscriptsubscriptℝbinomial𝑇20\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{\binom{T}{2}}\setminus\{0\}bold_d ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( FRACOP start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∖ { 0 } we have λG^⁢(𝐝)≤(1+4⁢ε)⁢λG⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆^𝐺𝐝14𝜀subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda_{\smash{\widehat{G}}}(\mathbf{d})\leq(1+4\varepsilon)\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≤ ( 1 + 4 italic_ε ) italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). By scaling 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d appropriately, it suffices to show that whenever λG^⁢(𝐝)≥1subscript𝜆^𝐺𝐝1\lambda_{\smash{\widehat{G}}}(\mathbf{d})\geq 1italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≥ 1, i.e., the demand 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d can be satisfied in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG, the slightly scaled demand 11+4⁢ε⁢𝐝114𝜀𝐝\tfrac{1}{1+4\varepsilon}\ \mathbf{d}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + 4 italic_ε end_ARG bold_d can be satisfied in G𝐺Gitalic_G. By Lemma 5.1, it suffices to prove a statement that is similar, but with the stronger hypothesis that 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d can be satisfied in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG along 2222-hop paths. And indeed, this is what we prove next by way of contradiction.

Suppose, for sake of a contradiction, there is a demand 𝐝≠0𝐝0\mathbf{d}\neq 0bold_d ≠ 0 that can be satisfied in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG along 2222-hop paths, but 11+4⁢ε⁢𝐝114𝜀𝐝\tfrac{1}{1+4\varepsilon}\mathbf{d}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + 4 italic_ε end_ARG bold_d cannot be satisfied in G𝐺Gitalic_G, i.e., λG⁢(𝐝)<11+4⁢εsubscript𝜆𝐺𝐝114𝜀\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})<\tfrac{1}{1+4\varepsilon}italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + 4 italic_ε end_ARG. Let 𝐝−superscript𝐝\mathbf{d}^{-}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the vector obtained from 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d by zeroing every coordinate ds⁢tsubscript𝑑𝑠𝑡d_{st}italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT that is smaller than 2⁢η⁢Fs⁢t2𝜂subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡2\eta F_{st}2 italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We can write this vector as 𝐝−=𝐝−∑s⁢tαs⁢t⁢𝐞s⁢tsuperscript𝐝𝐝subscript𝑠𝑡subscript𝛼𝑠𝑡subscript𝐞𝑠𝑡\mathbf{d}^{-}=\mathbf{d}-\sum_{st}\alpha_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = bold_d - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where 𝐞s⁢tsubscript𝐞𝑠𝑡\mathbf{e}_{st}bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the standard basis vector for pair (s,t)𝑠𝑡(s,t)( italic_s , italic_t ), and αs⁢t:=ds⁢tassignsubscript𝛼𝑠𝑡subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡\alpha_{st}:=d_{st}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT if this value is smaller than 2⁢η⁢Fs⁢t2𝜂subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡2\eta F_{st}2 italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and otherwise αs⁢t:=0assignsubscript𝛼𝑠𝑡0\alpha_{st}:=0italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := 0.
