Claim 6.10.

𝐝U⁢B/(1+ε)2∈𝒟U⁢Bsuperscript𝐝𝑈𝐵superscript1𝜀2superscript𝒟𝑈𝐵\mathbf{d}^{UB}/(1+\varepsilon)^{2}\in{\mathcal{D}}^{UB}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( 1 + italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

Proof of Claim 6.10.

We need to show that 𝐝U⁢B/(1+ε)2superscript𝐝𝑈𝐵superscript1𝜀2\mathbf{d}^{UB}/(1+\varepsilon)^{2}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( 1 + italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfies the two conditions of Lemma 6.6. Starting with the proof of condition (i) by way of contradiction, let us assume that demand 𝐝U⁢B/(1+ε)superscript𝐝𝑈𝐵1𝜀\mathbf{d}^{UB}/(1+\varepsilon)bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( 1 + italic_ε ) can be satisfied in G𝐺Gitalic_G by flow along 2222-hop paths. The set of demands satisfiable in this manner (by 2222-hop flow paths in G𝐺Gitalic_G) is convex and down-monotone, and by definition contains also the demands Fs⁢t⁢𝐞s⁢tsubscript𝐹𝑠𝑡subscript𝐞𝑠𝑡F_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for every s,t∈T𝑠𝑡𝑇s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T. Thus, a linear combination of vectors in the set, whose coefficients are non-negative and sum up to (1−ε)+∑s,t∈Tαs⁢tFs⁢t≤(1−ε)+k22⋅2⁢η=11𝜀subscript𝑠𝑡𝑇subscript𝛼𝑠𝑡subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡1𝜀⋅superscript𝑘222𝜂1(1-\varepsilon)+\sum_{s,t\in T}\frac{\alpha_{st}}{F_{st}}\leq(1-\varepsilon)+\tfrac{k^{2}}{2}\cdot 2\eta=1( 1 - italic_ε ) + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ≤ ( 1 - italic_ε ) + divide start_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ⋅ 2 italic_η = 1, must also be in the set. Taking the linear combination

(1−ε)⋅𝐝U⁢B1+ε+∑s⁢t∈Tαs⁢tFs⁢t⋅Fs⁢t⁢𝐞s⁢t≥1−ε(1+ε)2⁢𝐝−+∑s⁢t∈Tαs⁢t⁢𝐞s⁢t≥11+4⁢ε⁢[𝐝−+∑s⁢t∈Tαs⁢t⁢𝐞s⁢t]=11+4⁢ε⁢𝐝,⋅1𝜀superscript𝐝𝑈𝐵1𝜀subscript𝑠𝑡𝑇⋅subscript𝛼𝑠𝑡subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡subscript𝐞𝑠𝑡1𝜀superscript1𝜀2superscript𝐝subscript𝑠𝑡𝑇subscript𝛼𝑠𝑡subscript𝐞𝑠𝑡114𝜀delimited-[]superscript𝐝subscript𝑠𝑡𝑇subscript𝛼𝑠𝑡subscript𝐞𝑠𝑡114𝜀𝐝(1-\varepsilon)\cdot\frac{\mathbf{d}^{UB}}{1+\varepsilon}+\sum_{st\in T}\frac{\alpha_{st}}{F_{st}}\cdot F_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}\geq\frac{1-\varepsilon}{(1+\varepsilon)^{2}}\,\mathbf{d}^{-}+\sum_{st\in T}\alpha_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}\geq\frac{1}{1+4\varepsilon}\Big{[}\mathbf{d}^{-}+\sum_{st\in T}\alpha_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}\Big{]}=\frac{1}{1+4\varepsilon}\,\mathbf{d},( 1 - italic_ε ) ⋅ divide start_ARG bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 + italic_ε end_ARG + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t ∈ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ⋅ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ divide start_ARG 1 - italic_ε end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 + italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t ∈ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + 4 italic_ε end_ARG [ bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t ∈ italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + 4 italic_ε end_ARG bold_d ,

we see that 11+4⁢ε⁢𝐝114𝜀𝐝\frac{1}{1+4\varepsilon}\,\mathbf{d}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + 4 italic_ε end_ARG bold_d can be satisfied in G𝐺Gitalic_G by flow along 2222-hop paths, and clearly also without the restriction on the flow paths. The latter contradicts our earlier assumption that λG⁢(𝐝)<11+4⁢εsubscript𝜆𝐺𝐝114𝜀\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})<\tfrac{1}{1+4\varepsilon}italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) < divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 1 + 4 italic_ε end_ARG, and thus proves condition (i).

We now prove condition (ii), which asserts that every nonzero coordinate ds⁢t′/(1+ε)2subscriptsuperscript𝑑′𝑠𝑡superscript1𝜀2d^{\prime}_{st}/(1+\varepsilon)^{2}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( 1 + italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is in the range [η⁢Fs⁢t,Fs⁢t]𝜂subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡[\eta F_{st},F_{st}][ italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ]. One direction is immediate: if ds⁢t′subscriptsuperscript𝑑′𝑠𝑡d^{\prime}_{st}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is non-zero, then ds⁢t′≥ds⁢t−/(1+ε)≥2⁢η⁢Fs⁢t/(1+ε)≥(1+ε)2⁢η⁢Fs⁢tsubscriptsuperscript𝑑′𝑠𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑠𝑡1𝜀2𝜂subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡1𝜀superscript1𝜀2𝜂subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡d^{\prime}_{st}\geq d^{-}_{st}/(1+\varepsilon)\geq 2\eta F_{st}/(1+\varepsilon)\geq(1+\varepsilon)^{2}\eta F_{st}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( 1 + italic_ε ) ≥ 2 italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( 1 + italic_ε ) ≥ ( 1 + italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For the other direction, observe that Fs⁢t>0subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡0F_{st}>0italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 because otherwise G𝐺Gitalic_G has no 2222-hop path of positive capacity between s𝑠sitalic_s and t𝑡titalic_t, which implies the same in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG, and we get ds⁢t′≤ds⁢t=0subscriptsuperscript𝑑′𝑠𝑡subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡0d^{\prime}_{st}\leq d_{st}=0italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0. Define F~s⁢tsubscript~𝐹𝑠𝑡\widetilde{F}_{st}over~ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be Fs⁢tsubscript𝐹𝑠𝑡F_{st}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT rounded down to the next power of 1+ε1𝜀1+\varepsilon1 + italic_ε, which means (1+ε)⁢F~s⁢t>Fs⁢t1𝜀subscript~𝐹𝑠𝑡subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡(1+\varepsilon)\widetilde{F}_{st}>F_{st}( 1 + italic_ε ) over~ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then the corresponding demand F~s⁢t⁢𝐞s⁢t∈𝒟U⁢Bsubscript~𝐹𝑠𝑡subscript𝐞𝑠𝑡superscript𝒟𝑈𝐵\widetilde{F}_{st}\mathbf{e}_{st}\in{\mathcal{D}}^{UB}over~ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and using our assumption about all demands in 𝒟U⁢Bsuperscript𝒟𝑈𝐵{\mathcal{D}}^{UB}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, demand (1+ε)2⁢F~s⁢tsuperscript1𝜀2subscript~𝐹𝑠𝑡(1+\varepsilon)^{2}\widetilde{F}_{st}( 1 + italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT cannot be satisfied by flow along 2222-hop paths in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG. Recalling that demand 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d can be satisfied in that manner, we derive the other direction ds⁢t′≤ds⁢t−≤ds⁢t<(1+ε)2⁢F~s⁢t≤(1+ε)2⁢Fs⁢tsubscriptsuperscript𝑑′𝑠𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑠𝑡subscript𝑑𝑠𝑡superscript1𝜀2subscript~𝐹𝑠𝑡superscript1𝜀2subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡d^{\prime}_{st}\leq d^{-}_{st}\leq d_{st}<(1+\varepsilon)^{2}\widetilde{F}_{st}\leq(1+\varepsilon)^{2}F_{st}italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ( 1 + italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over~ start_ARG italic_F end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ ( 1 + italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This completes the proof of requirement (ii), and of Claim 6.10. ∎

We now finish the proof of Eqn. (6.10). Recall that we assumed the high probability event in Lemma 6.6 occurred for every demand in 𝒟U⁢Bsuperscript𝒟𝑈𝐵{\mathcal{D}}^{UB}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Using Claim 6.10 we know that 𝐝U⁢B/(1+ε)2superscript𝐝𝑈𝐵superscript1𝜀2\mathbf{d}^{UB}/(1+\varepsilon)^{2}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( 1 + italic_ε ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfies the properties of Lemma 6.6, which implies that the scaled-up demand 𝐝U⁢Bsuperscript𝐝𝑈𝐵\mathbf{d}^{UB}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT cannot be satisfied in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG by flow along 2222-hop paths. Since 𝐝U⁢B≤𝐝−≤𝐝superscript𝐝𝑈𝐵superscript𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}^{UB}\leq\mathbf{d}^{-}\leq\mathbf{d}bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U italic_B end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ bold_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ bold_d, also demand 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d cannot be satisfied in this manner, but this contradicts the choice of 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d. This completes the proof of (6.10). ∎

6.3 An Extension to More General Graphs

An extension of the techniques for quasi-bipartite graphs is to the following case: let G𝐺Gitalic_G be a terminal network such that if we delete the terminal set T𝑇Titalic_T then each component of G∖T𝐺𝑇G\setminus Titalic_G ∖ italic_T has at most w𝑤witalic_w nodes in it. (The case of quasi-bipartite graphs is precisely when w=1𝑤1w=1italic_w = 1.) The sampling technique extends to this case; we now sketch the ideas for the extension.

Let the vertex sets of the components in G∖T𝐺𝑇G\setminus Titalic_G ∖ italic_T be V1,V2,…,Vlsubscript𝑉1subscript𝑉2…subscript𝑉𝑙V_{1},V_{2},\ldots,V_{l}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with each |Vi|≤wsubscript𝑉𝑖𝑤\lvert V_{i}\rvert\leq w| italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ≤ italic_w. (Again, assume T𝑇Titalic_T forms an independent set.) For each s,t∈T𝑠𝑡𝑇s,t\in Titalic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T, compute a max-flow that is terminal-free, i.e., it only uses flow-paths that go from s𝑠sitalic_s to t𝑡titalic_t using vertices within a single Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and does not contain terminals as internal nodes. Let Fs⁢t,isubscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑖F_{st,i}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the value of this flow using Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and Fs⁢t=∑iFs⁢t,isubscript𝐹𝑠𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑖F_{st}=\sum_{i}F_{st,i}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the value of the maximum s𝑠sitalic_s-t𝑡titalic_t terminal-free flow itself. Observe that Fs⁢t,isubscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑖F_{st,i}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT also equals the value of the s𝑠sitalic_s-t𝑡titalic_t min-cut within the graph G⁢[Vi∪{s,t}]𝐺delimited-[]subscript𝑉𝑖𝑠𝑡G[V_{i}\cup\{s,t\}]italic_G [ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ { italic_s , italic_t } ]. Define pi:=M⋅max⁡{Fs⁢t,iFs⁢t:s,t∈T}assignsubscript𝑝𝑖⋅𝑀:subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑖subscript𝐹𝑠𝑡𝑠𝑡𝑇p_{i}:=M\cdot\max\{{\frac{F_{st,i}}{F_{st}}:s,t\in T}\}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_M ⋅ roman_max { divide start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG : italic_s , italic_t ∈ italic_T }, and the sampling probability of component i𝑖iitalic_i is then p~i:=min⁡{pi,1}assignsubscript~𝑝𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖1\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{i}:=\min\{p_{i},1\}over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := roman_min { italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 1 }. Now we sample each component i𝑖iitalic_i (i.e., keep subset Visubscript𝑉𝑖V_{i}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) independently with probability p~isubscript~𝑝𝑖\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{i}over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, in which case we scale the capacities of its incident edges by 1/p~i1subscript~𝑝𝑖1/\smash{\widetilde{p}}_{i}1 / over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, to get overall a graph G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG.

The analysis proceeds almost unchanged. The number of vertices in G^^𝐺{\smash{\widehat{G}}}over^ start_ARG italic_G end_ARG is now O⁢(k2⁢M⋅w)𝑂⋅superscript𝑘2𝑀𝑤O(k^{2}M\cdot w)italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_M ⋅ italic_w ) with high probability. The proof of the lower bound (6.9) is unchanged, apart from replacing the use of 2222-hop paths by terminal-free paths. For the upper bound, we again write down the dual LP for terminal-free flows (analogous to (LP4)), construct dual solutions {ℓes′⁢t′},{ys⁢ts′⁢t′}subscriptsuperscriptℓsuperscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′𝑒subscriptsuperscript𝑦superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′𝑠𝑡\{\ell^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}_{e}\},\{y^{s^{\prime}t^{\prime}}_{st}\}{ roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } , { italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } using the max-flow/min-cut duality (as in Lemma 6.8), and argue that the contribution of each component i𝑖iitalic_i to the LP value is bounded (as in Claim 6.9). The rest of the arguments in the upper bound proceed analogously to the quasi-bipartite case; details omitted.

7 Results Using Flow/Cut Gaps

Given the k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal network and demand matrix 𝐝≠0𝐝0\mathbf{d}\neq 0bold_d ≠ 0, recall that λG⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) is the maximum multiple of 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d that can be sent through G𝐺Gitalic_G. We can also define the sparsity of a cut (S,V∖S)𝑆𝑉𝑆(S,V\setminus S)( italic_S , italic_V ∖ italic_S ) to be

ΦG⁢(S;𝐝):=∑e∈∂Sce∑i,j:|{i,j}∩S|=1di⁢j,assignsubscriptΦ𝐺𝑆𝐝subscript𝑒𝑆subscript𝑐𝑒subscript:𝑖𝑗𝑖𝑗𝑆1subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗\Phi_{G}(S;\mathbf{d}):=\frac{\sum_{e\in\partial S}c_{e}}{\sum_{i,j:|\{i,j\}\cap S|=1}d_{ij}},roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ; bold_d ) := divide start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e ∈ ∂ italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j : | { italic_i , italic_j } ∩ italic_S | = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ,

and the sparsest cut as

ΦG⁢(𝐝):=minS⊆V⁡ΦG⁢(S;𝐝).assignsubscriptΦ𝐺𝐝subscript𝑆𝑉subscriptΦ𝐺𝑆𝐝\Phi_{G}(\mathbf{d}):=\min_{S\subseteq V}\Phi_{G}(S;\mathbf{d}).roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) := roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S ⊆ italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ; bold_d ) .

Define the flow-cut gap as

γ⁢(G):=max𝐝∈𝒟⁢(G)⁡ΦG⁢(𝐝)/λG⁢(𝐝).assign𝛾𝐺subscript𝐝𝒟𝐺subscriptΦ𝐺𝐝subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\gamma(G):=\max_{\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G)}\Phi_{G}(\mathbf{d})/\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d}).italic_γ ( italic_G ) := roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_d ∈ caligraphic_D ( italic_G ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) / italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) .

It is easy to see that ΦG⁢(𝐝)≥λG⁢(𝐝)subscriptΦ𝐺𝐝subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\Phi_{G}(\mathbf{d})\geq\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≥ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) for each demand vector 𝐝𝐝\mathbf{d}bold_d (and hence γ⁢(G)≥1𝛾𝐺1\gamma(G)\geq 1italic_γ ( italic_G ) ≥ 1); a celebrated result of [LLR95, AR98] shows that for every k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal network G𝐺Gitalic_G, the gap is γ⁢(G)≤O⁢(log⁡k)𝛾𝐺𝑂𝑘\gamma(G)\leq O(\log k)italic_γ ( italic_G ) ≤ italic_O ( roman_log italic_k ). Many results are known about the flow-cut gap based on the structure of the graph G𝐺Gitalic_G and that of the support of the demands in 𝒟⁢(G)𝒟𝐺{\mathcal{D}}(G)caligraphic_D ( italic_G ); in this section we use these results together with known results about cut sparsifiers, to derive new results about flow sparsifiers.

It will be convenient to generalize the notion of a k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal network. Given a k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal network G=(V,E,c)𝐺𝑉𝐸𝑐G=(V,E,c)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E , italic_c ) with its associated subset T⊆V𝑇𝑉T\subseteq Vitalic_T ⊆ italic_V of k𝑘kitalic_k terminals, define the demand-support to be another undirected graph H=(T,F)𝐻𝑇𝐹H=(T,F)italic_H = ( italic_T , italic_F ) with some subset of edges F𝐹Fitalic_F between the terminals T𝑇Titalic_T. The demand polytope with respect to (G,H)𝐺𝐻(G,H)( italic_G , italic_H ) is the set of all demand vectors 𝐝=(de)e∈H𝐝subscriptsubscript𝑑𝑒𝑒𝐻\mathbf{d}=(d_{e})_{e\in H}bold_d = ( italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_e ∈ italic_H end_POSTSUBSCRIPT which are supported on the edges in the demand-support H𝐻Hitalic_H, that are routable in G𝐺Gitalic_G; i.e.,

𝒟⁢(G,H):={𝐝∈ℝ+F:demand 𝐝 can be routed in G}.assign𝒟𝐺𝐻conditional-set𝐝superscriptsubscriptℝ𝐹demand 𝐝 can be routed in G\displaystyle{\mathcal{D}}(G,H):=\{\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{F}:\ \text{demand $\mathbf{d}$ can be routed in $G$}\}.caligraphic_D ( italic_G , italic_H ) := { bold_d ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT : demand bold_d can be routed in italic_G } . (7.16)

This is a generalization of (2.5), where we defined H𝐻Hitalic_H to be the complete graph on the terminal set T𝑇Titalic_T. Define the flow-cut gap with respect to the pair (G,H)𝐺𝐻(G,H)( italic_G , italic_H ) as

γ⁢(G,H):=max⁡{ΦG⁢(𝐝)/λG⁢(𝐝):𝐝∈𝒟⁢(G,H)∖{0}}.assign𝛾𝐺𝐻:subscriptΦ𝐺𝐝subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝𝐝𝒟𝐺𝐻0\gamma(G,H):=\max\{{\Phi_{G}(\mathbf{d})/\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d}):\ \mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G,H)\setminus\{0\}}\}.italic_γ ( italic_G , italic_H ) := roman_max { roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) / italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) : bold_d ∈ caligraphic_D ( italic_G , italic_H ) ∖ { 0 } } .

Analogously to a flow sparsifier, we can define cut-sparsifiers. Given a k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal network G𝐺Gitalic_G with terminals T𝑇Titalic_T, a cut-sparsifier for G𝐺Gitalic_G with quality β≥1𝛽1\beta\geq 1italic_β ≥ 1 is a graph G′=(V′,E′,c′)superscript𝐺′superscript𝑉′superscript𝐸′superscript𝑐′G^{\prime}=(V^{\prime},E^{\prime},c^{\prime})italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_E start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) with T⊆V′𝑇superscript𝑉′T\subseteq V^{\prime}italic_T ⊆ italic_V start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, such that for every partition (A,B)𝐴𝐵(A,B)( italic_A , italic_B ) of T𝑇Titalic_T, we have

mincutG⁡(A,B)≤mincutG′⁡(A,B)≤β⋅mincutG⁡(A,B).subscriptmincut𝐺𝐴𝐵subscriptmincutsuperscript𝐺′𝐴𝐵⋅𝛽subscriptmincut𝐺𝐴𝐵\operatorname{mincut}_{G}(A,B)\leq\operatorname{mincut}_{G^{\prime}}(A,B)\leq\beta\cdot\operatorname{mincut}_{G}(A,B).roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ) ≤ roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ) ≤ italic_β ⋅ roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ) .

A cut-sparsifier G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is contraction-based if it is obtained from G𝐺Gitalic_G by increasing the capacity of some edges and by identifying some vertices (from the perspective of cuts and flows, the latter is equivalent to adding infinite capacity edges between vertices).

Theorem 7.1.

Given a k-terminal network G𝐺Gitalic_G with terminals T𝑇Titalic_T, let G′superscript𝐺normal-′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be a quality β≥1𝛽1\beta\geq 1italic_β ≥ 1 cut-sparsifier for G𝐺Gitalic_G. Then for every demand-support H𝐻Hitalic_H and all 𝐝∈ℝ+E⁢(H)𝐝superscriptsubscriptℝ𝐸𝐻\mathbf{d}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{E(H)}bold_d ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT + end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_E ( italic_H ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,

1γ⁢(G′,H)≤λG′⁢(𝐝)λG⁢(𝐝)≤β⋅γ⁢(G,H).1𝛾superscript𝐺′𝐻subscript𝜆superscript𝐺′𝐝subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝⋅𝛽𝛾𝐺𝐻\displaystyle\frac{1}{\gamma(G^{\prime},H)}\leq\frac{\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})}{\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})}\leq\beta\cdot\gamma(G,H).divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_γ ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) end_ARG ≤ divide start_ARG italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) end_ARG ≤ italic_β ⋅ italic_γ ( italic_G , italic_H ) . (7.17)

Therefore, the graph G′superscript𝐺normal-′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with edge capacities scaled up by γ⁢(G′,H)𝛾superscript𝐺normal-′𝐻\gamma(G^{\prime},H)italic_γ ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) is a quality β⋅γ⁢(G,H)⋅γ⁢(G′,H)normal-⋅normal-⋅𝛽𝛾𝐺𝐻𝛾superscript𝐺normal-′𝐻\beta\cdot\gamma(G,H)\cdot\gamma(G^{\prime},H)italic_β ⋅ italic_γ ( italic_G , italic_H ) ⋅ italic_γ ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) flow sparsifier for G𝐺Gitalic_G for all demands supported on H𝐻Hitalic_H.

Moreover, if G′superscript𝐺normal-′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a contraction-based cut-sparsifier, then trivially λG⁢(𝐝)≤λG′⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝subscript𝜆superscript𝐺normal-′𝐝\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\leq\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≤ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ), and hence G′superscript𝐺normal-′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT itself is a quality β⋅γ⁢(G,H)normal-⋅𝛽𝛾𝐺𝐻\beta\cdot\gamma(G,H)italic_β ⋅ italic_γ ( italic_G , italic_H ) flow sparsifier for G𝐺Gitalic_G for demands supported on H𝐻Hitalic_H.

Proof.

Consider a demand 𝐝∈𝒟⁢(G,H)𝐝𝒟𝐺𝐻\mathbf{d}\in{\mathcal{D}}(G,H)bold_d ∈ caligraphic_D ( italic_G , italic_H ); the maximum multiple of it we can route is λG⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). For any partition (A,B)𝐴𝐵(A,B)( italic_A , italic_B ) of the terminal set T𝑇Titalic_T, let d⁢(A,B):=∑{i,j}:|{i,j}∩A|=1di⁢jassign𝑑𝐴𝐵subscript:𝑖𝑗𝑖𝑗𝐴1subscript𝑑𝑖𝑗d(A,B):=\sum_{\{i,j\}:|\{i,j\}\cap A|=1}d_{ij}italic_d ( italic_A , italic_B ) := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_i , italic_j } : | { italic_i , italic_j } ∩ italic_A | = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The flow across a cut cannot exceed that cut’s capacity, hence λG⁢(𝐝)⋅d⁢(A,B)≤mincutG⁡(A,B)⋅subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝𝑑𝐴𝐵subscriptmincut𝐺𝐴𝐵\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\cdot d(A,B)\leq\operatorname{mincut}_{G}(A,B)italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ⋅ italic_d ( italic_A , italic_B ) ≤ roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ). Since G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is a cut sparsifier of G𝐺Gitalic_G, we have mincutG⁡(A,B)≤mincutG′⁡(A,B)subscriptmincut𝐺𝐴𝐵subscriptmincutsuperscript𝐺′𝐴𝐵\operatorname{mincut}_{G}(A,B)\leq\operatorname{mincut}_{G^{\prime}}(A,B)roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ) ≤ roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ), and together we obtain

λG⁢(𝐝)≤mincutG⁡(A,B)d⁢(A,B).subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝subscriptmincut𝐺𝐴𝐵𝑑𝐴𝐵\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\leq\frac{\operatorname{mincut}_{G}(A,B)}{d(A,B)}.italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≤ divide start_ARG roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_d ( italic_A , italic_B ) end_ARG .

Minimizing the right-hand side over all partitions (A,B)𝐴𝐵(A,B)( italic_A , italic_B ) of the terminals, we have λG⁢(𝐝)≤ΦG′⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝subscriptΦsuperscript𝐺′𝐝\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\leq\Phi_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≤ roman_Φ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). The flow-cut gap for G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT implies that λG⁢(𝐝)≤γ⁢(G′,H)⋅λG′⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝⋅𝛾superscript𝐺′𝐻subscript𝜆superscript𝐺′𝐝\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})\leq\gamma(G^{\prime},H)\cdot\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≤ italic_γ ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) ⋅ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ), which shows the first inequality in (7.17). For the second one, we just reverse the roles of G𝐺Gitalic_G and G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in the above argument, but now have to use that mincutG′⁡(A,B)≤β⋅mincutG⁡(A,B)subscriptmincutsuperscript𝐺′𝐴𝐵⋅𝛽subscriptmincut𝐺𝐴𝐵\operatorname{mincut}_{G^{\prime}}(A,B)\leq\beta\cdot\operatorname{mincut}_{G}(A,B)roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ) ≤ italic_β ⋅ roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ) to get λG′⁢(𝐝)β≤mincutG⁡(A,B)d⁢(A,B)subscript𝜆superscript𝐺′𝐝𝛽subscriptmincut𝐺𝐴𝐵𝑑𝐴𝐵\frac{\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})}{\beta}\leq\frac{\operatorname{mincut}_{G}(A,B)}{d(A,B)}divide start_ARG italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_β end_ARG ≤ divide start_ARG roman_mincut start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A , italic_B ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_d ( italic_A , italic_B ) end_ARG, and hence eventually that λG′⁢(𝐝)≤β⋅γ⁢(G,H)⋅λG⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆superscript𝐺′𝐝⋅⋅𝛽𝛾𝐺𝐻subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})\leq\beta\cdot\gamma(G,H)\cdot\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≤ italic_β ⋅ italic_γ ( italic_G , italic_H ) ⋅ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ).

For the second part of the theorem, observe that if G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is contraction-based, then it is a better flow network than G𝐺Gitalic_G, which means λG′⁢(𝐝)≥λG⁢(𝐝)subscript𝜆superscript𝐺′𝐝subscript𝜆𝐺𝐝\lambda_{G^{\prime}}(\mathbf{d})\geq\lambda_{G}(\mathbf{d})italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ) ≥ italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( bold_d ). ∎

This immediately allows us to infer the following results.

Corollary 7.2 (Single-Source Flow Sparsifiers).

For every k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal network G𝐺Gitalic_G, there exists a graph G′superscript𝐺normal-′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with 22ksuperscript2superscript2𝑘2^{2^{k}}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT vertices that preserves (exactly) all single-source and two-source flows.555A two-source flow means that there are two terminals t′,t′′∈Tsuperscript𝑡normal-′superscript𝑡normal-′′𝑇t^{\prime},t^{\prime\prime}\in Titalic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_T such that every non-zero demand is incident to at least one of t′,t′′superscript𝑡normal-′superscript𝑡normal-′′t^{\prime},t^{\prime\prime}italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Single-source flows are defined analogously with a single terminal.

Proof.

Hagerup et al. [HKNR98] show that all graphs have (contraction-based) cut-sparsifiers with quality β=1𝛽1\beta=1italic_β = 1 and size 22ksuperscript2superscript2𝑘2^{2^{k}}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (see also [KRTV12] for a slight improvement for undirected graphs). Moreover, it is known that whenever H𝐻Hitalic_H has a vertex cover of size at most 2222, the flow-cut gap is exactly γ⁢(G,H)=γ⁢(G′,H)=1𝛾𝐺𝐻𝛾superscript𝐺′𝐻1\gamma(G,H)=\gamma(G^{\prime},H)=1italic_γ ( italic_G , italic_H ) = italic_γ ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) = 1 [Sch03, Theorem 71.1c]. ∎

Corollary 7.3 (Outerplanar Flow Sparsifiers).

If G𝐺Gitalic_G is a planar graph where all terminals T𝑇Titalic_T lie on the same face, then G𝐺Gitalic_G has an exact (quality 1111) flow sparsifier with O⁢(k2⁢22⁢k)𝑂superscript𝑘2superscript22𝑘O(k^{2}2^{2k})italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) vertices. In the special case where G𝐺Gitalic_G is outerplanar, the size bound improves to O⁢(k)𝑂𝑘O(k)italic_O ( italic_k ).

Proof.

Okamura and Seymour [OS81] show that the flow-cut gap for planar graphs with all terminals on a single face is γ⁢(G,H)=1𝛾𝐺𝐻1\gamma(G,H)=1italic_γ ( italic_G , italic_H ) = 1, and Krauthgamer and Rika [KR13] show that every planar graph G𝐺Gitalic_G has a contraction-based cut-sparsifier G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with quality β=1𝛽1\beta=1italic_β = 1 and size O⁢(k2⁢22⁢k)𝑂superscript𝑘2superscript22𝑘O(k^{2}2^{2k})italic_O ( italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). And since the latter is contraction-based, also this G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is planar with all terminals on a single face, hence γ⁢(G′,H)=1𝛾superscript𝐺′𝐻1\gamma(G^{\prime},H)=1italic_γ ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) = 1.

To improve the bound when G𝐺Gitalic_G is outerplanar, we use a result of Chaudhuri et al. [CSWZ00, Theorem 5(ii)] that every outerplanar graph G𝐺Gitalic_G has a cut-sparsifiers G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with quality β=1𝛽1\beta=1italic_β = 1 and size O⁢(k)𝑂𝑘O(k)italic_O ( italic_k ), and moreover, this also G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is outerplanar and thus γ⁢(G′,H)=1𝛾superscript𝐺′𝐻1\gamma(G^{\prime},H)=1italic_γ ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) = 1. ∎

Corollary 7.4 (4444-terminal Flow Sparsifiers).

For k≤4𝑘4k\leq 4italic_k ≤ 4, every k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal network has an exact (quality 1111) flow sparsifier with at most k+1𝑘1k+1italic_k + 1 vertices.

Proof.

Lomonosov [Lom85] shows that the flow-cut gap for at most 4444 terminals is γ⁢(G,H)=γ⁢(G′,H)=1𝛾𝐺𝐻𝛾superscript𝐺′𝐻1\gamma(G,H)=\gamma(G^{\prime},H)=1italic_γ ( italic_G , italic_H ) = italic_γ ( italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H ) = 1, and Chaudhuri et al. [CSWZ00] show that all graphs with k≤5𝑘5k\leq 5italic_k ≤ 5 terminals have cut-sparsifiers with quality β=1𝛽1\beta=1italic_β = 1 and at most k+1𝑘1k+1italic_k + 1 vertices. (See also [KRTV12, Table 1].) ∎

The above two results are direct corollaries, but we can use Theorem 7.1 to get flow-sparsifiers with quality 1 from results on cut-sparsifiers, even when the flow-cut gap is more than 1111. E.g., for series-parallel graphs we know that the flow-cut gap is exactly 2 [CJLV08, CSW13, LR10], but we give in the next section quality 1111 flow-sparsifiers by using cut-sparsifiers more directly.

7.1 Series-Parallel Graphs and Graphs of Bounded Treewidth

To begin, we give some definitions. An s𝑠sitalic_s-t𝑡titalic_t series-parallel graph is defined recursively: it is either (a) a single edge {s,t}𝑠𝑡\{s,t\}{ italic_s , italic_t }, or (b) obtained by taking a parallel composition of two smaller s𝑠sitalic_s-t𝑡titalic_t series-parallel graphs by identifying their s𝑠sitalic_s and t𝑡titalic_t nodes, or (c) obtained by a series composition of an s𝑠sitalic_s-x𝑥xitalic_x series-parallel graph with an x𝑥xitalic_x-t𝑡titalic_t series-parallel graph by identifying their x𝑥xitalic_x node. See Figure 7.1. The vertices s,t𝑠𝑡s,titalic_s , italic_t are called the portals of G𝐺Gitalic_G, and the rest of the vertices will be called the internal vertices.

Theorem 7.5 (Series-Parallel Graphs).

Every k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal series-parallel network G𝐺Gitalic_G admits an exact (quality 1111) flow sparsifier with O⁢(k)𝑂𝑘O(k)italic_O ( italic_k ) vertices.

Proof.

The way we build a series-parallel graph G𝐺Gitalic_G gives us a decomposition tree 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T, where the leaves of 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T are edges in G𝐺Gitalic_G, and each internal node prescribes either a series or a parallel combination of the graphs given by the two subtrees. We can label each node in 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T by the two portals. We will assume w.l.o.g. that 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T is binary.

Consider some decomposition tree 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T where the two portals for the root node are themselves terminals, and let the number of internal terminals in 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T be k𝑘kitalic_k (giving us a total of k+2𝑘2k+2italic_k + 2 terminals, including the portals). We construct a sparsifier for G𝐺Gitalic_G by working on the decomposition tree 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T recursively as follows, producing a sparsifier graph with at most S⁢(k)𝑆𝑘S(k)italic_S ( italic_k ) vertices, for S⁢(k)𝑆𝑘S(k)italic_S ( italic_k ) that will be determined later. Consider the two subtrees 𝒯1,𝒯2subscript𝒯1subscript𝒯2\mathcal{T}_{1},\mathcal{T}_{2}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The easy case is when the number of internal terminals in 𝒯1,𝒯2subscript𝒯1subscript𝒯2\mathcal{T}_{1},\mathcal{T}_{2}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which we denote k1,k2subscript𝑘1subscript𝑘2k_{1},k_{2}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, are both strictly less than k𝑘kitalic_k. Let Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the graph defined by 𝒯isubscript𝒯𝑖\mathcal{T}_{i}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In case G1,G2subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2G_{1},G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are composed in parallel, recursively construct for them sparsifiers G1′,G2′superscriptsubscript𝐺1′superscriptsubscript𝐺2′G_{1}^{\prime},G_{2}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and compose these two sparsifiers in parallel to get G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT; the Composition Lemma 5.2 implies this is a sparsifier for G𝐺Gitalic_G. In case they are in series, the middle vertex may not be a terminal: so add it as a new terminal, recurse on G1,G2subscript𝐺1subscript𝐺2G_{1},G_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and again compose G1′,G2′subscriptsuperscript𝐺′1subscriptsuperscript𝐺′2G^{\prime}_{1},G^{\prime}_{2}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In either case, the number of internal vertices in the new graph is S⁢(k)≤S⁢(k1)+S⁢(k2)+1𝑆𝑘𝑆subscript𝑘1𝑆subscript𝑘21S(k)\leq S(k_{1})+S(k_{2})+1italic_S ( italic_k ) ≤ italic_S ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_S ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + 1, where we account for adding the middle vertex as a terminal.

Now suppose all the k𝑘kitalic_k internal terminals of the root of 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T are also internal terminals of 𝒯1subscript𝒯1\mathcal{T}_{1}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In this case, find the node in 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T furthest from the root such that the subtree 𝒯′superscript𝒯′\mathcal{T}^{\prime}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT rooted at this node still has k𝑘kitalic_k internal terminals, but neither of its child subtrees 𝒯1′,𝒯2′superscriptsubscript𝒯1′superscriptsubscript𝒯2′\mathcal{T}_{1}^{\prime},\mathcal{T}_{2}^{\prime}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT contains all the k𝑘kitalic_k internal terminals.666The easy case above is in fact a special case of this, where 𝒯′=𝒯superscript𝒯′𝒯\mathcal{T}^{\prime}=\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = caligraphic_T. There must be such a node, because the leaves of 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T contain no internal terminals. Say the portals of 𝒯′superscript𝒯′\mathcal{T}^{\prime}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are s′,t′superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′s^{\prime},t^{\prime}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. And say the graphs given by 𝒯′,𝒯1′,𝒯2′superscript𝒯′superscriptsubscript𝒯1′superscriptsubscript𝒯2′\mathcal{T}^{\prime},\mathcal{T}_{1}^{\prime},\mathcal{T}_{2}^{\prime}caligraphic_T start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are G′,G1′,G2′superscript𝐺′superscriptsubscript𝐺1′superscriptsubscript𝐺2′G^{\prime},G_{1}^{\prime},G_{2}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The picture looks like one of the cases in Figure 7.2.

Add the two portals s′,t′superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′s^{\prime},t^{\prime}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and if it was a series combination then also the middle vertex x𝑥xitalic_x between G1′,G2′superscriptsubscript𝐺1′superscriptsubscript𝐺2′G_{1}^{\prime},G_{2}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, as new terminals. Observe that G𝐺Gitalic_G is obtained by composing G∖G′𝐺superscript𝐺′G\setminus G^{\prime}italic_G ∖ italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (at the new terminals s′,t′superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′s^{\prime},t^{\prime}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT), hence we can apply the Composition Lemma to the sparsifiers for G∖G′𝐺superscript𝐺′G\setminus G^{\prime}italic_G ∖ italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and for G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We can use Corollary 7.4 to find a flow sparsifier for G∖G′𝐺superscript𝐺′G\setminus G^{\prime}italic_G ∖ italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT: it has only 4444 terminals s,t,s′,t′𝑠𝑡superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′s,t,s^{\prime},t^{\prime}italic_s , italic_t , italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. To find a flow sparsifier for G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we recurse on G1′,G2′superscriptsubscript𝐺1′superscriptsubscript𝐺2′G_{1}^{\prime},G_{2}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and then combine the resulting sparsifiers H1′,H2′superscriptsubscript𝐻1′superscriptsubscript𝐻2′H_{1}^{\prime},H_{2}^{\prime}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT by the Composition Lemma to get a sparsifier H′superscript𝐻′H^{\prime}italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Overall, we obtain a flow sparsifier for G𝐺Gitalic_G with at most S⁢(k)≤S⁢(k1)+S⁢(k2)+(c4−4)+3𝑆𝑘𝑆subscript𝑘1𝑆subscript𝑘2subscript𝑐443S(k)\leq S(k_{1})+S(k_{2})+(c_{4}-4)+3italic_S ( italic_k ) ≤ italic_S ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_S ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 4 ) + 3 internal vertices, where the number of new vertices generated by Corollary 7.4 is at most c4−4subscript𝑐44c_{4}-4italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 4, and we added in at most 3333 new terminals (namely s′,t′superscript𝑠′superscript𝑡′s^{\prime},t^{\prime}italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and possibly x𝑥xitalic_x).

In either case, we arrive at the recurrence S⁢(k)≤S⁢(k1)+S⁢(k2)+c4𝑆𝑘𝑆subscript𝑘1𝑆subscript𝑘2subscript𝑐4S(k)\leq S(k_{1})+S(k_{2})+c_{4}italic_S ( italic_k ) ≤ italic_S ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_S ( italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where k1+k2≤ksubscript𝑘1subscript𝑘2𝑘k_{1}+k_{2}\leq kitalic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_k and k1,k2≥1subscript𝑘1subscript𝑘21k_{1},k_{2}\geq 1italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 1. The base case is when there are at most 2222 internal terminals, in which case we can use Corollary 7.4 again to get S⁢(1),S⁢(2)≤c4𝑆1𝑆2subscript𝑐4S(1),S(2)\leq c_{4}italic_S ( 1 ) , italic_S ( 2 ) ≤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The recurrence solves to S⁢(k)≤(2⁢k−1)⋅c4𝑆𝑘⋅2𝑘1subscript𝑐4S(k)\leq(2k-1)\cdot c_{4}italic_S ( italic_k ) ≤ ( 2 italic_k - 1 ) ⋅ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Adding the two portal terminals of 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T still remains O⁢(k)𝑂𝑘O(k)italic_O ( italic_k ), and proves the theorem. ∎

7.2 Extension to Treewidth-w𝑤witalic_w Graphs

The general theorem about bounded treewidth graphs follows a similar argument but with looser bounds. The only fact about a treewidth-w𝑤witalic_w graph G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ) we use is the following.

Theorem 7.6 ([Ree92]).

If a graph G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E)italic_G = ( italic_V , italic_E ) has treewidth w𝑤witalic_w, then for every subset T⊆V𝑇𝑉T\subseteq Vitalic_T ⊆ italic_V, there exists a subset X⊆V𝑋𝑉X\subseteq Vitalic_X ⊆ italic_V of w𝑤witalic_w vertices such that each component of G−X𝐺𝑋G-Xitalic_G - italic_X contains at most 23⁢|T∖X|23𝑇𝑋\frac{2}{3}|T\setminus X|divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG | italic_T ∖ italic_X | vertices of T𝑇Titalic_T.

Theorem 7.7.

Suppose every k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal network admits a flow sparsifier of quality q⁢(k)𝑞𝑘q(k)italic_q ( italic_k ) and size S⁢(k)𝑆𝑘S(k)italic_S ( italic_k ). Then every k𝑘kitalic_k-terminal network G𝐺Gitalic_G with treewidth w𝑤witalic_w has a q⁢(6⁢w)𝑞6𝑤q(6w)italic_q ( 6 italic_w )-quality flow sparsifier with at most k4⋅S⁢(6⁢w)normal-⋅superscript𝑘4𝑆6𝑤k^{4}\cdot S(6w)italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ italic_S ( 6 italic_w ) vertices.

Proof.

The proof is by induction. Consider a graph G𝐺Gitalic_G: if it has at most 6⁢w6𝑤6w6 italic_w terminals, we just build a q⁢(6⁢w)𝑞6𝑤q(6w)italic_q ( 6 italic_w )-quality vertex sparsifier of size S⁢(6⁢w)𝑆6𝑤S(6w)italic_S ( 6 italic_w ).

Else, let T𝑇Titalic_T be the set of terminals in G𝐺Gitalic_G, and use Theorem 7.6 to find a set X𝑋Xitalic_X such that each component of G−X𝐺𝑋G-Xitalic_G - italic_X contains at most 23⁢|T∖X|23𝑇𝑋\frac{2}{3}|T\setminus X|divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG | italic_T ∖ italic_X | terminals. Suppose the components have vertex sets V1,V2,…,Vlsubscript𝑉1subscript𝑉2…subscript𝑉𝑙V_{1},V_{2},\ldots,V_{l}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT; let Gi:=G⁢[Vi∪X]assignsubscript𝐺𝑖𝐺delimited-[]subscript𝑉𝑖𝑋G_{i}:=G[V_{i}\cup X]italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_G [ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∪ italic_X ]. Recurse on each Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with terminal set (T∩Vi)∪X𝑇subscript𝑉𝑖𝑋(T\cap V_{i})\cup X( italic_T ∩ italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∪ italic_X to find a flow sparsifier Gi′superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖′G_{i}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of quality q⁢(6⁢w)𝑞6𝑤q(6w)italic_q ( 6 italic_w ). Now use the Composition lemma to merge these sparsifiers Gi′superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖′G_{i}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT together and give the sparsifier G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of the same quality. Now use the Composition lemma to merge these sparsifiers Gi′superscriptsubscript𝐺𝑖′G_{i}^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT together and give the sparsifier G′superscript𝐺′G^{\prime}italic_G start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT of the same quality.

If the number of terminals in G𝐺Gitalic_G was kGsubscript𝑘𝐺k_{G}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the number of terminals in each Gisubscript𝐺𝑖G_{i}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is smaller by at least 13⁢kG−w=kG/613subscript𝑘𝐺𝑤subscript𝑘𝐺6\frac{1}{3}k_{G}-w=k_{G}/6divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_w = italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / 6, and hence kGi≤5/6⁢kGsubscript𝑘subscript𝐺𝑖56subscript𝑘𝐺k_{G_{i}}\leq 5/6\,k_{G}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 5 / 6 italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Hence the depth of the recursion is at most h:=log6/5⁡(k/w)≤log6/5⁡kassignℎsubscript65𝑘𝑤subscript65𝑘h:=\log_{6/5}(k/w)\leq\log_{6/5}kitalic_h := roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 / 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k / italic_w ) ≤ roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 / 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k, and the number of leaves is at most 2hsuperscript2ℎ2^{h}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Each leaf gives us a sparsifier of size S⁢(6⁢w)𝑆6𝑤S(6w)italic_S ( 6 italic_w ), and combining these gives a sparsifier of size at most S⁢(6⁢w)⋅klog6/5⁡2≤S⁢(6⁢w)⋅k4⋅𝑆6𝑤superscript𝑘subscript652⋅𝑆6𝑤superscript𝑘4S(6w)\cdot k^{\log_{6/5}2}\leq S(6w)\cdot k^{4}italic_S ( 6 italic_w ) ⋅ italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_log start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 6 / 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_S ( 6 italic_w ) ⋅ italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. ∎

Using, e.g., results from Englert et al. [EGK+{}^{+}start_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT + end_FLOATSUPERSCRIPT10] we can achieve q⁢(k)=O⁢(log⁡klog⁡log⁡k)𝑞𝑘𝑂𝑘𝑘q(k)=O\big{(}\frac{\log k}{\log\log k}\big{)}italic_q ( italic_k ) = italic_O ( divide start_ARG roman_log italic_k end_ARG start_ARG roman_log roman_log italic_k end_ARG ) and S⁢(k)=k𝑆𝑘𝑘S(k)=kitalic_S ( italic_k ) = italic_k, which gives the results stated in Section 1.

  • [RV99] S. Rajagopalan and V. V. Vazirani. On the bidirected cut relaxation for the metric steiner tree problem. In 10th Annual ACM-SIAM Symposium on Discrete Algorithms, pages 742–751. SIAM, 1999.
  • [Sch03] A. Schrijver. Combinatorial Optimization. Springer, 2003.
  • [Shm97] D. Shmoys. Cut problems and their applications to divide-and-conquer. In D. Hochbaum, editor, Approximation Algorithms for NP-Hard Problems. PWS Publishing Company, 1997.
  • [SS11] D. A. Spielman and N. Srivastava. Graph sparsification by effective resistances. SIAM J. Comput., 40(6):1913–1926, December 2011.
  • [ST04] D. A. Spielman and S.-H. Teng. Nearly-linear time algorithms for graph partitioning, graph sparsification, and solving linear systems. In 36th Annual ACM Symposium on Theory of Computing, pages 81–90. ACM, 2004.
